description: In this series viewers will be introduced to the basics of the interworking of a computer’s system hardware and the individual components. The series will also tackle the basics of a computer operating system, applications, utilities and navigation. Finally the viewer will be guided through the basics of networking. This series is intended to give an introductory demonstration of the computing environment that most will encounter in todays world.
name: IC3 Computing Fundamentals
subtitle: Global Standard 5

episodes.description: In this series viewers will be introduced to the basics of the interworking of a computer’s system hardware and the individual components. The series will also tackle the basics of a computer operating system, applications, utilities and navigation. Finally the viewer will be guided through the basics of networking. This series is intended to give an introductory demonstration of the computing environment that most will encounter in todays world.
episodes.title: Overview

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe and discuss the basic mobile device uses:  As a personal cell phone, a voice mail system, a SMS system and even a notification system. They describe the device must be connected with a service provider for the usage of these system.  Wes also describes the it’s functionality as a phone and shows some of the components to manually setup the device to use the voice mail and notification systems as well.  The guys also briefly tell us some of the most common vendors of the phone hardware.
episodes.title: Mobile Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.054 --> 00:00:10.054
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.125 --> 00:00:15.221
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.221 --> 00:00:19.524
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and you are
watching the IC3 Computing Fundamentals

4
00:00:19.524 --> 00:00:22.673
show where we are about to take
a look at some mobile devices and

5
00:00:22.673 --> 00:00:26.760
talk about some of the different things
that we need to understand there.

6
00:00:26.760 --> 00:00:28.830
And who better to help us than Mr.
Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:28.830 --> 00:00:29.950
Wes, welcome to our show.

8
00:00:29.950 --> 00:00:32.764
>> Thank you, sir, it's good to
be here as always with ITProTV.

9
00:00:32.764 --> 00:00:35.330
And that's right, we're gonna be
looking at mobile devices today.

10
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:36.890
And we're gonna talk
a little bit about well,

11
00:00:36.890 --> 00:00:39.620
what is more importantly a cell phone.

12
00:00:39.620 --> 00:00:41.130
Cuz there's many different
mobile devices and

13

we'll talk about some of those
device types in a later episode.

14
00:00:43.890 --> 00:00:44.736
But for us today,

15
00:00:44.736 --> 00:00:48.303
what we're gonna be focusing in on
really is the concept of the cell phone.

16
00:00:48.303 --> 00:00:51.900
And how long have the cell
phones been around?

17
00:00:51.900 --> 00:00:53.930
Well, they've been around since,
I wanna say, like the late 70s or

18
00:00:53.930 --> 00:00:58.650
the early 80s was the first time somebody
made a call over the air through

19
00:00:58.650 --> 00:01:02.940
radiated energy and wasn't plugged in,
if you will, to the wall.

20
00:01:02.940 --> 00:01:05.800
I joke around with people and
I tell them I had a cell phone once and

21
00:01:05.800 --> 00:01:08.790
I got it all the way to Georgia
until the cord came out of the wall.

22
00:01:08.790 --> 00:01:13.260
But all joking aside, we're gonna
look at the mobile phone here, and

23

when it comes down to a mobile phone,
what are we talking about?

24
00:01:16.030 --> 00:01:17.520
Well, we're talking about a device that,

25
00:01:17.520 --> 00:01:20.030
first, like the name
implies is the mobility.

26
00:01:20.030 --> 00:01:25.096
The ability to move this device and not be

27
00:01:25.096 --> 00:01:27.685
Now they are more and
more prevalent today, and

28
00:01:27.685 --> 00:01:32.490
maybe you've heard of this term and maybe
you haven't, BYOD, bring your own device.

29
00:01:32.490 --> 00:01:36.165
They are in the home environment,
they are in the enterprise environment and

30
00:01:36.165 --> 00:01:41.990
we're having many millions of them as we
speak are probably being made right now.

31
00:01:41.990 --> 00:01:44.044
So looking at a mobile phone,

32
00:01:44.044 --> 00:01:49.314
let's talk about how I would get a mobile
phone before I even start to use it?

33

Well, mobile phones you typically go to a
vendor or provider and you purchase them.

34
00:01:53.492 --> 00:01:57.721
Now these are subscription based devices
in which you have to have a subscription

35
00:01:57.721 --> 00:01:58.850

36
00:01:58.850 --> 00:01:59.980
It's not like a desktop.

37

Right, if I purchase, let's say go to
a vendor and I purchase a desktop,

38
00:02:03.868 --> 00:02:04.760
I bring it home.

39
00:02:04.760 --> 00:02:09.376
Well, guess what, I don't need to talk
really to any kind of subscription

40
00:02:09.376 --> 00:02:12.085
provider in order to use that desktop.

41
00:02:12.085 --> 00:02:13.995
On the other hand,
if I have a mobile phone,

42
00:02:13.995 --> 00:02:17.265
if I don't talk to a subscription
provider and pay a monthly fee,

43
00:02:17.265 --> 00:02:22.980
the mobile phone's really gonna
be useless for us in that aspect.

44
00:02:22.980 --> 00:02:25.030
So let go ahead, let's dive right in.

45
00:02:25.030 --> 00:02:29.446
I've actually got a mobile phone
pulled up here on my computer, right.

46
00:02:29.446 --> 00:02:31.142
And with these mobile phones today,

47
00:02:31.142 --> 00:02:33.941
they definitely differ a lot
than they did in the early days.

48
00:02:33.941 --> 00:02:37.971
With these mobile phones today, these
are really, when it comes down to it,

49
00:02:37.971 --> 00:02:39.470
these are small computers.

50
00:02:39.470 --> 00:02:44.250
These are very, very powerful devices and
they allow us a lot of functionality.

51
00:02:44.250 --> 00:02:46.820
And what we really wanna look at is,

52
00:02:46.820 --> 00:02:50.775
just some of the basics on how you
would use a cellphone to begin with.

53
00:02:50.775 --> 00:02:52.060
We're gonna look at some
of the settings and

54
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:54.740
then we'll gonna talk a little bit
about how you would use one to dial out

55
00:02:54.740 --> 00:02:55.260
and make a call.

56
00:02:55.260 --> 00:02:56.430
All right, so

57
00:02:56.430 --> 00:02:59.930
this is the interface and there's
a couple of different types of phones.

58
00:02:59.930 --> 00:03:04.650
This is by far, when we talk about
the input and working with the phone,

59
00:03:04.650 --> 00:03:06.030
it's one of the more common ones.

60
00:03:06.030 --> 00:03:08.590
You can't really see it right here,
it's kinda off camera here.

61
00:03:08.590 --> 00:03:10.580
But this is a touch screen interface.

62
00:03:10.580 --> 00:03:15.490
And you can see on my computer
screen where I'm actually inputting,

63
00:03:15.490 --> 00:03:18.590
touching the screen if you will.

64
00:03:18.590 --> 00:03:22.210
Now the other type that we have is one
that's been around for a while as well and

65
00:03:22.210 --> 00:03:25.390
that's the one that has more
of the tactile push button.

66
00:03:25.390 --> 00:03:26.960
They're still out there,

67
00:03:26.960 --> 00:03:31.080
they're very prevalent but the most common
one today are the touch interfaces.

68
00:03:31.080 --> 00:03:33.600
And they're typically
today called smartphones

69
00:03:33.600 --> 00:03:37.680
versus another term that maybe you have or
haven't heard called the dumbphone, right.

70
00:03:37.680 --> 00:03:44.150
The older phones back in the 90s and even
the mid 2000s with Blackberry and stuff

71

and again they have the tactile keyboard
and sometimes you could use a stylus.

72
00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:52.310
When you look at these smartphones today,
again, primarily what we have is

73
00:03:52.310 --> 00:03:56.935
the touch interface as the means

74
00:03:56.935 --> 00:04:00.860
Let's go ahead and look at some of the
settings that you could configure in your

75
00:04:00.860 --> 00:04:04.420
cell phone so you'll be a little
bit more aware of how to use it.

76
00:04:04.420 --> 00:04:08.190
Now understand that what we're on
right now is a Windows mobile phone.

77
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:11.780
Some of the major mobile phones that
you have, really the big three,

78
00:04:11.780 --> 00:04:14.680
if you will, and I say big really big two,
as Ronnie and I were talking about

79

it prior to coming on stage here,

80
00:04:18.770 --> 00:04:23.300
The iPhone definitely is one that kind

81

82
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:28.380

83
00:04:28.380 --> 00:04:33.030
The other one being the Samsung
based devices, and this is Android.

84
00:04:33.030 --> 00:04:34.849
Not Samsung, excuse me,
I'm thinking of my phone.

85
00:04:34.849 --> 00:04:35.752
>> Android based.

86
00:04:35.752 --> 00:04:37.008
>> Yeah, the Android devices.

87
00:04:37.008 --> 00:04:39.180
Now when we look at
something like an iPhone or

88

we look at something like an Android,
they're definitely two completely

89
00:04:42.782 --> 00:04:46.190
different markets even though
we're talking about cellphones.

90
00:04:46.190 --> 00:04:51.180
When we look at iPhone, iPhone is what's
known as a close source proprietary phone

91
00:04:51.180 --> 00:04:56.090
in which the operating system that
runs on it is controlled by Apple and

92
00:04:56.090 --> 00:05:00.970
the hardware itself is controlled

93
00:05:00.970 --> 00:05:04.540
Now with the Android devices,
this is a little bit different.

94
00:05:05.680 --> 00:05:08.660
They have many different
devices that an Android

95
00:05:08.660 --> 00:05:12.190
phone operating system more

96
00:05:12.190 --> 00:05:16.060
And you have many different vendors out
there, Samsung being one of the ones that

97
00:05:16.060 --> 00:05:18.339
I think about cuz that's
the cell phone that I have.

98
00:05:19.350 --> 00:05:21.740
Android is an open source platform.

99
00:05:21.740 --> 00:05:24.400
And there's a little bit
of a major difference here.

100
00:05:24.400 --> 00:05:26.240
When we say proprietary,
what does that mean?

101
00:05:26.240 --> 00:05:30.724
Well, when we talk about proprietary,
what we mean is that, again,

102
00:05:30.724 --> 00:05:34.140

103
00:05:34.140 --> 00:05:38.700
They don't release it to the public,
it's maintained in-house, internally.

104
00:05:38.700 --> 00:05:41.598
And if, let's say, if Ronnie was
to get a piece of that code and

105
00:05:41.598 --> 00:05:44.277
say, hey, let me go ahead and
do some designing on that and

106
00:05:44.277 --> 00:05:47.340
maybe try to put that on a phone

107
00:05:47.340 --> 00:05:50.460
the company that owns that software,
that proprietary software,

108
00:05:50.460 --> 00:05:53.960
they could end up suing him for
everything that he's worth, right?

109
00:05:53.960 --> 00:05:58.530
Well, that's what the iOS, the operating
system that runs on the iPhone is,

110
00:05:58.530 --> 00:06:02.540
it's closed source and even the hardware

111
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:05.010
Now you look at something like Android,
when we say open source,

112
00:06:05.010 --> 00:06:06.970
we say non-proprietary.

113
00:06:06.970 --> 00:06:10.745
All right, what this means is that, and
I'm pretty sure when it came to Android,

114
00:06:10.745 --> 00:06:14.521
it started out with something known as the
Open Handset Alliance that started this

115
00:06:14.521 --> 00:06:18.026
operating system based on the Linux
kernel, and Google comes along and they

116
00:06:18.026 --> 00:06:21.944
say well, we really like this, we wanna
go ahead, and they purchased the company.

117
00:06:21.944 --> 00:06:25.500
Now today it's considered
Google's platform, if you will.

118
00:06:25.500 --> 00:06:30.925
But it is still open source in the fact
that the code that the operating system,

119
00:06:30.925 --> 00:06:37.040
right, what allows us to even use
the cellphone, it's freely downloadable.

120
00:06:37.040 --> 00:06:38.540
You can make contributions to it, and

121
00:06:38.540 --> 00:06:40.720
there's a lot of variance
out there as well.

122
00:06:40.720 --> 00:06:45.430
But one of the great things about that
is the fact that if you decide to make

123
00:06:45.430 --> 00:06:49.876
changes or modifications to the operating
system you're really not gonna be charged.

124
00:06:49.876 --> 00:06:52.120
So I wanna kinda set the stage for

125
00:06:52.120 --> 00:06:57.790
what cellphones you might see out there
and then some of the operating systems.

126
00:06:57.790 --> 00:06:59.210
So with that being said,

127
00:06:59.210 --> 00:07:02.210
the other one is maybe not quite
as popular as the first two.

128
00:07:02.210 --> 00:07:04.940
Those first two are definitely
the most popular.

129
00:07:04.940 --> 00:07:07.370
The third one there is the mobile phone.

130
00:07:07.370 --> 00:07:10.900
And the mobile phone, or the Windows,

131
00:07:10.900 --> 00:07:14.260

132

And this is also a closed source operating

134
00:07:21.790 --> 00:07:25.390

135
00:07:25.390 --> 00:07:27.400
But we're gonna go ahead and
look at that a little bit more.

So let's go ahead, let's dive back in.

We're gonna look at some of the settings,

140

And a lot of times what you have,

We talk about a smartphone and

00:08:03.984 --> 00:08:06.225
But we also wanna look at the basics too.

00:08:06.225 --> 00:08:07.791
How do you even make a phone call?

00:08:07.791 --> 00:08:12.926

00:08:18.070 --> 00:08:20.330

00:08:20.330 --> 00:08:23.660

155
00:08:23.660 --> 00:08:25.160
And then history as well is there.

159
00:08:35.408 --> 00:08:38.580
Well we could see that in

160
00:08:38.580 --> 00:08:41.110

161
00:08:41.110 --> 00:08:43.130
And then there's a button

162
00:08:43.130 --> 00:08:45.110
You have a series of buttons here.

163
00:08:45.110 --> 00:08:49.100
You can see that this one, the one all the

164
00:08:49.100 --> 00:08:50.920
Let me get back in there, sorry guys.

165
00:08:50.920 --> 00:08:51.770
That's your voicemail.

166
00:08:51.770 --> 00:08:53.220
We'll talk a little bit

167
00:08:53.220 --> 00:08:58.070
And then you have your keypad, and
the keypad really brings up the numerical

168

to enter the text if you will.

169
00:09:01.650 --> 00:09:06.330
If you wanted to you could, for

170
00:09:06.330 --> 00:09:10.310

something like that, right?

171
00:09:10.310 --> 00:09:15.230
And then all I have to do is I could
just choose call and, provided we have

172
00:09:15.230 --> 00:09:19.780
our subscription paid, we can make
a call to the other end, all right?

173
00:09:19.780 --> 00:09:20.720
Now that being said,

174
00:09:20.720 --> 00:09:22.840
fairly straight forward when it
comes to using a cell phone.

175
00:09:22.840 --> 00:09:27.140
It doesn't take much as far as dialing and
making a call.

176
00:09:27.140 --> 00:09:29.130
Again, voicemail is
something else that we have.

177
00:09:29.130 --> 00:09:32.720
But the really cool thing is,
we also have this other icon down here and

178
00:09:32.720 --> 00:09:34.780
this is your contacts icon, right?

179
00:09:34.780 --> 00:09:38.700
Your contacts icon can
bring you right into what,

180
00:09:38.700 --> 00:09:41.570
if you can think back to the old,
for instance, the old Rolodex,

181
00:09:41.570 --> 00:09:44.270
I know many people probably don't
know what a Rolodex is anymore.

182
00:09:44.270 --> 00:09:47.140
When you had contacts you would write
them down, you'd have a little book you

183
00:09:47.140 --> 00:09:50.410
would write down all your contacts,
and then if I need to call Ronnie and

184
00:09:50.410 --> 00:09:54.680
I don't know what his number is,
I could look into that little paper file.

185
00:09:54.680 --> 00:09:57.440
Well, obviously we're not going
to carry those around, so

186
00:09:57.440 --> 00:10:01.070
it makes it convenient in the fact that
we can have our contacts right here.

187
00:10:01.070 --> 00:10:06.600
And if we need to dial those contacts,
we can, all right?

188
00:10:06.600 --> 00:10:08.870
Now we also have the search functionality,
right?

189
00:10:08.870 --> 00:10:12.030
And the search functionality gives me
a little bit easier way, in this case,

190
00:10:12.030 --> 00:10:16.160
to just search through those contacts
without actually having to scroll through.

191
00:10:17.660 --> 00:10:21.680
All right, so fairly straight forward
process when it comes to using the cell

192
00:10:21.680 --> 00:10:23.990
phone to make a phone call.

193
00:10:23.990 --> 00:10:28.210
However, there are other things that you
might wanna be able or have the ability to

194
00:10:28.210 --> 00:10:32.130
do, so let's go ahead and
continue through some of those settings.

195
00:10:32.130 --> 00:10:34.900
All right, now the first one I
wanna talk about are the email and

196
00:10:34.900 --> 00:10:36.610
the accounts, all right?

197
00:10:36.610 --> 00:10:41.140
If you are going to allow your
cell phone to receive and

198
00:10:41.140 --> 00:10:44.260
send email,
you do have to set up your accounts.

199
00:10:44.260 --> 00:10:48.330
And whichever phone you have,
it might differ a little bit, but

200
00:10:48.330 --> 00:10:50.860
essentially the steps should
be pretty much the same.

201
00:10:50.860 --> 00:10:54.770
You have things like your Gmail accounts
that are out there, Exchange accounts.

202
00:10:54.770 --> 00:10:58.690
Yahoo accounts, I don't know, maybe a AOL,
I don't know if they still exist.

203
00:10:58.690 --> 00:11:01.250
But we could set those
up if we wanted too.

204
00:11:01.250 --> 00:11:05.090
And you could see, I have a Microsoft
account already attached to this.

205
00:11:05.090 --> 00:11:07.170
And if I wanted to,
I could add an account.

206
00:11:07.170 --> 00:11:09.080
And you could see some of
the options that we have, right?

207
00:11:09.080 --> 00:11:13.030
Exchange, if you have a business account,
you could setup an Exchange account.

208
00:11:13.030 --> 00:11:15.500
If you, Outlook.com.

209
00:11:15.500 --> 00:11:19.480
They old Hotmail if some of you maybe
guys know what the old Hotmail was.

210
00:11:19.480 --> 00:11:21.630
We could set that up and
then there's also, and

211
00:11:21.630 --> 00:11:23.060
you could see the provider by the way.

212
00:11:23.060 --> 00:11:25.706
This third one down here,

message, let me go ahead and

431
00:23:35.510 --> 00:23:36.230
show you guys.

432
00:23:36.230 --> 00:23:40.346
When you're sending a text message here,
it's fairly easy.

433
00:23:40.346 --> 00:23:46.455
I've got this nice little thought
bubble here and messaging there.

434
00:23:46.455 --> 00:23:49.406
Now that I've fumbled around for
it a little bit here, we'll go ahead and

435
00:23:49.406 --> 00:23:50.748
look at the text messaging here.

436
00:23:50.748 --> 00:23:55.535
So, you can see the little plus symbol
right down here and this plus symbol would

437
00:23:55.535 --> 00:24:00.177
allow me to start typing a text and what I
would do is I would put the contact here

438
00:24:00.177 --> 00:24:04.977
and whoever the contact might be and then
I could start typing the text message.

439
00:24:04.977 --> 00:24:10.494
I could do something
like This Is my text or

440
00:24:10.494 --> 00:24:13.600
test, if you will.

441
00:24:13.600 --> 00:24:17.170
And then what that allows me to do,
is once I put the contact in there,

442
00:24:17.170 --> 00:24:21.700
if I just go ahead and push send,
it'll send that text message only.

443
00:24:21.700 --> 00:24:24.580
Right, it's not a phone call so
we're not communicating with them

444
00:24:24.580 --> 00:24:29.140
other than through a text based method,
if you will.

445
00:24:29.140 --> 00:24:31.950
Now, remember one of the things that I
said that you could do here is that you

446
00:24:31.950 --> 00:24:34.380
could send an attachment.

447
00:24:34.380 --> 00:24:37.890
If I wanted to,
I could also add a picture, add a video.

448
00:24:37.890 --> 00:24:40.200
Now, I want you to keep
in mind something though.

449
00:24:40.200 --> 00:24:44.430
If you're not familiar with these data
plans, remember you start sending these

450
00:24:44.430 --> 00:24:47.800
text messages and a lot of times,
depending on your subscription,

451
00:24:47.800 --> 00:24:51.590
right, you could get text message for
really cheap today.

452
00:24:51.590 --> 00:24:55.120
But, if you start adding video, if you
start adding attachments through this,

453
00:24:55.120 --> 00:24:58.420
it's gonna chew through your data plan and
it's gonna cost you more money.

454
00:24:58.420 --> 00:25:03.070
So just keep that in mind that this
is a great way to send a quick,

455
00:25:03.070 --> 00:25:04.890
fast message to somebody.

456
00:25:04.890 --> 00:25:07.710
It's relatively inexpensive, but

457
00:25:07.710 --> 00:25:12.130
as you start adding attachments, you could
start adding a little bit more value,

458
00:25:12.130 --> 00:25:16.250
or charge, if you will,
to your regular SMS-based text messages.

459
00:25:16.250 --> 00:25:18.440
So very basic here.

460
00:25:18.440 --> 00:25:22.780
And at this point, once I was done all
I would have to do is just click Send,

461
00:25:22.780 --> 00:25:26.130
and it would send that text message,
let's say in this case, to Ronnie.

462
00:25:26.130 --> 00:25:30.560
And then if I dialed the number right or
used the contact, I got the right contact

463
00:25:30.560 --> 00:25:34.220
information, Ronnie's gonna end
up receiving that text message.

464
00:25:34.220 --> 00:25:35.760
>> Yeah, the neat thing or

465
00:25:35.760 --> 00:25:40.210
the nice thing then about the idea of
using text messages is that not only

466
00:25:40.210 --> 00:25:44.370
can we do that one to one communication
just like a regular telephone call, but

467
00:25:44.370 --> 00:25:48.890
let's say that Wes wanted a group
of us to go and meet for lunch.

468
00:25:48.890 --> 00:25:52.920
Well in theory if we were just doing this
on a telephone call, Wes would call me,

469
00:25:52.920 --> 00:25:55.120
and then call somebody else, and
then call somebody else, and

470
00:25:55.120 --> 00:25:59.050
then call somebody else, let's say four or
five different phone calls to do so.

471
00:25:59.050 --> 00:26:02.720
With the text messaging system though,
if he knows what my phone number is,

472
00:26:02.720 --> 00:26:06.390
he can actually add in all of our phone
numbers and just say, hey let's go and

473
00:26:06.390 --> 00:26:10.240
meet for pizza for lunch today and
then send that and

474
00:26:10.240 --> 00:26:14.820
it sends it to all of those people
in who the destination is for.

475
00:26:14.820 --> 00:26:17.550
And this way even if I'm in
the middle of working, I will

476
00:26:17.550 --> 00:26:21.270
get that message without having to pick
up the phone and so will everybody else.

477
00:26:21.270 --> 00:26:23.480
And then we can respond individually and

478
00:26:23.480 --> 00:26:26.740
that will also forward it on to
everybody in that group as well.

479
00:26:26.740 --> 00:26:28.370
Normally when you start doing that.

480
00:26:28.370 --> 00:26:31.590
So the idea of messaging,
this seems to kind of, almost,

481
00:26:31.590 --> 00:26:35.791
at least here in the United States to be
one of the most predominant reasons why we

482
00:26:35.791 --> 00:26:40.000
end up using the phone is the ability
to get these quick messages

483
00:26:40.000 --> 00:26:41.910
that we need to to
the people that we need to.

484
00:26:41.910 --> 00:26:47.090
And a lot of time it's taken even over
really the social side of things where

485
00:26:47.090 --> 00:26:51.460
you do walk into restaurants today and you
see people sitting at the same table and

486
00:26:51.460 --> 00:26:53.450
they're actually either
texting other people or

487
00:26:53.450 --> 00:26:57.190
even each other as they're actually
sitting right across from each other.

488
00:26:57.190 --> 00:27:00.790
So you do have some of that
that tends to go on there.

489
00:27:00.790 --> 00:27:05.730
But remember that the primary idea here
behind that cell phone is the idea

490
00:27:05.730 --> 00:27:10.400
here of being able to communicate and
establish that communication that we need.

491
00:27:10.400 --> 00:27:12.400
And we do have different
methods that are out there,

492
00:27:12.400 --> 00:27:17.020
it goes from the very most basic thing
which is simply to have a telephone call.

493
00:27:17.020 --> 00:27:21.250
And voice mail just like we used to have
answering machines by our phones, now we

494
00:27:21.250 --> 00:27:25.730
can actually carry that with us regardless
of where we are on this planet as well.

495
00:27:25.730 --> 00:27:28.780
And then of course you even have
fancy ones, which Wes was actually

496
00:27:28.780 --> 00:27:33.780
mentioning and even showed us here, in
that model of that Windows phone for us.

497
00:27:33.780 --> 00:27:38.200
And because we have barely scratched the
surface on that Windows phone technology,

498
00:27:38.200 --> 00:27:41.800
just by talking about the idea the phone,
and of course the text messaging and

499
00:27:41.800 --> 00:27:46.610
even the voicemail type setup and even
a basic notification on things as well.

500
00:27:46.610 --> 00:27:50.090
So there is a lot of features that
are actually in here with us Wes,

501
00:27:50.090 --> 00:27:54.160
is there anything we need to know about
just the basics of the mobile device

502
00:27:54.160 --> 00:27:55.380
that we've been talking about?

503
00:27:55.380 --> 00:27:56.970
>> No, I would say just subscription.

504
00:27:56.970 --> 00:28:01.350
Subscription is the important thing,
keep in mind that the features and

505
00:28:01.350 --> 00:28:05.150
functionalities that you have is really
based on the provider that you're

506
00:28:05.150 --> 00:28:06.350
gonna use as your carrier.

507
00:28:06.350 --> 00:28:10.280
So Like Ronnie said we've already,
we've talked about some of the basics.

508
00:28:10.280 --> 00:28:12.060
Keep in mind that you will
just tailor make these, or

509
00:28:12.060 --> 00:28:17.490
tweak them a little bit just to suit
whatever the provider is that you have.

510
00:28:17.490 --> 00:28:19.140
>> All right Wes, well thank you again for

511
00:28:19.140 --> 00:28:23.190
helping us to understand at least
the basics of these mobile devices.

512
00:28:23.190 --> 00:28:24.390
There's a lot more for

513
00:28:24.390 --> 00:28:28.050
us to actually think about when it
comes down to computing fundamentals.

514
00:28:28.050 --> 00:28:31.600
But at least you are getting a start here
on these mobile devices if you haven't

515
00:28:31.600 --> 00:28:32.570
encountered them before.

516
00:28:32.570 --> 00:28:36.680
And it is a great place for us to end this
episode as we also move on to new and

517
00:28:36.680 --> 00:28:38.880
other episodes that we
are going to be doing.

518
00:28:38.880 --> 00:28:42.460
So, signing off for ITProTV,
I have been your host Ronnie Wong.

519
00:28:42.460 --> 00:28:43.520
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

520
00:28:43.520 --> 00:28:48.654
Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

521
00:28:48.654 --> 00:28:55.414
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe different types of computing hardware systems that users are likely to use in a work environment.  They discuss the nature of desktop computers and compare to mobile types like laptops and tablets.   Also discussed by the team is the use of servers, supercomputers and mainframes especially the context of their usage. They emphasize the most likely use of each type of hardware and where a user is most likely to encounter the them in their work environment.
episodes.title: Hardware Device Types
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.132 --> 00:00:15.950
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.950 --> 00:00:17.380
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:17.380 --> 00:00:21.490
And you're watching the IC3 Computing
Fundamentals show, where we're about

5
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:25.110
to take a look at some of the different
types of computers that you and

6
00:00:25.110 --> 00:00:27.480
I may encounter as we
enter into the workforce,

7
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:30.330
where we're starting to work
with computers on a daily basis.

8
00:00:30.330 --> 00:00:33.330
Now everything that we see right here,
right, you may see some of them,

9
00:00:33.330 --> 00:00:34.320
you may not.

10
00:00:34.320 --> 00:00:38.910
But you at least need to have a concept
of what they are, and who better

11
00:00:38.910 --> 00:00:42.740
to help us than Mr. Wes Bryan to help us
understand some of these different ones.

12
00:00:42.740 --> 00:00:43.450
Welcome back Wes.

13
00:00:43.450 --> 00:00:44.850
>> Thank you for having me here.

14
00:00:44.850 --> 00:00:48.670
That's right it's great to be with ITProTV
and we are going to look at some of those

15
00:00:48.670 --> 00:00:51.620
device types and one of the first
things that we're gonna look at is,

16
00:00:51.620 --> 00:00:54.120
well, the traditional desktop PC.

17
00:00:54.120 --> 00:00:59.970
And this has definitely gone through many
changes since it's first release way back

18
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:05.210
in God I wanna say 80 something, early
80s when IBM well, first delivered it.

19
00:01:05.210 --> 00:01:08.750
And thank goodness that they're
not the size of refrigerators,

20
00:01:08.750 --> 00:01:09.620
like they used to be.

21
00:01:09.620 --> 00:01:13.030
Now let's keep in mind what a desktop is,
when we say a desktop,

22
00:01:13.030 --> 00:01:13.720
what are you talking about?

23
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:16.560
Are you talking about a desk and
the top of the desk?

24
00:01:16.560 --> 00:01:21.370
No, it's just a term that we use for
a small personal computer,

25
00:01:21.370 --> 00:01:23.370
hence the name PC.

26
00:01:23.370 --> 00:01:26.600
It usually has what's
known as a computer case.

27
00:01:26.600 --> 00:01:31.280
And when we talk about the size of
the desktop in relation to the hardware

28
00:01:31.280 --> 00:01:35.560
itself, a lot of times what we're talking
about is something known as a chassis,

29
00:01:35.560 --> 00:01:37.130
tower, or case.

30
00:01:37.130 --> 00:01:41.380
Now we're gonna look at some more of the
intricacies of the towers in general when

31
00:01:41.380 --> 00:01:43.020
we look at some of
the hardware components.

32
00:01:43.020 --> 00:01:46.250
But for now we just wanna understand
that what we're talking about is really

33
00:01:46.250 --> 00:01:48.030
the size of the computer.

34
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:50.760
And it all boils down to what
is the size of the case.

35
00:01:50.760 --> 00:01:52.030
Let me show you what I mean here.

36
00:01:52.030 --> 00:01:55.150
Here in my computer I've got,
Ronnie was just making a joke here.

37
00:01:55.150 --> 00:01:59.610
You guys didn't get to hear it, that he
remembers when that computer first came

38
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:03.020
out, maybe not this specific model but
certainly when computers were this big.

39
00:02:03.020 --> 00:02:04.910
They were probably the size of your desk.

40
00:02:04.910 --> 00:02:07.520
And who knows, they might have been
called desktops because, well,

41
00:02:07.520 --> 00:02:09.610
they came up to the top of
the desk in those days.

42
00:02:09.610 --> 00:02:14.340
Now, Ronnie do you remember something
like this when it was the size of

43
00:02:14.340 --> 00:02:15.438
a small refrigerator?

44
00:02:15.438 --> 00:02:19.490
>> [LAUGH] Well, this one's a little bit
smaller than a small refrigerator but

45
00:02:19.490 --> 00:02:22.160
just a little bit larger than a dinosaur.

46
00:02:22.160 --> 00:02:25.484
No, but overall though when you
start seeing something like this,

47
00:02:25.484 --> 00:02:29.039
most of these computers today that we
tend to have that we call desktops,

48
00:02:29.039 --> 00:02:32.860
it has this basic functionality and what
we need to work with on a daily basis.

49
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:34.030
And that's the key.

50
00:02:34.030 --> 00:02:37.190
Most the time if you're in a work
environment, you're probably going to

51
00:02:37.190 --> 00:02:41.550
end up with a computer that's gonna have
a monitor, a keyboard, probably a mouse.

52
00:02:41.550 --> 00:02:44.210
And sometimes and probably a lot of times,

53
00:02:44.210 --> 00:02:47.470
there may actually be a device that's
similar to this, if not smaller,

54
00:02:47.470 --> 00:02:51.740
but looks similar, that's gonna be
sitting in that same area with you.

55
00:02:51.740 --> 00:02:55.090
And that willl be your
working desktop computer.

56
00:02:55.090 --> 00:02:58.680
Now Wes, one of the limitations
behind a machine like this

57
00:02:58.680 --> 00:03:02.080
is that we are essentially tethered
to that area that we are working in.

58
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.390
And so when you need to do computing and
you roll away from the desk,

59
00:03:06.390 --> 00:03:10.670
you always have to come back to it, and
so the location to where this thing is,

60
00:03:10.670 --> 00:03:12.980
is pretty much the key here.

61
00:03:12.980 --> 00:03:15.760
And even though it's portable,
which means that you can move it

62
00:03:15.760 --> 00:03:20.280
from one area to another one, the problem
is moving it from one area to another one

63
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:22.750
is actually even a little bit
more challenging than you think.

64
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:26.870
Sometimes the computer itself is heavy,
but even then you still have to go and

65
00:03:26.870 --> 00:03:28.860
connect everything back
up once you move it.

66
00:03:28.860 --> 00:03:32.880
So as portable as it is,
it's really not mobile per se.

67
00:03:32.880 --> 00:03:34.200
>> Yeah, that's interesting.

68
00:03:34.200 --> 00:03:38.130
And it's funny, you don't have to do this,
but if you go watch some of the history on

69
00:03:38.130 --> 00:03:40.370
computers they would have called
this a portable computer.

70
00:03:40.370 --> 00:03:44.120
Not mobile by any means, a portable
computer because In those days when these

71
00:03:44.120 --> 00:03:47.120
were first coming out, computers were
typically the size of an entire room, and

72
00:03:47.120 --> 00:03:50.920
they certainly weren't going anywhere
unless the building was coming down.

73
00:03:50.920 --> 00:03:54.990
So this did give you
the first type of in-home

74
00:03:54.990 --> 00:03:57.230
appliance that you could have
that could do computing.

75
00:03:57.230 --> 00:04:01.185
Now more commonly today that we see, and
even though I do call this more of a full

76
00:04:01.185 --> 00:04:06.260
sized computer, it actually would be more
of the midsize computer in relation.

77
00:04:06.260 --> 00:04:08.172
So some of the earlier ones that
were even taller than that,

78
00:04:08.172 --> 00:04:09.740
like Ronnie's already mentioned.

79
00:04:09.740 --> 00:04:12.842
Now another common one here
that we have is the microtower.

80
00:04:12.842 --> 00:04:19.330
The microtower is really one of the most
common, if you will, desktop PCs.

81
00:04:19.330 --> 00:04:19.900
Why is that?

82
00:04:19.900 --> 00:04:21.580
Well it goes back to what
Ronnie was talking about.

83
00:04:21.580 --> 00:04:26.020
Not so much in the mobility aspect,
but we wanna save some space, right?

84
00:04:26.020 --> 00:04:30.933
We want these typically,
we're gonna have all the extra peripherals

85
00:04:30.933 --> 00:04:34.596
that we're gonna talk about
in later episodes, and

86
00:04:34.596 --> 00:04:39.027
we need them to fit within
the confine of a certain desk itself.

87
00:04:39.027 --> 00:04:41.166
The micro case if you will,

88
00:04:41.166 --> 00:04:46.190
micro PC is one of the ones that
does happen to be the most common.

89
00:04:46.190 --> 00:04:48.370
Now there's another one
that's out here too and

90
00:04:48.370 --> 00:04:51.820
that's called the slimline and
it's about half the size of this.

91
00:04:51.820 --> 00:04:54.960
Some of you might have seen it
before in things like banks, right,

92
00:04:54.960 --> 00:04:55.770
banks or schools.

93
00:04:55.770 --> 00:04:58.800
Schools, and
in fact I know my son's school

94
00:04:58.800 --> 00:05:03.400
has what are called the OptiPlex I believe
they're the 720s or something like that.

95
00:05:03.400 --> 00:05:06.120
And now we're literally
talking four inches thick.

96
00:05:06.120 --> 00:05:09.340
They sit on their side and
they put the monitor on top of those.

97
00:05:09.340 --> 00:05:14.570
Again you can also see them in things like
banks where the computer case is very,

98
00:05:14.570 --> 00:05:15.280
very small.

99
00:05:15.280 --> 00:05:16.610
And that's really about, again,

100
00:05:16.610 --> 00:05:20.900
not so much as it is mobility,
more than it is just space saving and

101
00:05:20.900 --> 00:05:24.320
getting a lot of these computers
in a relatively small space.

102
00:05:24.320 --> 00:05:28.150
So that's another one that you could
definitely see when you come down to it.

103
00:05:28.150 --> 00:05:32.170
Now what are the benefits over
let's say the full size case,

104
00:05:32.170 --> 00:05:35.460
or even the midsize case
as we would say today?

105
00:05:35.460 --> 00:05:39.910
Even some of the biggest gaming
unit cases are really still midsize

106
00:05:39.910 --> 00:05:41.640
cases compared to the earlier ones.

107
00:05:41.640 --> 00:05:42.970
So what's the benefit?

108
00:05:42.970 --> 00:05:47.060
Right, why would we want to get one of
these midsize cases, if you will, or

109
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:49.760
even one of these micro cases and

110
00:05:49.760 --> 00:05:54.400
it really comes down to the functionality
of the unit, in totality.

111
00:05:54.400 --> 00:05:57.925
And what I mean by that is bigger cases,
a lot of times,

112
00:05:57.925 --> 00:06:01.065
will allow for more customizations, right?

113
00:06:01.065 --> 00:06:05.665
If you have more space inside of
that case, a lot of times you can

114
00:06:05.665 --> 00:06:08.892
add more functionality by
adding additional components.

115
00:06:08.892 --> 00:06:12.072
I want you to think about,
maybe a small car, like,

116
00:06:12.072 --> 00:06:14.712
for instance, I got a small KIA, right?

117
00:06:14.712 --> 00:06:21.032
And let's just say, theoretically,
I didn't really worry about money,

118
00:06:21.032 --> 00:06:24.852
there's not a lot of modifications
I could make inside of that KIA,

119
00:06:24.852 --> 00:06:26.832
cuz there's no space to
put anything else in.

120
00:06:26.832 --> 00:06:29.730
So I'm pretty much limited
to what I have now.

121
00:06:29.730 --> 00:06:31.920
But if you step back in time a little bit,

122
00:06:31.920 --> 00:06:35.980
we go back to one of those muscle
cars back in the 60s, right?

123
00:06:35.980 --> 00:06:41.120
You could put a big block engine in
the car, and then you could jump inside,

124
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:45.500
next to the engine, and shut the hood,
and still have more space to add all

125
00:06:45.500 --> 00:06:48.770
the different components that you
really want to beef up that engine.

126

00:31:30.820 --> 00:31:33.910
And if you have never heard
about this term, it's IOT.

578
00:31:33.910 --> 00:31:36.050
They call it the Internet of Things.

579
00:31:36.050 --> 00:31:40.290
You also hear this blended with
things like embedded technologies.

580
00:31:40.290 --> 00:31:42.741
I actually got a little
demonstration here.

581
00:31:42.741 --> 00:31:46.263
I just want you to know as Internet
of Things just being the fact

582
00:31:46.263 --> 00:31:51.077
that a computing device isn't limited to
what we been talking about the traditional

583
00:31:51.077 --> 00:31:52.327
computing devices.

584
00:31:52.327 --> 00:31:56.534
Now we have the way that we can control
and you can see Things like health

585
00:31:56.534 --> 00:32:00.599
monitors here, Google Glass,
experience based devices as well,

586
00:32:00.599 --> 00:32:04.160
environmental systems,
control systems if you will.

587
00:32:04.160 --> 00:32:08.457
These have embedded chips and
they take a programming, if you will,

588
00:32:08.457 --> 00:32:10.841
a language to be able to control them.

589
00:32:10.841 --> 00:32:14.920
But there are certainly not
full blown desktop machines.

590
00:32:14.920 --> 00:32:19.450
They're not the, they do have their place
but their not the same thing as laptops.

591
00:32:19.450 --> 00:32:23.830
Again, very small, very stripped
down devices that allow the end user

592
00:32:23.830 --> 00:32:27.730
the ability to do things like develop and
design.

593
00:32:27.730 --> 00:32:28.460
They're very,

594
00:32:28.460 --> 00:32:33.880
very common today to provide young
kids with a way to get into computing.

595
00:32:33.880 --> 00:32:37.330
And they typically have a lowered expense.

596
00:32:37.330 --> 00:32:39.660
That doesn't mean that
they can't get expensive.

597
00:32:39.660 --> 00:32:41.120
But, pretty much,

598
00:32:41.120 --> 00:32:46.120
you have computing power that can control
just about any aspect of your life today.

599
00:32:46.120 --> 00:32:51.600
Like I said, health monitoring devices,
if you will, embedded in your cars.

600
00:32:51.600 --> 00:32:52.350
That's the other thing.

601
00:32:52.350 --> 00:32:55.900
You have a lot of computing systems
that are bedded right in your

602
00:32:55.900 --> 00:32:59.520
cars that are controlling things
like machinery and factory.

603
00:32:59.520 --> 00:33:01.260
So we do have to bring those up.

604
00:33:01.260 --> 00:33:05.370
Keep in mind that term IOT, just Internet
of Things just means that it's bringing

605
00:33:05.370 --> 00:33:09.240
everything online and connecting
it to the network so that we can

606
00:33:09.240 --> 00:33:13.370
control various systems throughout
our day to day goings on in life.

607
00:33:13.370 --> 00:33:16.330
>> There's no doubt that there's a lot of
different types of hardware that's out

608
00:33:16.330 --> 00:33:18.300
there for us and available to us.

609
00:33:18.300 --> 00:33:20.240
And if we're just entering
into the computing world,

610
00:33:20.240 --> 00:33:22.200
it can be a little bit overwhelming.

611
00:33:22.200 --> 00:33:25.920
But hopefully we've put into context
of when you're gonna normally encounter

612
00:33:25.920 --> 00:33:26.950
some of these things.

613
00:33:26.950 --> 00:33:29.390
More than likely today as
a person getting started,

614
00:33:29.390 --> 00:33:32.680
the desktop computer's gonna
be our day to day environment,

615
00:33:32.680 --> 00:33:35.300
whether that's gonna be something
like a laptop that's mobile or

616
00:33:35.300 --> 00:33:39.590
whether it's a desktop computer in which
we are tethered to that one location.

617
00:33:39.590 --> 00:33:43.220
You will also encounter the use of
servers, but in the background.

618
00:33:43.220 --> 00:33:45.420
In other words,
you don't have to go ahead and do it,

619
00:33:45.420 --> 00:33:49.680
you'll connect to them through software
and then the software handle exchange and

620
00:33:49.680 --> 00:33:51.988
the communication process and
everything else that we need.

621
00:33:51.988 --> 00:33:56.320
And at times, you may encounter
a super computer or even a mainframe.

622
00:33:56.320 --> 00:33:58.480
Those are normally purpose built or

623
00:33:58.480 --> 00:34:01.700
purpose driven in terms of
what they end up doing.

624
00:34:01.700 --> 00:34:07.020
And, of course, if you are driving
now in a relatively a modern vehicle

625
00:34:07.020 --> 00:34:09.800
that has the backup display,
that has the ability to for

626
00:34:09.800 --> 00:34:13.430
you connect your Bluetooth devices so
they can play through your systems,

627
00:34:13.430 --> 00:34:16.640
that allow you to connect your
cell phone or your mobile phone,

628
00:34:16.640 --> 00:34:21.230
smart phone, to be able to connect out and
also connect it to network and

629
00:34:21.230 --> 00:34:25.230
do GPS, that's part of that
internet of things option as well.

630
00:34:25.230 --> 00:34:30.440
One day if you don't already have it, even
your toaster oven inside of your home,

631
00:34:30.440 --> 00:34:35.290
may end up with one of these devices,
that will help it to connect and control.

632
00:34:35.290 --> 00:34:39.300
And that way as Wes is driving home and
he wants it to pop a pizza in that toaster

633
00:34:39.300 --> 00:34:43.410
oven, he can pop a piece of
pizza in that toaster oven and

634
00:34:43.410 --> 00:34:46.480
have it begin to warm and then he walks
through the door and there it is.

635
00:34:46.480 --> 00:34:48.380
It is nice and ready for him to go.

636
00:34:48.380 --> 00:34:51.870
So just kind of realize you are gonna
encounter this type of technology.

637
00:34:51.870 --> 00:34:55.590
Just being familiar with the idea is
actually gonna be part of the benefit that

638
00:34:55.590 --> 00:34:59.520
you'll understand as you continue to
work more and more with these devices.

639
00:34:59.520 --> 00:35:00.760
Wes, any last words?

640
00:35:00.760 --> 00:35:02.310
>> No, I pretty much think you go it.

641
00:35:02.310 --> 00:35:05.580
That's what I was gonna say is
that the desktops, laptops,

642
00:35:05.580 --> 00:35:08.790
tablets, those are really gonna be
the ones that you're gonna focus on.

643
00:35:08.790 --> 00:35:10.610
We just mentioned some of the other
ones in the background for

644
00:35:10.610 --> 00:35:11.530
the sake of completion.

645
00:35:11.530 --> 00:35:14.700
So that if you do get in an environment
where maybe they are using one of those

646
00:35:14.700 --> 00:35:17.640
purpose driven servers,
you're not like, my gosh, what is this?

647
00:35:17.640 --> 00:35:21.380
It’s just a computer that has
a different purpose, if you will, and

648
00:35:21.380 --> 00:35:24.750
more power but definitely pay attention
to the desktops, the laptops, and

649
00:35:24.750 --> 00:35:28.090
the tablets because you only going
to see more and more of them.

650
00:35:28.090 --> 00:35:32.500
>> All right well that's a great place for
us to also sign off for this episode then.

651
00:35:32.500 --> 00:35:35.870
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

652
00:35:35.870 --> 00:35:36.710
>> And I’m Wes Bryan.

653
00:35:36.710 --> 00:35:41.286
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

654
00:35:41.286 --> 00:35:47.458
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show and explain the the different hardware components found within the system unit.  They describe 64bit and 32 bit platforms as well as computing types:  PC and Apple based computers.  They also describe the basic units that must match in form factor:  the case, the motherboard and power supply unit.  They spend some time displaying the computer case and the features of the power supply unit.
episodes.title: Hardware Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:03.552
[SOUND]

2
00:00:03.552 --> 00:00:12.281
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:12.281 --> 00:00:14.490
Welcome to another great
episode right here in ITPro.Tv.

4
00:00:14.490 --> 00:00:16.930
I'm your host Ronnie Wong, and

5
00:00:16.930 --> 00:00:21.310
you're watching the IC3 Computing
Fundamental Show where we're about to dive

6
00:00:21.310 --> 00:00:25.340
into the hardware that we find
inside of a computer system.

7
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:28.080
And we have our hardware expert
with us today, Mr. Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:29.230
Wes, welcome back to our show.

9
00:00:29.230 --> 00:00:30.140
>> Thanks for having me here.

10
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:32.700
That's right, we're going to be
talking about hardware today.

11
00:00:32.700 --> 00:00:37.090
And to start us off here, we're going
to talk a little bit about platform,

12
00:00:37.090 --> 00:00:41.450
if you will, and compatibility,
because it is important to understand

13
00:00:41.450 --> 00:00:45.720
before you even attempt to start
working on your devices here,

14
00:00:45.720 --> 00:00:49.150
you really have to know what
kind of platform you have.

15
00:00:49.150 --> 00:00:51.250
So I wanna take a little
bit of time here and

16
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:55.460
just talk about the two main platform
types that we have out there and

17
00:00:55.460 --> 00:01:00.640
that is the IBM slash Intel base that we
typically call a PC, you might have heard

18
00:01:00.640 --> 00:01:05.660
it called PC market and just real
briefly wanna mention Macintosh as well.

19
00:01:05.660 --> 00:01:09.430
We're gonna be focusing in on the PC
side of things but we do wanna mention

20
00:01:09.430 --> 00:01:13.020
both of those platforms because we
wouldn't really be doing you any justice

21
00:01:13.020 --> 00:01:17.720
if we just mention PC so we do wanna
mention out there that the Macintosh

22
00:01:17.720 --> 00:01:22.650
platform has been around there
just about as long as PC has been.

23
00:01:22.650 --> 00:01:25.960
In fact, they've both been around
about the same amount of time.

24
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:30.310
Primarily though, when we talk about
Intel base, we talk about PC based,

25
00:01:30.310 --> 00:01:33.390
what we're really looking at when
we start to build a machine,

26
00:01:33.390 --> 00:01:38.190
there's another component that we've
got to consider and that really is

27
00:01:38.190 --> 00:01:42.570
whether your system is 32-bit or
whether it's 64-bit.

28
00:01:42.570 --> 00:01:43.730
And what this means for

29
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:47.180
us really is just the amount of
information that the processor can chew.

30
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:50.030
Now the processor we'll get to in a bit,
but I'm gonna go ahead and

31
00:01:50.030 --> 00:01:51.640
mention a couple of terms here and

32
00:01:51.640 --> 00:01:55.270
I'll try to set the stage before we
actually show you what the processor is.

33
00:01:55.270 --> 00:01:59.570
Just for now if you will, think of it
as the brains of the entire operation.

34
00:01:59.570 --> 00:02:03.238
It what does all the arithmetic and
the calculations if you will.

35
00:02:03.238 --> 00:02:08.430
And the 32-bit if you will,
there's 32 bits

36
00:02:08.430 --> 00:02:13.010
of information that gets shoved in to
the CPU for it to calculate, all right.

37
00:02:13.010 --> 00:02:16.385
So these 32 bit chunks if you will.

38
00:02:16.385 --> 00:02:19.990
64-bit doubles the width of that
amount of that information,

39
00:02:19.990 --> 00:02:24.580
and there's 64 bits that can be
chewed off at a single time.

40
00:02:24.580 --> 00:02:28.400
Now when we say this, please understand
that when we say 32 bits it doesn't take

41
00:02:28.400 --> 00:02:33.060
long to calculate that information
because our modern CPUs can do

42
00:02:33.060 --> 00:02:37.220
billions of calculations in a second, so
think about it as eating a whole bunch

43
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:42.410
of food really quick and you guys can
probably see I can eat some food here.

44
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:45.310
If I can eat more food than
the person next to me that would

45
00:02:45.310 --> 00:02:49.850
be kind of the comparison, if you will,
from the 32-bit to the 64-bit system.

46
00:02:49.850 --> 00:02:53.700
And you might say well why wouldn't
I just get a 64-bit system?

47
00:02:53.700 --> 00:02:54.950
Well, that's up to you.

48
00:02:54.950 --> 00:03:01.815
And again it does It really hinges on what
do you actually need in your systems.

49
00:03:01.815 --> 00:03:07.770
32-bit still has it's benefit inside
of things like smaller systems, smaller

50
00:03:07.770 --> 00:03:12.600
notebooks, if you will, that don't need
a lot of processing power if you will.

51
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:15.030
Just really basic devices.

52
00:03:15.030 --> 00:03:17.980
But the main thing we really look
at when we look at 32-bit and

53
00:03:17.980 --> 00:03:21.730
we look at 64-bit is the amount
of something known as memory.

54
00:03:21.730 --> 00:03:23.970
And again,
we're gonna talk more about memory.

55
00:03:23.970 --> 00:03:27.620
Again, let me kinda set the stage for
that so as I mention these terms,

56
00:03:27.620 --> 00:03:28.810
it doesn't sound foreign to you.

57
00:03:28.810 --> 00:03:33.650
I just want you to think about as memory
as a temporary place that we put data

58
00:03:33.650 --> 00:03:36.950
before or
after the CPU needs to work with it.

59
00:03:36.950 --> 00:03:42.105
So the amount of that memory,
that staging area where we can store

60
00:03:42.105 --> 00:03:47.778
data temporarily for the CPU to work with
it, the amount of memory is limited.

61
00:03:47.778 --> 00:03:54.100
In a 32-bit system, we have a maximum of
what's known as 4GB of system memory.

62
00:03:54.100 --> 00:03:58.720
Now in the 64-bit, theoretically
there is a limit, but I don't think

63
00:03:58.720 --> 00:04:03.280
that we're gonna see a system with
the upper limit of that memory.

64
00:04:03.280 --> 00:04:06.860
It's just a massive amount of memory,
we don't have systems

65
00:04:06.860 --> 00:04:11.660
right now that really support that
amount of memory in a system,

66
00:04:11.660 --> 00:04:14.925
so we want you to know that
going out the gate first.

67
00:04:14.925 --> 00:04:20.440
Know that 32-bit versus 64-bit is really
going to dictate what kind of pieces,

68
00:04:20.440 --> 00:04:25.648
what kind of motherboard you're gonna
get and then ultimately what we're gonna

69
00:04:25.648 --> 00:04:30.952
lead up to what you're gonna talk about is
the software that you run on the system.

70
00:04:30.952 --> 00:04:33.698
So it is important before
you start any kind of build,

71
00:04:33.698 --> 00:04:37.909
before you start working on the computers
is knowing what the platform is that your

72
00:04:37.909 --> 00:04:41.998
supporting so that you can make sure that
you get the right components if you ever

73
00:04:41.998 --> 00:04:45.134
need to replace anything,
if you need to service anything.

74
00:04:45.134 --> 00:04:50.634
And nobody would wanna have to spend money
on a whole bunch of that system memory and

75
00:04:50.634 --> 00:04:55.830
then realize that when you put it in
the system you're only seeing four gigs.

76
00:04:55.830 --> 00:04:58.880
You might be wasting your money,
so those are good things to know.

77
00:04:58.880 --> 00:05:03.590
The other one I might just briefly mention
here is ARM, ARM based processors if you

78
00:05:03.590 --> 00:05:08.580
will, because of how many
mobile devices are out there.

79
00:05:08.580 --> 00:05:11.800
Okay, this is not something you're
gonna find in one of your desktop PCs.

80
00:05:11.800 --> 00:05:14.170
It's typically something you're
gonna find in a cell phone.

81
00:05:14.170 --> 00:05:16.090
It's something you're
gonna find in a tablet.

82
00:05:16.090 --> 00:05:17.150
And I just wanna mention them here,

83
00:05:17.150 --> 00:05:20.710
because it's the other architecture that's
out there and it's important to know that.

84
00:05:20.710 --> 00:05:24.450
Again, you're not gonna find these inside
of these bigger systems like that.

85
00:05:24.450 --> 00:05:27.340
They're low powered, they're low heat, and

86
00:05:27.340 --> 00:05:29.080
they're typically in
things like cell phones.

87
00:05:29.080 --> 00:05:32.780
And it does lend itself to mentioning it.

88
00:05:32.780 --> 00:05:34.920
Now the other thing I'll tell
you that you have to know,

89
00:05:34.920 --> 00:05:37.750
I mentioned briefly about compatibility.

90
00:05:37.750 --> 00:05:40.450
I mentioned the chipset, all right, well,

91
00:05:40.450 --> 00:05:43.730
there's other things that are involved
with that chipset, and drivers.

92
00:05:43.730 --> 00:05:46.110
Now, what is a driver,
what are we talking about?

93
00:05:46.110 --> 00:05:49.590
Are we talking about something
out there on a golf course that

94
00:05:49.590 --> 00:05:51.570
we hit a golf ball 300 yards?

95
00:05:51.570 --> 00:05:54.680
Not really, what we're talking
about is a piece of software.

96
00:05:54.680 --> 00:05:57.930
And I know we haven't gotten into software
yet but this is a very important piece of

97
00:05:57.930 --> 00:06:03.090
software that really dictates whether
you can use your hardware at all.

98
00:06:03.090 --> 00:06:08.180
And that is basically a component within
the operating system that takes a language

99
00:06:08.180 --> 00:06:15.480
that our operating system is written in,
the software that runs the machine, right.

100
00:06:15.480 --> 00:06:19.500
Well it can't run the machine because
it's speaking a foreign language

101
00:06:19.500 --> 00:06:22.410
as opposed to what our
hardware is speaking, right?

102
00:06:22.410 --> 00:06:28.060
Our hardware speaks a completely different
machine dependent type of lingo, right?

103
00:06:28.060 --> 00:06:30.890
And if we want these two to interact,
we want them to communicate,

104
00:06:30.890 --> 00:06:33.860
well we've got to put like a translator,
right in the middle of it, right?

105
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:37.290
If I don't speak Spanish and
I wanna have a conversation with somebody

106
00:06:37.290 --> 00:06:40.990
that speaks Spanish, well I would love
to know Spanish but I don't speak it.

107
00:06:40.990 --> 00:06:42.850
I would have to get a translator, right?

108
00:06:42.850 --> 00:06:45.920
If you take the translator out then we're
not really making much sense between

109
00:06:45.920 --> 00:06:50.170
the conversation and likewise somebody
talking back to me trying to understand

110
00:06:50.170 --> 00:06:53.400
the English that I'm speaking and it's
just gonna sound like nothing to them.

111
00:06:53.400 --> 00:06:57.330
You put the translator in the way, right,
and now you've got communication and

112
00:06:57.330 --> 00:07:00.740
that's what the driver does, so it's
important getting back to 32 and 64 bit,

113
00:07:00.740 --> 00:07:06.160
you'll see that it all hinges
on those decisions that you make

114
00:07:06.160 --> 00:07:10.720
when you first get your computer or when
you're buying, repairing or building one.

115
00:07:10.720 --> 00:07:15.180
So 32-bit drivers go with 32-bit systems.

116
00:07:15.180 --> 00:07:17.640
64-bit drivers go with 64-bit systems.

117
00:07:17.640 --> 00:07:19.450
Let's go ahead and step back.

118
00:07:19.450 --> 00:07:24.280
Remember, those drivers,
32-bit translators, if you will,

119
00:07:24.280 --> 00:07:28.050
allow the operating system,
on a 32-bit machine,

120
00:07:28.050 --> 00:07:33.050
to talk to the hardware on the 32-bit
machine, and likewise with 64-bit.

121
00:07:33.050 --> 00:07:36.920
Now, I also mentioned a component
called the chipset right?

122
00:07:36.920 --> 00:07:40.700
Well, that has to do with another
component, that we're gonna talk about,

123
00:07:40.700 --> 00:07:43.950
coming up known as a motherboard,
all right?

124
00:07:43.950 --> 00:07:48.040
And it is what really
handles a lot of the majority

125
00:07:48.040 --> 00:07:52.190
of the communication between the operating
system and its drivers and the hardware.

126
00:07:52.190 --> 00:07:53.100
Let me go ahead and show you.

127
00:07:53.100 --> 00:07:53.756
I pulled up a web site.

128
00:07:53.756 --> 00:07:57.461
There's only really two chipsets that
we have to worry about in today's

129
00:07:57.461 --> 00:07:58.137
day and age.

130
00:07:58.137 --> 00:07:59.609
And, I'm up on Intel's site.

131
00:07:59.609 --> 00:08:04.892
I know it's kind of hard to see here; but,
this is actually Intel chipset software

132
00:08:04.892 --> 00:08:09.890
installation makes it very easy if you're
not sure you know have Intel board.

133
00:08:09.890 --> 00:08:12.530
You find out the specifications
of your system unit and

134
00:08:12.530 --> 00:08:15.420
you say okay, you know it's Intel,
I need this chipset drivers.

135
00:08:15.420 --> 00:08:17.930
Now what does that mean, all right?

136
00:08:17.930 --> 00:08:21.570
In your system there is a crucial
collection of these little,

137
00:08:21.570 --> 00:08:26.580
little computing chips that really
govern all the traffic that goes

138
00:08:26.580 --> 00:08:29.970
across this motherboard and
allows the communication there.

139

In the earlier days, it was used for
some of the earlier hard drives.

365
00:20:30.330 --> 00:20:35.760
Earlier hard drives stands as a power
supply connector if you will.

366
00:20:35.760 --> 00:20:39.870
Today, with the older hard drive system,

367
00:20:39.870 --> 00:20:43.520
that we're not really using too much any
more, you might still see it out there.

368
00:20:43.520 --> 00:20:45.710
It isn't much of a necessity for that.

369
00:20:45.710 --> 00:20:50.960
However, what you can do is you can take,
we need cooling in our systems, right?

370
00:20:50.960 --> 00:20:53.635
To make sure that they don't overheat.

371
00:20:53.635 --> 00:20:55.085
Well because of that,

372
00:20:55.085 --> 00:21:01.085
you can use that connector on this
power supply for system fans.

373
00:21:01.085 --> 00:21:04.115
So keep in mind, this is the Molex
connector, a little four pin connector

374
00:21:04.115 --> 00:21:06.659
that you can use,
typically today with your system fans.

375
00:21:09.020 --> 00:21:14.440
Now, remember how I told I said that
some of these power supplies don't or

376
00:21:14.440 --> 00:21:16.800
it'll have a connector that
you might use any more.

377
00:21:16.800 --> 00:21:19.620
This remember always reminds me
of like the old space invaders or

378
00:21:19.620 --> 00:21:21.040
something like that.

379
00:21:21.040 --> 00:21:23.340
This little four pin connector
is called a bird connector.

380
00:21:23.340 --> 00:21:24.810
That is for your floppy disks.

381
00:21:24.810 --> 00:21:28.460
I know some of you out there maybe
you still see floppies,,but for

382
00:21:28.460 --> 00:21:32.770
most part this is considered more
of a legacy connector in general.

383
00:21:32.770 --> 00:21:36.300
Again, not to say that you couldn't see it
out there but we do put it here because

384
00:21:36.300 --> 00:21:39.550
you can still see your power supplies
that they have those on them.

385
00:21:41.370 --> 00:21:43.560
All right, so
that takes care of some of the connectors.

386
00:21:43.560 --> 00:21:48.810
We do have one other that I'll save for
the hard drives themselves, and

387
00:21:48.810 --> 00:21:53.530
that is the serial ATA,
another hard drive technology.

388
00:21:53.530 --> 00:21:56.250
But, it does look like Ronnie's got
something that he wants to throw in there.

389
00:21:56.250 --> 00:21:57.110
Ronnie, what you got sir?

390
00:21:57.110 --> 00:22:00.020
>> Well, when we start taking
a look at a power supply,

391
00:22:00.020 --> 00:22:03.290
also a key thing that we wanna understand
as I start to take a look at it, and

392
00:22:03.290 --> 00:22:05.650
I was making sure that we saw this.

393
00:22:05.650 --> 00:22:09.950
Remember that when we do connect
a computer to be able to run,

394
00:22:09.950 --> 00:22:14.540
we have this connector right here that
goes to where our power supply is actually

395
00:22:14.540 --> 00:22:16.500
gonna get power from.

396
00:22:16.500 --> 00:22:19.055
That is alternating current.

397
00:22:19.055 --> 00:22:20.280
Now,I know that sounds strange.

398
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:20.900
If you already know.
Greg,

399
00:22:20.900 --> 00:22:24.870
you're telling me that there's alternating
current coming into the power supply.

400
00:22:24.870 --> 00:22:26.940
And why in the world is that important?

401
00:22:26.940 --> 00:22:31.610
It is important because every
component inside of the system

402
00:22:31.610 --> 00:22:36.580
unit itself runs off of
direct current instead.

403
00:22:36.580 --> 00:22:41.040
So the power supply not only plays
the function to provide different power

404
00:22:41.040 --> 00:22:44.770
to all those components that Wes was
mentioning, the motherboard as well as

405
00:22:44.770 --> 00:22:49.390
the different devices that are inside,
but it also does a conversion, right?

406
00:22:49.390 --> 00:22:54.230
It takes whatever the outlet power is
from your wall, whether it's actually

407
00:22:54.230 --> 00:22:58.660
the 240 or 220 or 110, 120 whatever it is,
an alternating current.

408
00:22:58.660 --> 00:23:03.130
And then, out each of these pigtail types
of connections that you see regardless of

409
00:23:03.130 --> 00:23:10.060
whichever one it is, it supplies a lower
voltage that is also a direct current.

410
00:23:10.060 --> 00:23:16.760
So at its heart, at its basic function
of what it does it is a power converter.

411
00:23:16.760 --> 00:23:23.050
Converts alternating current into direct
current and when it does it it takes

412
00:23:23.050 --> 00:23:28.640
things 220 volts and it may convert
it down to 5 volts, or 12 volts,

413
00:23:28.640 --> 00:23:34.520
or even 3 volts of power, and so
it does a lot of things for us.

414
00:23:34.520 --> 00:23:37.900
And if you're not ever sure,
make sure that when you take a look at,

415
00:23:37.900 --> 00:23:40.190
take a look at the label on the side, and

416
00:23:40.190 --> 00:23:45.410
it will normally tell you the overall
wattage in what you need as well.

417
00:23:45.410 --> 00:23:48.860
And if you're having to replace
one because one has died.

418
00:23:48.860 --> 00:23:51.000
Make sure you get one that's equal to or

419
00:23:51.000 --> 00:23:55.060
greater than the number that's
listed here on this label.

420
00:23:55.060 --> 00:23:56.360
And that's the key.

421
00:23:56.360 --> 00:23:59.340
Never get one that is
lower than that as well.

422
00:23:59.340 --> 00:24:02.870
So make sure you get one that's
equal to or greater than that.

423
00:24:02.870 --> 00:24:06.570
Most of the time we're not gonna
have to worry about this too much.

424
00:24:06.570 --> 00:24:11.510
But every once in a while you will run
across broken or dead power supplies, and

425
00:24:11.510 --> 00:24:13.710
these things must come out of the system.

426
00:24:13.710 --> 00:24:17.240
It's always best to get one that at
least matches, but normally they die.

427
00:24:17.240 --> 00:24:20.520
It's probably two or three years,
and technology has improved, so

428
00:24:20.520 --> 00:24:23.600
you'll probably get one that ends up
giving you more wattage, as well.

429
00:24:23.600 --> 00:24:25.440
But do remember that conversion process.

430
00:24:25.440 --> 00:24:28.220
It's very important that we
get that concept locked down,

431
00:24:28.220 --> 00:24:30.085
and that's why we need it.

432
00:24:30.085 --> 00:24:33.570
It'd be very interesting if all our
components would run off of alternating

433
00:24:33.570 --> 00:24:36.420
current, but
none of them inside the computer does, and

434
00:24:36.420 --> 00:24:37.915
that's why this is also important.

435
00:24:37.915 --> 00:24:40.910
>> Yeah, we definitely don't have
the case taking your components and

436
00:24:40.910 --> 00:24:46.000
trying to powering them to a 110 volts or
210 volts like Ronnie said,

437
00:24:46.000 --> 00:24:49.640
it's gonna do that power stepping down,
that power inversion, and it is important.

438
00:24:49.640 --> 00:24:53.300
It's one of the things that make that
power supply just such an important

439
00:24:53.300 --> 00:24:56.290
component inside of our machines.

440
00:24:56.290 --> 00:24:59.110
Well, Ronnie,
I've got a lot more to talk about, man.

441
00:24:59.110 --> 00:25:01.670
But it looks like you've
let me talk a lot here, so

442
00:25:01.670 --> 00:25:04.410
it looks like we are going to
have to go into a part two.

443
00:25:04.410 --> 00:25:05.620
>> Sounds like a great idea,

444
00:25:05.620 --> 00:25:09.170
remember that we took a look at some
of the very basic components here.

445
00:25:09.170 --> 00:25:12.520
When you talk about the individual
components within the computer system,

446
00:25:12.520 --> 00:25:15.400
we took a look at the case,
we also briefly talked about

447
00:25:15.400 --> 00:25:19.390
how that case fits in there,
do to something called form factors.

448
00:25:19.390 --> 00:25:22.930
And, if you're deciding that you're gonna
build your own computer, and you're gonna

449
00:25:22.930 --> 00:25:25.910
do something like that, and you got to
remember that those things have to match.

450
00:25:25.910 --> 00:25:26.660
In form factor.

451
00:25:26.660 --> 00:25:28.770
At least the power supply,
the motherboard, and

452
00:25:28.770 --> 00:25:32.510
the case at the very beginning,
at the bare minimum, those are what

453
00:25:32.510 --> 00:25:35.740
has to be able to match cuz they're
gonna all go in the same case together.

454
00:25:35.740 --> 00:25:38.370
And then of course,
realizing that we have to have enough

455
00:25:38.370 --> 00:25:40.760
power to power up those
components as well.

456
00:25:40.760 --> 00:25:42.510
So you wanna make sure
that you understand that.

457
00:25:42.510 --> 00:25:45.480
And we talked about of course,
just really one unit so

458
00:25:45.480 --> 00:25:49.380
far of what we normally find inside,
which is a power supply itself.

459
00:25:49.380 --> 00:25:52.230
And that is kinda one of the most
important units because without it,

460
00:25:52.230 --> 00:25:54.770
well there is no raw computer
system that functions and

461
00:25:54.770 --> 00:25:58.848
all you really have is well
a very big gigantic paper weight.

462
00:25:58.848 --> 00:26:01.110
>> That's right.
>> It's what we have here.

463
00:26:01.110 --> 00:26:04.020
Well that's a great place for
us to end this episode then.

464
00:26:04.020 --> 00:26:06.070
Signing off our ITProTV.

465
00:26:06.070 --> 00:26:07.540
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

466
00:26:07.540 --> 00:26:08.590
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

467
00:26:08.590 --> 00:26:13.280
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing fundamentals.

468
00:26:13.280 --> 00:26:20.880
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show and demonstrates some additional hardware components beginning with the motherboard and cpu.  They take the time to describe how each of these function and some attributes of how they’re rated for use.   They want to makes sure that we understand how the cpu, motherboard, ram and even expansion card help us to improve the system unit’s performance.
episodes.title: Hardware Components Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.155 --> 00:00:15.970
Welcome to another great
episode here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.970 --> 00:00:20.080
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and you're
watching the IC3 Computing Fundamental

4
00:00:20.080 --> 00:00:25.270
show where we're about to continue on to a
part two on different hardware components.

5
00:00:25.270 --> 00:00:28.390
We've already taken a look at the system
case and the power supply and

00:00:28.390 --> 00:00:30.350
talked about form factors a little bit and

00:00:30.350 --> 00:00:34.040
even some of the platform
differences that are out there.

8
