And now we're actually moving
on to some other things, and

9
00:00:37.570 --> 00:00:40.950
our hardware guy is with us again,
Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:40.950 --> 00:00:41.959
Wes, welcome back to our show.

11
00:00:41.959 --> 00:00:43.220
>> Thanks for having me back here.

12
00:00:43.220 --> 00:00:45.140
It's great to be with the ITProTV crew.

13
00:00:45.140 --> 00:00:49.330
That's right, we are gonna be continuing
on with more of those hardware components

14
00:00:49.330 --> 00:00:51.940
because, well,
I talked a lot in the first episode and

15
00:00:51.940 --> 00:00:53.980
we just couldn't get all
of those components in.

16
00:00:53.980 --> 00:00:56.510
So let's go ahead and dive right back in.

17
00:00:56.510 --> 00:01:00.700
In the first episode we looked at
the system unit right, or the case.

18
00:01:00.700 --> 00:01:03.980
Remember system unit is collectively the
whole thing with all of its components in

19
00:01:03.980 --> 00:01:07.620
there, the case is one
part of the system unit.

20
00:01:07.620 --> 00:01:09.200
We also looked at the power supply and

21
00:01:09.200 --> 00:01:12.520
keep in mind form factor,
form factor, form factor.

22
00:01:12.520 --> 00:01:16.390
When it comes down to it, three things
that you need to make sure match in their

23
00:01:16.390 --> 00:01:19.930
form factor and that's the case,
the motherboard, and the power supply.

24
00:01:19.930 --> 00:01:22.590
So we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna dive in here.

25
00:01:22.590 --> 00:01:25.450
The first thing that we're gonna talk
about is well let's talk a little bit

26
00:01:25.450 --> 00:01:27.190
about motherboards right?

27
00:01:27.190 --> 00:01:28.370
What is a motherboard?

28
00:01:28.370 --> 00:01:32.412
Well if the case is the exoskeleton,
the skin that brings everything and

29
00:01:32.412 --> 00:01:34.076
holds everything together.

30
00:01:34.076 --> 00:01:37.770
Well the motherboard is definitely
the backbone of the computing system.

31
00:01:37.770 --> 00:01:41.290
It's where everything connects,
if you will.

32
00:01:41.290 --> 00:01:42.610
And it is very,

33
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:48.440
very important to understand what is this
big circuit board even doing for us.

34
00:01:48.440 --> 00:01:52.784
Well, the circuit board itself is made
up of a lot of different components.

35
00:01:52.784 --> 00:01:56.526
And when we look at a motherboard, let's
go ahead, I'll tell you what, let's go

36
00:01:56.526 --> 00:02:00.330
ahead and look at a motherboard and we'll
talk about some of these components here.

37
00:02:00.330 --> 00:02:02.530
I've pulled up this motherboard here,
and you can see man,

38
00:02:02.530 --> 00:02:05.070
we've got all kinds of things
going on on this thing.

39
00:02:05.070 --> 00:02:07.170
Remember when we showed you the case?

40
00:02:07.170 --> 00:02:11.270
We did look at the back of the case,
it had this rectangular pattern.

41
00:02:11.270 --> 00:02:13.950
Now what's interesting,
notice that pattern.

42
00:02:13.950 --> 00:02:18.810
I would almost be willing to bet that
if I was to measure the pattern there

43
00:02:18.810 --> 00:02:22.941
that rectangular pattern where
all of those connectors go,

44
00:02:22.941 --> 00:02:25.616
matches the case that we have, right?

45
00:02:25.616 --> 00:02:30.452
Now, it doesn't match the arrangements of
all these little openings that are called

46
00:02:30.452 --> 00:02:34.820
connection ports, but the square,
that rectangular pattern does match and

47
00:02:34.820 --> 00:02:40.010
that's part of that form factor standard,
that's where we get that consistency.

48
00:02:40.010 --> 00:02:43.913
Now we've got other components, now all
right, now, keep in mind that it's always,

49
00:02:43.913 --> 00:02:47.684
when we talk about computers in general,
it's always about information, right?

50
00:02:47.684 --> 00:02:49.450
It's an information system.

51
00:02:49.450 --> 00:02:52.880
So, what is our information doing here,
when it comes to this motherboard?

52
00:02:52.880 --> 00:02:56.500
Well, we have these little highways,
these copper highways, if you will.

53
00:02:56.500 --> 00:03:00.656
Think of them as,
the road that cars travel upon, right?

54
00:03:00.656 --> 00:03:03.670
If I want to get from point A to point B,
I've got to get in my car.

55
00:03:03.670 --> 00:03:08.110
I've got to get on the highway, and I've
got to drive down that road, if you will,

56
00:03:08.110 --> 00:03:10.830
to get from point A to point B.

57
00:03:10.830 --> 00:03:13.320
Well when your information,
when you need to retrieve or

58
00:03:13.320 --> 00:03:16.300
work with information,
that's basically what it's doing along

59
00:03:16.300 --> 00:03:19.070
these little copper conductors
that are on the motherboard.

60
00:03:19.070 --> 00:03:21.070
We call them buses, right?

61
00:03:21.070 --> 00:03:26.230
And it's nothing more than a pathway,
a highway that the data moves

62
00:03:26.230 --> 00:03:31.350
along and you can see right here in
the middle, we have the processor, right?

63
00:03:31.350 --> 00:03:33.020
And that's where the processor sits.

64
00:03:33.020 --> 00:03:39.270
We've got area where the memory sits and
then we also got some spots here for what

65
00:03:39.270 --> 00:03:43.300
are known as expansion cards and we'll
look at those coming up a little bit more.

66
00:03:43.300 --> 00:03:46.910
Now, We do wanna keep in mind that one
of the things that we talked about in

67
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:49.360
the first part of this was the chip set,
right?

68
00:03:49.360 --> 00:03:54.300
Well, the chip set and the CPU itself is
something you really have to consider

69
00:03:54.300 --> 00:03:59.230
when you look at a system in general
because it defines what type of system,

70
00:03:59.230 --> 00:04:02.310
the DNA if you will,
that the system written in.

71
00:04:02.310 --> 00:04:04.220
If you have an Intel motherboard,

72
00:04:04.220 --> 00:04:08.990
it's written in the language, the DNA if
you will of Intel, and you have to make

73
00:04:08.990 --> 00:04:14.040
sure you have an Intel CPU that
fits in an Intel board, all right?

74
00:04:14.040 --> 00:04:18.630
Now the other thing that you gotta keep in
mind too is that AMD is out there as well.

75
00:04:18.630 --> 00:04:22.410
So AMD is another major manufacturer,
and you don't mix and match.

76
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:23.750
If you have an AMD board,

77
00:04:23.750 --> 00:04:28.450
you don't put an Intel processor in it,
you put an AMD processor in it.

78
00:04:28.450 --> 00:04:29.830
So it's very important.

79
00:04:29.830 --> 00:04:34.360
I do want you to keep in mind that when
it comes to the platform in general,

80
00:04:34.360 --> 00:04:39.020
the motherboard's form factor matches
the case, which matches the power supply.

81
00:04:39.020 --> 00:04:42.780
It's a little difficult on
this one to see here, but

82
00:04:42.780 --> 00:04:45.350
if we look all the way
back there at the back,

83
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:48.620
there's that power connector that
I was telling you about, right?

84
00:04:48.620 --> 00:04:51.800
Remember the power connector we seen in
Part I of this episode that was on that

85
00:04:51.800 --> 00:04:52.570
power supply.

86
00:04:52.570 --> 00:04:55.440
It matches the power connector for
this motherboard, so

87
00:04:55.440 --> 00:04:58.470
it is important to keep that in mind.

88
00:04:58.470 --> 00:05:02.760
All right, now the next thing
that we have to worry about is

89
00:05:02.760 --> 00:05:06.470
integrated components versus
non-integrated components.

90
00:05:06.470 --> 00:05:11.150
This is important because
it really boils down to

91
00:05:11.150 --> 00:05:15.510
repair versus replace, all right,
see this little box back here?

92
00:05:15.510 --> 00:05:18.480
You don't really have to worry about
too much, but let me just go ahead and

93
00:05:18.480 --> 00:05:19.560
mention what that is.

94
00:05:19.560 --> 00:05:22.720
That's called,
that's part of the chip set, all right.

95
00:05:22.720 --> 00:05:26.600
And that is kind of like a processor,
a controller if you will.

96
00:05:26.600 --> 00:05:29.190
It's like a traffic controller
saying hey data you come,

97
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:31.070
you can go from point A to point B.

98
00:05:31.070 --> 00:05:35.170
Okay you stop hey data go on from C to D,
you can go ahead and move right?

99
00:05:35.170 --> 00:05:37.040
That is integrated in the motherboard.

100
00:05:37.040 --> 00:05:42.230
They soldered that into the motherboard
at the factory, if that breaks,

101
00:05:42.230 --> 00:05:43.930
the motherboard has to be replaced, right?

102
00:05:43.930 --> 00:05:48.180
That's an integrated component,
it can't be replaced, however,

103
00:05:48.180 --> 00:05:53.240
notice these empty slots here all over
this thing, including the CPU, right.

104
00:05:53.240 --> 00:05:55.974
Socket as they call it,
where the CPU's mounted.

105
00:05:55.974 --> 00:06:00.602
These are non-integrated components,
the non-integrated components,

106
00:06:00.602 --> 00:06:03.600
on the other hand,
they can be replaced, right?

107
00:06:03.600 --> 00:06:07.605
If I have a memory module or a little
memory stick that goes bad, I can isolate

108
00:06:07.605 --> 00:06:11.735
it down, I can find out which one's wrong,
I can go up to my favorite vendor and

109
00:06:11.735 --> 00:06:15.770
I can match them up and say okay,
I need to buy another memory stick, right?

110
00:06:15.770 --> 00:06:17.040
I can replace it.

111
00:06:17.040 --> 00:06:19.320
If that fails, then yes, that day or

112
00:06:19.320 --> 00:06:22.080
for however long that you
can't afford to replace it.

113
00:06:22.080 --> 00:06:26.371
Sure you're going to have a bad day, but
you can at least have the ability to

114
00:06:26.371 --> 00:06:30.000
replace it, and you can move on
in your computing experience.

115
00:06:30.000 --> 00:06:33.195
Now, motherboards come in all

00:30:10.543 --> 00:30:16.448
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes talk about some of the most common out device peripherals users will use or see on a regular workday.  They discuss and describe display devices including CRTs, LCDs, LEDs and OLEDs too.  They talk about not only some of the properties but also the devices they are normally are used with or used on.  They also take a the time to describe some of the most common printing devices:  Laser printers, thermal printers and inject printers.  To connect these peripherals to the system unit are several different cabling technologies including serial, parallel, usb and some wireless including Wi-Fi and bluetooth.
episodes.title: Peripherals
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.215 --> 00:00:10.215
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.360 --> 00:00:14.727
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:14.727 --> 00:00:17.830
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,
and you're watching

4
00:00:17.830 --> 00:00:22.696
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals show, where
we're about to take a look at some of

5
00:00:22.696 --> 00:00:27.351
the different peripheral components that
we can attach to our motherboard and

6
00:00:27.351 --> 00:00:30.740
to our computer to make it
work the way they want to.

7
00:00:30.740 --> 00:00:32.740
And here to help us understand
that interaction and

8
00:00:32.740 --> 00:00:35.030
some of those different components,
Mr. Wes Brian.

9
00:00:35.030 --> 00:00:36.130
Wes, welcome back to our studio.

10
00:00:36.130 --> 00:00:36.960
>> Thanks for having me.

11
00:00:36.960 --> 00:00:39.440
That's right, it's great to be
here with the ITProTV crew.

12
00:00:39.440 --> 00:00:42.620
We are looking at, well,
peripherals, like Ronnie said.

13
00:00:42.620 --> 00:00:45.990
And what is the main peripheral
we'll be talking about first?

14
00:00:45.990 --> 00:00:48.160
That's gonna be something
known as our monitors.

15
00:00:48.160 --> 00:00:53.070
And a monitor's a very important
aspect of a computing system.

16
00:00:53.070 --> 00:00:56.970
Otherwise, how could we tell that we're
even working with a computing system?

17
00:00:56.970 --> 00:00:58.450
So, monitors are very important, and

18
00:00:58.450 --> 00:01:02.430
they've definitely gone through some
different technologies over the years.

19
00:01:02.430 --> 00:01:05.310
And we just wanna kinda hopefully
bring you up to speed on some of

20
00:01:05.310 --> 00:01:08.640
those technologies, and
kinda show you what's under the hood here,

21
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:12.630
so that maybe if you are going
to be using these devices,

22
00:01:12.630 --> 00:01:15.400
you can make the choice on
which one is adequate for you.

23
00:01:15.400 --> 00:01:17.390
Because some of them are old and

24
00:01:17.390 --> 00:01:19.750
going by the wayside,
some of them you still see today.

25
00:01:19.750 --> 00:01:23.290
And you might need to know the pros and
cons over each.

26
00:01:23.290 --> 00:01:26.280
>> Now, Wes, as I take a look
at the idea of peripherals here,

27
00:01:26.280 --> 00:01:29.070
it looks like that we're actually
hitting that categorization, or

28
00:01:29.070 --> 00:01:33.470
the classification, of peripherals that we
call different types of output devices.

29
00:01:33.470 --> 00:01:36.320
So, can you just give a little
bit of explanation here.

30
00:01:36.320 --> 00:01:37.889
Output versus input devices,

31
00:01:37.889 --> 00:01:41.275
what do we need here when we
start working with our computers?

32
00:01:41.275 --> 00:01:42.769
>> That's a great question.

33
00:01:42.769 --> 00:01:46.021
So, if we are going to interact
with a machine, right, and

34
00:01:46.021 --> 00:01:49.597
we have to enter commands,
we have to have a way that we can input,

35
00:01:49.597 --> 00:01:52.218
we can send commands into the machine,
right?

36
00:01:52.218 --> 00:01:56.320
And we do that through some of the
peripherals that we'll look at a little

37
00:01:56.320 --> 00:01:57.830
bit later.

38
00:01:57.830 --> 00:01:58.618
The keyboard, right?

39
00:01:58.618 --> 00:01:59.170
And the mouse.

40
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:01.450
That's how we send
instructions into the machine.

41
00:02:01.450 --> 00:02:04.080
But we need to get the results
of those instructions back,

42
00:02:04.080 --> 00:02:05.340
whatever the instruction might be.

43
00:02:05.340 --> 00:02:09.510
It doesn't necessarily have to be like
your telling computer show me something.

44
00:02:09.510 --> 00:02:12.950
We see the results of those
instructions back through

45
00:02:12.950 --> 00:02:14.890
an output device known as a monitor.

46
00:02:14.890 --> 00:02:19.200
So, output devices allow us to
see the results of whatever it is

47
00:02:19.200 --> 00:02:21.680
that we're sending into the machine,
right?

48
00:02:21.680 --> 00:02:26.500
So, for instance, by click, with a mouse,
and I point and click on a video, right?

49
00:02:26.500 --> 00:02:30.300
Well, I'm sending an instruction,
input, into the machine, and

50
00:02:30.300 --> 00:02:32.070
telling it to, well, play that video.

51
00:02:32.070 --> 00:02:35.312
But then I have to see the video,
so what does the computer do?

52
00:02:35.312 --> 00:02:39.256
It responds to my input by
giving me an outbound signal.

53
00:02:39.256 --> 00:02:42.410
In this case, it'll be, the results
will be viewing the machine, or

54
00:02:42.410 --> 00:02:43.980
reviewing that video.

55
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:46.760
Again, input could be
just sending information.

56
00:02:46.760 --> 00:02:49.470
We talk a lot about, I mean,
that's what computer is about, about data.

57
00:02:49.470 --> 00:02:53.710
Maybe you're just sending information into
like a spreadsheet or a document, right?

58
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:57.140
You're typing the information in, you're
sending a command through the keyboard,

59
00:02:57.140 --> 00:02:59.450
through its cable into
the computer itself, and

60
00:02:59.450 --> 00:03:04.530
then you see the output, the results of
that input, inside of the document there.

61
00:03:04.530 --> 00:03:08.750
That primary output interface
being a monitor display.

62
00:03:08.750 --> 00:03:10.780
And there are a few different
technologies that we're gonna look at.

63
00:03:10.780 --> 00:03:11.360
>> All right.

64
00:03:11.360 --> 00:03:14.990
So, Wes, describe for us some of these
different types of displays that we're

65
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:18.560
talking about, and normally what
are the components or devices,

66
00:03:18.560 --> 00:03:20.860
I should say,
that we'll normally see these in.

67
00:03:20.860 --> 00:03:25.950
>> Definitely, one of the first ones that
we talk about is, it's relatively old now.

68
00:03:25.950 --> 00:03:29.790
Some of you out there maybe watching
this have seen these before.

69
00:03:29.790 --> 00:03:35.350
Maybe some of you have seen them, maybe
even worked on them and didn't even know.

70
00:03:35.350 --> 00:03:39.160
And that first one's the old
cathode ray tube, right?

71
00:03:39.160 --> 00:03:42.830
These are the heavy monitors,
if you will, right?

72
00:03:42.830 --> 00:03:43.930
The size of a freight train.

73
00:03:43.930 --> 00:03:48.530
Just kidding, not really the size of
a freight train, but very, very heavy and

74
00:03:48.530 --> 00:03:50.060
very hard to move around.

75
00:03:50.060 --> 00:03:55.210
Now, the CRT, cathode ray tube monitors,
they had some drawbacks.

76
00:03:55.210 --> 00:03:58.410
One of them being how heavy they were,
the other one being the fact

77
00:03:58.410 --> 00:04:02.130
that they didn't help you in
the space aspect, if you will.

78
00:04:02.130 --> 00:04:03.970
But they also were very power hungry.

79
00:04:03.970 --> 00:04:07.590
And you also have to know maybe
a little bit about how they work.

80
00:04:07.590 --> 00:04:09.890
When it comes to a cathode ray tube,
essentially,

81
00:04:09.890 --> 00:04:13.100
what you're doing is you're
using these electron beams.

82
00:04:13.100 --> 00:04:14.680
Just call it a ray gun, if you will.

83
00:04:14.680 --> 00:04:18.320
And it sends three
different primary colors.

84
00:04:18.320 --> 00:04:22.340
The red, the green, the blue,
I believe, down a tube.

85
00:04:22.340 --> 00:04:27.130
And then what you end up seeing
is a magnetic spreader that kinda

86
00:04:27.130 --> 00:04:28.860
paints the image on the machine.

87
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:30.940
In fact, I got a little diagram here.

88
00:04:30.940 --> 00:04:31.640
All right.

89
00:04:31.640 --> 00:04:35.270
And what we're doing is we're just
essentially sending three different colors

90
00:04:35.270 --> 00:04:37.300
down through these anodes.

91
00:04:37.300 --> 00:04:41.900
And this deflection magnet, what it does
is it bends the light to our will, right?

92
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:44.410
Love that, bending the light to our will.

93
00:04:44.410 --> 00:04:45.400
We have the power.

94
00:04:45.400 --> 00:04:47.020
No, really,
it's the monitor that's doing that.

95
00:04:47.020 --> 00:04:49.430
Remember, Ronnie said, input, right?

96
00:04:49.430 --> 00:04:52.480
So if I want to type a piece
of text on the screen,

97
00:04:52.480 --> 00:04:55.850
we're controlling the output, right?

98
00:04:55.850 --> 00:04:58.200
Really, it's the monitor
that's doing this for me, but

99
00:04:58.200 --> 00:05:01.550
what we're telling it through the system
is, hey, I wanna see this picture here.

100
00:05:01.550 --> 00:05:03.520
I wanna see this color here, if you will.

101
00:05:03.520 --> 00:05:05.560
I wanna see this image right here.

102
00:05:05.560 --> 00:05:06.120
All right.
And

103
00:05:06.120 --> 00:05:11.070
the deflection magnets inside of it is
what paints the image across the screen.

104
00:05:11.070 --> 00:05:14.290
Now, in that same line of thought,
I'm gonna go ahead, Ronnie,

105
00:05:14.290 --> 00:05:17.380
and I'm gonna jump ahead
just a little bit.

106
00:05:17.380 --> 00:05:20.150
When we talk about painting
the image across the screen.

107
00:05:21.260 --> 00:05:22.850
It's interesting that
what we're seeing here,

108
00:05:22.850 --> 00:05:26.630
even though it looks like a static image
to us, isn't really a static image.

109
00:05:26.630 --> 00:05:29.040
It's the fact that it is being repainted.

110
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:33.900
And what I mean by that is the image is
going up on the screen and disappearing.

111
00:05:33.900 --> 00:05:36.330
And then going up on the screen and
disappearing.

112
00:05:36.330 --> 00:05:37.596
And so, that's the repainting it.

113
00:05:37.596 --> 00:05:40.110
Again, it dissipates, if you will.

114
00:05:40.110 --> 00:05:42.910
And then it comes back, and
that's something known as a refresh rate.

115
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:43.574
All right.

116
00:05:43.574 --> 00:05:49.234
Now, refresh rate is important, especially
in some of these older CRT monitors cuz

117
00:05:49.234 --> 00:05:54.270
refresh rate is how many times per
second that image is repainted, right?

118
00:05:54.270 --> 00:05:57.700
So, and
what happens is at a certain level rate,

119
00:05:57.700 --> 00:06:01.830
our optical nerves get tricked, and
our eyes, into believing what we see

120
00:06:01.830 --> 00:06:05.060
is a static image when really it's nothing
more than an image that's blinking on and

121
00:06:05.060 --> 00:06:08.670
off so fast that it gives
the illusion of a static image.

122
00:06:08.670 --> 00:06:11.630
And the reason I mention refresh rate
is cuz it might be a setting that you

123
00:06:11.630 --> 00:06:15.680
configure in the operating
system on warning your monitors.

124
00:06:15.680 --> 00:06:19.281
There might a fixed refresh rate,
you might not be able to set anything.

125
00:06:19.281 --> 00:06:21.712
And in that case,
it's usually gonna be set for you,

126
00:06:21.712 --> 00:06:23.431
you don't have to worry about this.

127
00:06:23.431 --> 00:06:27.620
But in the case of the older monitors,
you could maybe set it below like a 60

128
00:06:27.620 --> 00:06:32.370
Hertz level, which just happens to be the
level where it looks like a static image.

129
00:06:32.370 --> 00:06:34.950
And if you misconfigured it, and
you set it a little bit lower,

130
00:06:34.950 --> 00:06:37.140
you start to give yourself headaches.

131
00:06:37.140 --> 00:06:40.770
And the reason being is because now your
eye can pick up on the fact that that's no

132
00:06:40.770 --> 00:06:45.230
longer a static image, it's actually being
repainted, and it can cause problems.

133
00:06:45.230 --> 00:06:47.620
Now, these are older monitors.

134
00:06:47.620 --> 00:06:50.340
I put them in here for
the sake of completion.

135
00:06:50.340 --> 00:06:53.410
We wanna be consistent with something,
never say never.

136
00:06:53.410 --> 00:06:56.090
The fact that you might
see these out there.

137
00:06:56.090 --> 00:06:58.100
Some people might still have them.

138
00:06:58.100 --> 00:07:01.400
One of the other things that was
characteristic about these monitors.

139
00:07:01.400 --> 00:07:04.230
Notice that we talk about
deflection magnets, and

140
00:07:04.230 --> 00:07:08.370
I don't really want you to worry too
much about the inner workings of it.

141
00:07:08.370 --> 00:07:11.630
We want you to see it here, but
notice that's a magnet, right?

142
00:07:11.630 --> 00:07:13.410
That's a magnetic spreader, if you will.

143
00:07:13.410 --> 00:07:17.085
And that means that these type of monitors

144
00:07:17.085 --> 00:07:22.130
are susceptible to magnetic fields,
to interference.

145
00:07:22.130 --> 00:07:25.500
So you do have to worry about that, and
that's one of the things I wanna bring up.

146
00:07:25.500 --> 00:07:29.110
One of the drawbacks to these
monitors is that if you had a,

147
00:07:29.110 --> 00:07:33.310
maybe you had a desk fan that was sitting
next to the monitor that had a very,

148
00:07:33.310 --> 00:07:36.470
very powerful electromagnetic
motor in the background.

149
00:07:36.470 --> 00:07:39.270
You might notice, as you slide that
fan closer and closer to the monitor,

150
00:07:39.270 --> 00:07:41.820
you start getting these distortions in it.

151
00:07:41.820 --> 00:07:45.440
So it does have that tendency
that it could get distorted.

152
00:07:45.440 --> 00:07:49.801
Now, you also have settings on there
that could help you de-magnetize these

153
00:07:49.801 --> 00:07:50.764
monitors.

154
00:07:50.764 --> 00:07:52.540
Now, backing up just a step.

155
00:07:52.540 --> 00:07:54.072
Let's go a little bit more basic.

156
00:07:54.072 --> 00:07:54.631
All right?

157
00:07:54.631 --> 00:07:58.682
If I have a monitor, what is something
that I need to worry about, right?

158
00:07:58.682 --> 00:08:02.876
Well, what I need to worry about is the
type of connector that we have going from

159
00:08:02.876 --> 00:08:06.392
the back of the monitor Into
the back of the computer, all right?

160
00:08:06.392 --> 00:08:08.764
Now we're gonna talk more about some
of these connections coming up.

161
00:08:08.764 --> 00:08:13.180
But I wanna mention today what VCRT
monitors would use what is known as a VGA

162
00:08:13.180 --> 00:08:14.045
connection.

163
00:08:14.045 --> 00:08:17.584
So definitely pay attention to
that little blue connector and

164
00:08:17.584 --> 00:08:19.600
I want you to be aware of that.

165
00:08:19.600 --> 00:08:22.440
So the CRT been around for a long time.

166
00:08:22.440 --> 00:08:25.400
Whether you see them or
not is really dependent on

167
00:08:25.400 --> 00:08:27.780
how old is the technology that
you're gonna be supporting.

168
00:08:27.780 --> 00:08:30.240
I can't rule out the fact that
you might see one of these.

169
00:08:30.240 --> 00:08:35.210
But more commonly what you're gonna
see is the next type of monitor

170
00:08:35.210 --> 00:08:39.420
that we're gonna talk about and
that is something known as an LCD screen.

171
00:08:39.420 --> 00:08:44.960
Now LCD screens, these have some
benefits over the older CRT monitors.

172
00:08:44.960 --> 00:08:49.240
And what I mean by that is with the older
CRT monitors, again they were very,

173
00:08:49.240 --> 00:08:52.300
very power hungry and
they were not space savers.

174
00:08:52.300 --> 00:08:54.937
If you had to carry them around for
any length of time,

175
00:08:54.937 --> 00:08:56.996
you probably wanna be using a back brace.

176
00:08:56.996 --> 00:09:01.320
Well, the LCD monitor, yeah,
I know another acronym, right?

177
00:09:01.320 --> 00:09:03.734
We're never shy of our acronyms.

178
00:09:03.734 --> 00:09:04.490
What does that mean?

179
00:09:04.490 --> 00:09:07.090
Well, instead of a cathode ray, right?

180
00:09:07.090 --> 00:09:08.923
Like that ray gun that
we were talking about.

181
00:09:08.923 --> 00:09:12.320
Now this uses something known
as liquid crystals, all right?

182
00:09:12.320 --> 00:09:18.070
And it gives, these monitors have the
ability to be very, very thin, all right?

183
00:09:18.070 --> 00:09:23.150
And also they can produce
a very good quality image.

184
00:09:23.150 --> 00:09:23.890
Let's go ahead and

185
00:09:23.890 --> 00:09:26.900
look at some of the different things
that you'll see in here, all right?

186
00:09:26.900 --> 00:09:29.820
They have different layers
inside of these monitors.

187
00:09:29.820 --> 00:09:31.920
And essentially it's like a wafer.

188
00:09:31.920 --> 00:09:35.930
That's all it really is with a whole
bunch of layers compacted together.

189
00:09:35.930 --> 00:09:38.190
But the reason I make
mention of all these, not so

190
00:09:38.190 --> 00:09:40.120
that you know all these individual layers.

191
00:09:40.120 --> 00:09:43.450
I really just want you to pay
attention to a couple of the layers

192
00:09:43.450 --> 00:09:45.050
that are important, right?

193
00:09:45.050 --> 00:09:48.560
We have that liquid crystal layer
that we were talking about, right?

194
00:09:48.560 --> 00:09:55.030
That's how we form, if you will,
the image within the monitor itself.

195
00:09:55.030 --> 00:09:59.261
The other thing is something known as
TFT and I mentioned TFT as thin-film

196
00:09:59.261 --> 00:10:02.460
transistor because you might
hear it called a TFT screen.

197
00:10:02.460 --> 00:10:06.900
And what this is is it's known
as a thin-film transistor and

198
00:10:06.900 --> 00:10:09.730
essentially what it does is it allows.

199
00:10:09.730 --> 00:10:15.600
Every single one of the pixels in
the screen to have its own light source,

200
00:10:15.600 --> 00:10:16.570
all right?

201
00:10:16.570 --> 00:10:21.290
The last thing that I would
know when it comes to your LCD

202
00:10:21.290 --> 00:10:24.145
monitors is the backlight source,
all right?

203
00:10:24.145 --> 00:10:27.040
Because we're gonna talk about
a couple of more kinds coming up here.

204
00:10:27.040 --> 00:10:32.330
Notice that it's a CCFL backlight that's
cold cathode fluorescent lamp and

205
00:10:32.330 --> 00:10:34.270
I just want you to know the backlight.

206
00:10:34.270 --> 00:10:37.100
We've got a couple of different types
of lightings that you might have seen.

207
00:10:37.100 --> 00:10:40.165
We have what's known as backlighting and
we have what's sidelighting.

208
00:10:40.165 --> 00:10:45.230
Sidelighting is when you,
if you've ever had like a small oldor mp3

209
00:10:45.230 --> 00:10:49.230
player maybe and you turn it on and
the light literally is on the side

210
00:10:49.230 --> 00:10:52.010
illuminating the screen from
the side that's side lighting right?

211
00:10:52.010 --> 00:10:56.190
Most of our modern day monitors
are backlit if you will.

212
00:10:56.190 --> 00:11:00.130
What really differentiates them from
another technology that we are gonna talk

213
00:11:00.130 --> 00:11:05.610
about is that backlighting source,
so do keep that in mind.

214
00:11:05.610 --> 00:11:07.970
Now that's the liquid crystal display.

215
00:11:07.970 --> 00:11:14.100
We also have what's known as, well,
LED, the light emitting diode, okay?

216
00:11:14.100 --> 00:11:16.490
So what is the difference
between these two?

217
00:11:16.490 --> 00:11:20.820
LCD I got on the left and
LED I have on the right.

218
00:11:20.820 --> 00:11:25.540
Well, we back out here,
just look at the color coordination here.

219
00:11:25.540 --> 00:11:27.970
There isn't a difference, all right?

220
00:11:27.970 --> 00:11:30.550
But the exception of one thing.

221
00:11:30.550 --> 00:11:33.030
You'll notice it still uses
a liquid crystal layer.

222
00:11:33.030 --> 00:11:37.210
It still has that little
thin-film transistor in there.

00:24:51.010 --> 00:24:54.861
And that is exactly what it is,
just think of the term thermal.

448
00:24:54.861 --> 00:24:59.796
Thermal printer means that the way that
we create the output is by applying

449
00:24:59.796 --> 00:25:03.720
heat to the media, all right,
whatever it might be.

450
00:25:03.720 --> 00:25:08.050
You might say to yourself, well I have
never seen one of these thermal printers.

451
00:25:08.050 --> 00:25:11.234
I bet you see one every day and
you just never realize it.

452
00:25:11.234 --> 00:25:15.869
If you've ever paid gas at the pump,
if you've ever bought something and

453
00:25:15.869 --> 00:25:17.990
had a receipt given to you.

454
00:25:17.990 --> 00:25:20.920
Those are thermal printers and
what are they doing?

455
00:25:20.920 --> 00:25:25.504
All right, well there is one, a common one
that is called a direct thermal printer

456
00:25:25.504 --> 00:25:28.568
and this is one that uses
a series of heating elements.

457
00:25:28.568 --> 00:25:31.890
Heating pins if you will, and
what they do is they press,

458
00:25:31.890 --> 00:25:35.226
we will have our heating
element right here, all right.

459
00:25:35.226 --> 00:25:40.569
And our heating element, what it's going
to do is it's going to make contact,

460
00:25:40.569 --> 00:25:43.540
it's going to heat up this thermal ribbon.

461
00:25:43.540 --> 00:25:46.757
This is where our ink, I don't want
to call it ink, if you will, but

462
00:25:46.757 --> 00:25:47.850
our thermal ribbon.

463
00:25:47.850 --> 00:25:50.990
And it's going to press and
heat that up, and

464
00:25:50.990 --> 00:25:53.770
press it into the paper, and
that's how we get the output.

465
00:25:53.770 --> 00:25:58.220
Now, historically these have really
only been black as far as the color,

466
00:25:58.220 --> 00:26:01.120
but they've done something that's
kind of interesting today.

467
00:26:01.120 --> 00:26:03.810
They can get a black, a red, and a blue.

468
00:26:03.810 --> 00:26:07.450
And what I think's kind of fascinating
on these is just the fact that it uses

469
00:26:07.450 --> 00:26:08.530
different temperatures.

470
00:26:08.530 --> 00:26:12.070
It creates the color by applying
different temperatures.

471
00:26:12.070 --> 00:26:18.120
The other thing that you might notice is
that when you have to use a special paper.

472
00:26:18.120 --> 00:26:23.230
So, our thermal paper, there's a reason
I call it thermal paper because

473
00:26:23.230 --> 00:26:28.300
it's not a paper that's gonna go into
other types of printers, all right?

474
00:26:28.300 --> 00:26:32.021
If you've ever seen where the receipt
that maybe you've got and held for

475
00:26:32.021 --> 00:26:33.859
a couple of years and it fades away.

476
00:26:33.859 --> 00:26:38.575
Well, that's because it's returning
to it's original state and

477
00:26:38.575 --> 00:26:41.150
it will lose the color after a while.

478
00:26:41.150 --> 00:26:45.000
And all you'd have to do really is you can
probably press some heat on it again and

479
00:26:45.000 --> 00:26:46.250
you'd see it'd change color.

480
00:26:46.250 --> 00:26:48.480
So that's the thermal printer,
again keep in mind,

481
00:26:48.480 --> 00:26:54.280
it's a heating element that applies heat
to the media to create the printed output.

482
00:26:54.280 --> 00:27:00.430
Now the next one that we have here is,
has been around for a while and

483
00:27:00.430 --> 00:27:04.420
this has got several components in it that
I want to just take a second here, and

484
00:27:04.420 --> 00:27:05.090
I want to talk about.

485
00:27:05.090 --> 00:27:06.340
This is called the laser printer.

486
00:27:06.340 --> 00:27:08.810
It's probably one of the best
printers that are out there

487
00:27:08.810 --> 00:27:10.850
as far as the quality of the image goes.

488
00:27:10.850 --> 00:27:13.110
There's another one, but
we wont really go into that.

489
00:27:13.110 --> 00:27:14.904
There's one called a dye
sublimation printer, but

490
00:27:14.904 --> 00:27:18.420
this is one of the ones that's the most
common in the average office space, and

491
00:27:18.420 --> 00:27:19.930
that's why we want to mention it here.

492
00:27:19.930 --> 00:27:21.840
So, what we end up having here,

493
00:27:21.840 --> 00:27:26.480
is we have what's known as the laser unit,
this is where it gets its name from.

494
00:27:26.480 --> 00:27:30.290
The laser unit is exactly that,
it sends a beam, and

495
00:27:30.290 --> 00:27:34.950
that beam is shot over here, to what's
known as a scanning mirror, all right?

496
00:27:34.950 --> 00:27:38.354
And the scanning mirror
reflects based on your input,

497
00:27:38.354 --> 00:27:43.101
remember we're talking about input,
back down to this centralized drum.

498
00:27:43.101 --> 00:27:47.325
All right, the centralized drum we can
abbreviate and just call it an EP drum,

499
00:27:47.325 --> 00:27:49.570
it's an electrostatic photoreceptor.

500
00:27:49.570 --> 00:27:52.350
And what it does is it responds
to electrical current, and

501
00:27:52.350 --> 00:27:53.790
it also responds to light.

502
00:27:54.940 --> 00:27:56.840
We have a couple more
components in here too.

503
00:27:56.840 --> 00:27:58.960
You have what's known as a discharge lamp.

504
00:27:58.960 --> 00:28:02.680
I want you to keep in mind that
this drum is constantly spinning.

505
00:28:02.680 --> 00:28:07.970
Every process that you see here is
happening each time a piece of paper

506
00:28:07.970 --> 00:28:10.850
runs through this printer
from your paper source.

507
00:28:10.850 --> 00:28:14.255
You have a couple of other components too,
you have what's known as a discharge lamp.

508
00:28:14.255 --> 00:28:19.216
Because we're electrifying, we're
putting a static charge to this drum,

509
00:28:19.216 --> 00:28:23.900
this discharge lamp removes that,
and it neutralizes the drum.

510
00:28:23.900 --> 00:28:26.640
We've got a couple of corona wires,
and here's a technician.

511
00:28:26.640 --> 00:28:28.740
If you are going to get into this and
maybe support this,

512
00:28:28.740 --> 00:28:32.110
this might be something that you have
to figure out if it's working right.

513
00:28:32.110 --> 00:28:34.060
And the corona wires,
they do a couple of things.

514
00:28:34.060 --> 00:28:37.530
They charge the drum, and
they charge the paper, all right?

515
00:28:37.530 --> 00:28:39.670
So there are a couple of a different
things that are happening here.

516
00:28:39.670 --> 00:28:43.200
We've got your toner hopper,
that's where your toner is and

517
00:28:43.200 --> 00:28:44.918
you have a developing roller as well.

518
00:28:44.918 --> 00:28:49.895
All right, so all of these components,
basically send the paper through,

519
00:28:49.895 --> 00:28:52.942
they charge the paper,
they charge the drum.

520
00:28:52.942 --> 00:28:56.857
And what happens is the toner is attracted
down to the paper as it rolls through

521
00:28:56.857 --> 00:28:57.473
this drum.

522
00:28:57.473 --> 00:29:02.603
And then the last process that we
see is a fusing assembly, all right.

523
00:29:02.603 --> 00:29:06.059
The fusing assembly,
what it does is it takes that toner,

524
00:29:06.059 --> 00:29:09.797
which is nothing more than a mixture
of plastics and resin, and

525
00:29:09.797 --> 00:29:14.120
it heats it up enough to cook a turkey
[LAUGH] and it fuses, hence the name.

526
00:29:14.120 --> 00:29:16.760
It adheres that toner to the paper.

527
00:29:16.760 --> 00:29:20.610
If you've ever picked up a piece of paper,
a printed output that comes out of a laser

528
00:29:20.610 --> 00:29:22.820
printer really quick,
you've probably noticed that it's warm.

529
00:29:22.820 --> 00:29:25.330
Well that's because it just
passed the fusing process.

530
00:29:25.330 --> 00:29:27.990
Here's a couple of things I
want you to keep in mind if

531
00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:30.715
you start to have to
troubleshoot these out there.

532
00:29:30.715 --> 00:29:35.415
If you get, your image can smear off,
you might have the fact that this

533
00:29:35.415 --> 00:29:38.175
fusing assembly has warped
because of the heat in it.

534
00:29:38.175 --> 00:29:39.605
And what happens is as it rolls,

535
00:29:39.605 --> 00:29:42.385
it doesn't make complete
contact fusing all the toner.

536
00:29:42.385 --> 00:29:47.105
The other thing that might happen here
to your laser printer is that drum

537
00:29:47.105 --> 00:29:52.320
itself might get damaged and
in this place, it will have to replaced.

538
00:29:52.320 --> 00:29:54.790
So, just want to keep that in mind there.

539
00:29:54.790 --> 00:29:57.700
That's another one of the common printers.

540
00:29:57.700 --> 00:29:59.990
Now, in a home environment
the last one that we have,

541
00:29:59.990 --> 00:30:04.555
the most major one I would say,
probably is the inkjet printer.

542
00:30:04.555 --> 00:30:08.330
All right, and the inkjet printer
is a fascinating printer in and

543
00:30:08.330 --> 00:30:11.100
of itself and you've got a couple
of things that go on here.

544
00:30:11.100 --> 00:30:13.650
In fact, let me grab this,
pull that down there and

545
00:30:13.650 --> 00:30:15.540
we'll look at these individually.

546
00:30:15.540 --> 00:30:18.700
All right, we have what's known
as a drive belt stepper motor.

547
00:30:18.700 --> 00:30:20.510
All right, what is that responsible for?

548
00:30:20.510 --> 00:30:24.290
Well, that actually helps in
combination with the drive belt.

549
00:30:24.290 --> 00:30:26.670
It pulls the ink cartridge head back and

550
00:30:26.670 --> 00:30:31.560
forth across the media
that you're printing to.

551
00:30:31.560 --> 00:30:35.741
Now, the main thing centers around this
ink cartridge and a print Head Assembly,

552
00:30:35.741 --> 00:30:36.356
all right.

553
00:30:36.356 --> 00:30:39.828
The print head assembly, it's responsible
for the printed output that you see.

554
00:30:39.828 --> 00:30:43.260
And what we use is well, a couple of
different things, we either use heat or

555
00:30:43.260 --> 00:30:48.550
we use electrical current, and
it forces that ink out of those nozzles,

556
00:30:48.550 --> 00:30:52.700
and it sprays them right on to the paper.

557
00:30:52.700 --> 00:30:56.090
What's interesting is the first
two printers that we looked at,

558
00:30:56.090 --> 00:30:58.640
they actually make contact with the media.

559
00:30:58.640 --> 00:31:00.890
This one, doesn't make contact
with the media at all.

560
00:31:00.890 --> 00:31:04.420
It actually sprays the liquid or
the ink out of the cartridge, and

561
00:31:04.420 --> 00:31:06.660
you typically have different cartridges.

562
00:31:06.660 --> 00:31:10.220
You'll have your four different cartridges
there and I've got the colors up here too.

563
00:31:10.220 --> 00:31:12.800
The next thing you have
is the guiding rod.

564
00:31:12.800 --> 00:31:18.160
The guiding rod is what the print
cartridge moves along as it goes back and

565
00:31:18.160 --> 00:31:23.590
forth with the drive belt
stepper motor there, all right.

566
00:31:23.590 --> 00:31:26.000
Next thing you have and
these could be a couple of different ways,

567
00:31:26.000 --> 00:31:27.680
a lot of times they are friction feed.

568
00:31:27.680 --> 00:31:30.469
You have how the paper advances,
all right, and

569
00:31:30.469 --> 00:31:33.159
the paper advances out of the machine
through these rollers that grab it.

570
00:31:33.159 --> 00:31:36.420
You could have a friction feed, which is
two rollers that are pressing down on

571
00:31:36.420 --> 00:31:40.920
that paper, and they are turning it and
pulling it out of the machine.

572
00:31:40.920 --> 00:31:44.954
One of the things that I would keep in
mind on this one is that if you don't

573
00:31:44.954 --> 00:31:49.392
print often enough on these printers,
the ink nozzles could get clogged up and

574
00:31:49.392 --> 00:31:53.112
if that's the case,
the printer isn't gonna print correctly.

575
00:31:53.112 --> 00:31:56.241
So just keep in mind those
are the three major types of printers

576
00:31:56.241 --> 00:31:57.272
that you might see.

577
00:31:57.272 --> 00:32:02.000
Again, the thermal printer, the laser
printer as well as the ink printer.

578
00:32:02.000 --> 00:32:03.122
I do wanna take a second and

579
00:32:03.122 --> 00:32:05.730
talk about some of the connections
here that you could have.

580
00:32:05.730 --> 00:32:07.610
How do we actually
connect to these devices?

581
00:32:07.610 --> 00:32:11.200
Well, there's a couple of old ones that
I don't really know that you'll see,

582
00:32:11.200 --> 00:32:15.030
but I do still,
I mention them here just so you're aware.

583
00:32:15.030 --> 00:32:17.430
There's the old serial based printers,
right?

584
00:32:17.430 --> 00:32:21.330
The serial connection, there's something
known as the parallel connection,

585
00:32:21.330 --> 00:32:23.179
again, those are more legacy today.

586
00:32:23.179 --> 00:32:26.071
I highly doubt that you're gonna,
really you never say never, but

587
00:32:26.071 --> 00:32:28.364
I highly doubt you'll come
into contact with those.

588
00:32:28.364 --> 00:32:31.665
But, more common today we
have USB-based printers,

589
00:32:31.665 --> 00:32:36.548
we have printers that also connect through
things like wireless and Bluetooth,

590
00:32:36.548 --> 00:32:41.010
as well as potentially Thunderbolt
connections, likewise, too.

591
00:32:41.010 --> 00:32:44.430
You're seeing this commonly,
where probably one of the most common for

592
00:32:44.430 --> 00:32:47.770
a long time have been the USB connections,
right?

593
00:32:47.770 --> 00:32:52.326
More common or even more common today is
now wireless printing, where in fact,

594
00:32:52.326 --> 00:32:55.590
I don't have to have a direct
connection to the printer,

595
00:32:55.590 --> 00:32:58.174
we can print to it over
the wireless network.

596
00:32:58.174 --> 00:33:01.225
Now I didn't put this in the notes,
there's another technology out there

597
00:33:01.225 --> 00:33:03.752
called NFC printing,
which is near-field communication.

598
00:33:03.752 --> 00:33:07.212
And, essentially, if you've got it set up,
it means I could take a mobile phone,

599
00:33:07.212 --> 00:33:10.490
touch it right to the printer, and it
sends the print job right to the printer.

600
00:33:10.490 --> 00:33:14.630
A little eccentric, love it, but
more commonly USB and wireless.

601
00:33:16.120 --> 00:33:19.290
The last thing I want to mention
in this are the consumables.

602
00:33:19.290 --> 00:33:21.350
What is it that we have to pay for?

603
00:33:21.350 --> 00:33:22.690
Ink cartridges, all right?

604
00:33:22.690 --> 00:33:24.510
You're gonna have to replace
your ink cartridges.

605
00:33:24.510 --> 00:33:27.150
I know they're expensive,
I know that's usually the burden.

606
00:33:27.150 --> 00:33:28.710
That's usually the point you
throw away the printer and

607
00:33:28.710 --> 00:33:32.730
buy a new one cuz the cartridges
are more expensive, but just kidding.

608
00:33:32.730 --> 00:33:33.670
Don't really do that,

609
00:33:33.670 --> 00:33:36.610
but that's one of the things that you
have to replace in the inkjet printers.

610
00:33:36.610 --> 00:33:38.840
In the laser printer,
it's the toner cartridge,

611
00:33:38.840 --> 00:33:40.730
typically that has to be replaced.

612
00:33:40.730 --> 00:33:43.690
In a thermal printer,
a lot of times it's just a ribbon and

613
00:33:43.690 --> 00:33:45.760
the paper, but there might be a case and

614
00:33:45.760 --> 00:33:49.460
scenario where you have to clean the
thermal, the heating elements in there.

615
00:33:49.460 --> 00:33:53.890
At worst case scenario, they might be
replaceable, but they can get clogged up

616
00:33:53.890 --> 00:33:58.080
with little debris, so potentially those,
and then last is just your paper, right?

617
00:33:58.080 --> 00:34:01.670
Labels, cardstock, envelopes, again,

618
00:34:01.670 --> 00:34:05.570
normal printing paper, that's all gonna
be stuff that we're gonna have to buy.

619
00:34:05.570 --> 00:34:07.240
It's gonna be stuff that
we're gonna have to replace.

620
00:34:07.240 --> 00:34:10.920
I do want to make mention though, keep
in mind that thermal paper is a special

621
00:34:10.920 --> 00:34:15.350
paper, and you can't just put an average
paper inside of a thermal printer, or,

622
00:34:15.350 --> 00:34:16.950
well, you're gonna cause a fire.

623
00:34:16.950 --> 00:34:18.400
That's not a good day at the office cuz,

624
00:34:18.400 --> 00:34:21.870
keep in mind, everything else
in the office can go wrong, but

625
00:34:21.870 --> 00:34:24.368
if you have a printer up and running,
at least you could print your resume.

626
00:34:24.368 --> 00:34:28.074
>> All right, Wes, well, thank you for
introducing us to some of this different

627
00:34:28.074 --> 00:34:31.670
types of output peripherals that we're
more than likely to encounter, and

628
00:34:31.670 --> 00:34:35.350
also taking a look at the technologies
that help us to connect them together.

629
00:34:35.350 --> 00:34:37.110
Whether we are using, of course,

630
00:34:37.110 --> 00:34:41.070
a cable or whether we are using something
like a wireless connection to do so.

631
00:34:41.070 --> 00:34:44.080
Well, that's great place for
us to also in this episode then.

632
00:34:44.080 --> 00:34:47.503
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

633
00:34:47.503 --> 00:34:48.579
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

634
00:34:48.579 --> 00:34:53.058
>> And you wanna stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

635
00:34:54.412 --> 00:35:00.895
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes take look at some of the different input devices that daily computer users in a work environment are likely to see and use.  They describe the concept and show the keyboard as the main input device.  Just as prolific as the keyboard is the computer mouse that they describe has giving us the ability to do point and click.  They display and discuss many of the other input devices that are out there and talk about when users are most likely to encounter them.
episodes.title: Peripherals Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.059 --> 00:00:15.590
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.590 --> 00:00:17.090
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong,

4
00:00:17.090 --> 00:00:20.900
and you're watching
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals Show,

5
00:00:20.900 --> 00:00:25.370
where we are about to take a look at
a part two in terms of peripherals.

6
00:00:25.370 --> 00:00:29.110
And we've already been talking about some
of the different output devices that we

7
00:00:29.110 --> 00:00:32.730
have been able to understand that
we're gonna use with our computers.

8
00:00:32.730 --> 00:00:36.480
And this time, we're actually turning
our focus, well, toward the input.

9
00:00:36.480 --> 00:00:39.330
And who better to help us to
understand how to get more information

10
00:00:39.330 --> 00:00:40.360
into the computer?

11
00:00:40.360 --> 00:00:41.460
Well, Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:41.460 --> 00:00:42.540
So, Wes, welcome back.

13
00:00:42.540 --> 00:00:45.200
>> Thank you, and hopefully that
information that comes out is actually

14
00:00:45.200 --> 00:00:47.629
something that's intelligible, for sure.

15
00:00:47.629 --> 00:00:48.260
[LAUGH]
>> Hopefully.

16
00:00:48.260 --> 00:00:48.880
>> That's right.

17
00:00:48.880 --> 00:00:52.438
So, we're gonna be looking at some of
the devices that we use to interact with

18
00:00:52.438 --> 00:00:53.807
computer versus some of the,

19
00:00:53.807 --> 00:00:57.340
in the first episode we talked about
things like our printers, if you will.

20
00:00:57.340 --> 00:00:58.840
We talked about display devices.

21
00:00:58.840 --> 00:01:00.520
Remember that the printers
we talked about,

22
00:01:00.520 --> 00:01:02.440
we talked about some of the major ones.

23
00:01:02.440 --> 00:01:06.700
The thermal printer, common to see
those inside of things like your

24
00:01:06.700 --> 00:01:09.720
point of sale systems and
your gas stations, right?

25
00:01:09.720 --> 00:01:12.490
Grocery stores will
print you out receipts.

26
00:01:12.490 --> 00:01:14.130
The laser printer,
we talked about as well.

27
00:01:14.130 --> 00:01:16.570
Keep in mind, it's a very fast and
efficient printer.

28
00:01:16.570 --> 00:01:20.490
It also has a good little expense
that comes along with it.

29
00:01:20.490 --> 00:01:23.670
So, it's perfect for
something like the enterprise environment.

30
00:01:23.670 --> 00:01:25.790
Now, please don't get me wrong.

31
00:01:25.790 --> 00:01:28.400
You can certainly get a laser printer for
your house, and

Gaming, a lot of times they like wired
connections because they have a lot less

476
00:25:16.530 --> 00:25:20.325
delay, so they give a better performance.

477
00:25:20.325 --> 00:25:24.240
Yeah, I think that has just about got it.

478
00:25:24.240 --> 00:25:27.780
There are a couple other things
that I want you to keep in mind,

479
00:25:27.780 --> 00:25:29.900
and just as a recap,
remember the connections.

480
00:25:29.900 --> 00:25:33.120
Primary connections with
this is gonna be wireless,

481
00:25:33.120 --> 00:25:38.170
USB, PS2, and
just know where those connections are.

482
00:25:38.170 --> 00:25:42.310
You usually find them on the front of
a computer, the system unit that we were

483
00:25:42.310 --> 00:25:45.040
talking about, the tower, or
you could find them on the back.

484
00:25:45.040 --> 00:25:48.932
A lot of times you could find both of
them,depending on your motherboard itself.

485
00:25:48.932 --> 00:25:51.953
But that is a big thing to keep in
mind that when you're gonna use

486
00:25:51.953 --> 00:25:56.171
these input devices, if you're supporting
the end user, it's about their choice and

487
00:25:56.171 --> 00:25:59.249
their preference,
not about your choice and your preference,

488
00:25:59.249 --> 00:26:01.600
cuz remember it's not
you using that computer.

489
00:26:01.600 --> 00:26:04.151
For instance,
I can't stand the trackball but

490
00:26:04.151 --> 00:26:07.738
we've got some people around here
that love the trackball right.

491
00:26:07.738 --> 00:26:09.815
And there's nothing wrong with
that because that's why we

492
00:26:09.815 --> 00:26:11.310
call it personal computing.

493
00:26:11.310 --> 00:26:15.050
So keep in mind the connections, keep
in mind the batteries if it's wireless,

494
00:26:15.050 --> 00:26:17.130
keep in mind specialty
drivers if you need them.

495
00:26:17.130 --> 00:26:19.670
Remember the driver if you,
first time you've heard that and

496
00:26:19.670 --> 00:26:22.660
you haven't watched some of the other
episodes, that component that allows our

497
00:26:22.660 --> 00:26:26.130
operating system to talk to that device,
it is important.

498
00:26:26.130 --> 00:26:29.590
So those are some of the things that
you should probably be aware of

499
00:26:29.590 --> 00:26:32.210
when you have to maybe either support or
troubleshoot these.

500
00:26:32.210 --> 00:26:35.160
>> When we start taking a look at
different types of peripherals

501
00:26:35.160 --> 00:26:39.540
that we have been talking about, remember
to keep it in the context that you need.

502
00:26:39.540 --> 00:26:41.340
A lot of times in the work environment,

503
00:26:41.340 --> 00:26:43.370
more than likely it's
gonna be that keyboard and

504
00:26:43.370 --> 00:26:46.950
that mouse that you need to be familiar
with and feel comfortable with in using.

505
00:26:46.950 --> 00:26:51.490
So make sure you do pay attention there
and learn how to actually use those.

506
00:26:51.490 --> 00:26:54.470
Typing is a great skill that I
do recommend that you have if

507
00:26:54.470 --> 00:26:55.530
you're doing this.

508
00:26:55.530 --> 00:26:58.740
But you might be wondering when am I gonna
actually ever encounter some of these

509
00:26:58.740 --> 00:27:00.460
other types of devices?

510
00:27:00.460 --> 00:27:02.010
Well, it depends on the situation.

511
00:27:02.010 --> 00:27:05.290
If you are in a laptop situation
where somebody has said,

512
00:27:05.290 --> 00:27:08.460
here is what you're gonna work from which
is a notebook or a laptop, it might be

513
00:27:08.460 --> 00:27:13.310
a touchscreen, it might be that idea of
that touchpad or even that TrackPoint.

514
00:27:13.310 --> 00:27:16.486
Or they may even give you just a very
small area in which they give you

515
00:27:16.486 --> 00:27:19.294
a trackball,
you should become familiar with those too.

516
00:27:19.294 --> 00:27:22.577
But there are highly specialized
types of application that

517
00:27:22.577 --> 00:27:24.939
you might end up using
that do require you,

518
00:27:24.939 --> 00:27:29.419
also, to be able to use the webcam, as
well as the speakers and the microphones.

519
00:27:29.419 --> 00:27:32.955
The great thing about those is most of
the time, you don't have to set them up,

520
00:27:32.955 --> 00:27:34.530
especially on a laptop.

521
00:27:34.530 --> 00:27:38.580
They're pre-built into
the actual device itself and

522
00:27:38.580 --> 00:27:41.860
normally, if you need to use
those to get them set up,

523
00:27:41.860 --> 00:27:45.610
whatever program you're using
will have a configuration wizard.

524
00:27:45.610 --> 00:27:49.060
In other words, it will guide you
through step-by-step to ensure

525
00:27:49.060 --> 00:27:52.700
that you have set it up correctly
to use that program as well.

526
00:27:52.700 --> 00:27:56.699
So if you feel like that this is a bit
overwhelming because there's a ton of

527
00:27:56.699 --> 00:28:00.829
different things, the great thing is
computing has come to this point where

528
00:28:00.829 --> 00:28:04.401
they realize that and that they
can actually help you out as well.

529
00:28:04.401 --> 00:28:07.221
>> One of the last things that I do wanna
mention is I do wanna take just a couple

530
00:28:07.221 --> 00:28:09.605
minutes here and show you some
of the different connections.

531
00:28:09.605 --> 00:28:12.664
Since we're talking about peripherals and
we're talking about displays,

532
00:28:12.664 --> 00:28:13.369
let me go ahead and

533
00:28:13.369 --> 00:28:15.970
show you some of this connections
on our machine here real quick.

534
00:28:15.970 --> 00:28:18.255
Now, I know my head's kinda
covering up one of them there but

535
00:28:18.255 --> 00:28:21.040
these are the primary interfaces
that we see today, the cords,

536
00:28:21.040 --> 00:28:24.530
the cables that you plug from the back
of your computer into the monitors.

537
00:28:24.530 --> 00:28:28.590
You could see an older one here,
VGA, and its connector there.

538
00:28:28.590 --> 00:28:32.230
This is an analog signal,
basically a lower quality signal and

539
00:28:32.230 --> 00:28:36.310
then as time went on,
we got the what's known as DVI cable So

540
00:28:36.310 --> 00:28:38.840
pay attention to those,
again, this is important.

541
00:28:38.840 --> 00:28:41.560
We also have the HDMI connector there.

542
00:28:41.560 --> 00:28:44.860
The HDMI connector is for
high definition, in fact, it stands for

543
00:28:44.860 --> 00:28:46.690
high definition multimedia interface.

544
00:28:46.690 --> 00:28:50.800
So it's a very high quality, high
resolution that's capable of producing

545
00:28:50.800 --> 00:28:55.960
sound and video, or sending sound and
video over the same cable.

546
00:28:55.960 --> 00:28:58.140
So that's one of the great
things about it.

547
00:28:58.140 --> 00:29:01.100
Couple of the other ones that we
have that I wanna go ahead and

548
00:29:01.100 --> 00:29:03.760
just mention here since we're
talking about peripherals.

549
00:29:03.760 --> 00:29:07.400
We have display port,
you could see that one as well.

550
00:29:07.400 --> 00:29:11.100
And it looks a lot like that SATA
connector that we'll talk about when

551
00:29:11.100 --> 00:29:14.030
it comes up, when we talk
about storage and hard drives.

552
00:29:14.030 --> 00:29:16.670
And then Thunderbolt,
Thunderbolt's out there as well

553
00:29:16.670 --> 00:29:19.175
and one of the things that I think
is interesting is be careful with

554
00:29:19.175 --> 00:29:23.750
these because that is also a mini-display
port that I have right here.

555
00:29:23.750 --> 00:29:26.580
And if you'll notice up here this
is the Thunderbolt connector and

556
00:29:26.580 --> 00:29:27.889
they look a lot alike.

557
00:29:29.020 --> 00:29:32.800
They do work with each other but
technically they are different,

558
00:29:32.800 --> 00:29:34.790
so keep that in mind.

559
00:29:34.790 --> 00:29:36.410
So we do have a couple of those.

560
00:29:37.680 --> 00:29:42.410
All right, and here are the various
connectors that I had mentioned earlier.

561
00:29:42.410 --> 00:29:45.430
These are some of the connectors
you can see in peripheral devices,

562
00:29:45.430 --> 00:29:49.510
your FireWire connector here, that big box
there, that's an older one, that was for

563
00:29:49.510 --> 00:29:51.730
the older FireWire 800 standard.

564
00:29:51.730 --> 00:29:54.530
And then these are more of your common
FireWire standards that you'll see in

565
00:29:54.530 --> 00:29:55.330
the back of the machine.

566
00:29:55.330 --> 00:29:57.650
See a little bullet shaped
connector there and

567
00:29:57.650 --> 00:30:00.250
you'll also see a little
square box connector.

568
00:30:00.250 --> 00:30:04.860
And then a slew and I can't tell you how
many of them, in fact, six of them to

569
00:30:04.860 --> 00:30:10.020
be exact, there are when it comes to USB
and there's different standards here.

570
00:30:10.020 --> 00:30:13.960
All the way on the left you
have the micro standards.

571
00:30:13.960 --> 00:30:18.575
I'm not sure exactly what this one right
here is but then you have the mini so

572
00:30:18.575 --> 00:30:19.976
we got micro and mini.

573
00:30:19.976 --> 00:30:24.795
You see the micros, our charging
cables for phones commonly as well,

574
00:30:24.795 --> 00:30:27.664
but they also plug in different devices.

575
00:30:27.664 --> 00:30:31.067
And then you have A devices and
we have a female and a male version here,

576
00:30:31.067 --> 00:30:34.600
the male version with the post,
the female with the port there.

577
00:30:34.600 --> 00:30:37.840
And then last but not least, you have
a what's known as a type B connector which

578
00:30:37.840 --> 00:30:41.160
is commonly associated
with USB-based printers.

579
00:30:41.160 --> 00:30:42.689
So we definitely want to know that.

580
00:30:42.689 --> 00:30:45.478
But those are a couple of the peripheral
connections that I did wanna show in

581
00:30:45.478 --> 00:30:46.150
there, Ronnie.

582
00:30:46.150 --> 00:30:49.162
I thought we might save them for another
episode but this is a great place since

583
00:30:49.162 --> 00:30:52.330
we're talking about displays and
we're talking about external connections.

584
00:30:52.330 --> 00:30:55.057
It is good to know what connections
you need when you're gonna support

585
00:30:55.057 --> 00:30:56.180
those devices.

586
00:30:56.180 --> 00:30:59.240
>> All right, well that's a great place
for us to also end this episode then.

587
00:30:59.240 --> 00:31:04.030
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wang.

588
00:31:04.030 --> 00:31:05.120
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

589
00:31:05.120 --> 00:31:10.211
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

590
00:31:10.211 --> 00:31:16.306
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce some of the different storage devices.  They describe the difference between mechanical and solid state drives and discuss briefly the capacity of storage drives.  They also talk about optical drives and their application.  They end the episode, by taking a look at multiple different types of connectors you’re likely to see.
episodes.title: Storage
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.314 --> 00:00:16.550
All right, welcome back to another
great episode right here on IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:16.550 --> 00:00:18.055
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:18.055 --> 00:00:21.522
you're watching the IC 3
computing fundamentals show.

5
00:00:21.522 --> 00:00:25.074
Where we're about to take a look
into the realm of storage.

6
00:00:25.074 --> 00:00:28.080
Now, Wes actually hasn't described
anything else to me except for

7
00:00:28.080 --> 00:00:29.570
the title of the episode.

8
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:32.600
So Wes, what are we taking a look at
today and welcome back to our studios.

9
00:00:32.600 --> 00:00:33.630
>> Well, thanks for having me here.

10
00:00:33.630 --> 00:00:34.165
That's right.

11
00:00:34.165 --> 00:00:37.887
We're gonna talk about,
we've been talking about data, right?

12
00:00:37.887 --> 00:00:42.715
Data, and that's the purpose of our
entire computing experience, right?

13
00:00:42.715 --> 00:00:43.825
Information systems.

14
00:00:43.825 --> 00:00:46.055
Being able to move data
from point A to point B,

15
00:00:46.055 --> 00:00:48.980
when we talk about it at
the hardware level, right?

16
00:00:48.980 --> 00:00:51.550
Well, where does that data end up?

17
00:00:51.550 --> 00:00:55.230
We've talked in an earlier episode
that if it was in memory volatile,

18
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:57.720
volatile memory it needs
an electrical current.

19
00:00:57.720 --> 00:01:02.400
And if we pull the plug,
that unfortunately that data's gone.

20
00:01:02.400 --> 00:01:05.420
So we need a place in where
we can store our data.

21
00:01:05.420 --> 00:01:10.040
And the type of storage mediums that
we've been using over the last 20,

22
00:01:10.040 --> 00:01:12.020
30 years has definitely changed.

23
00:01:12.020 --> 00:01:14.960
So we're gonna be looking at some
of the storage devices that you can

24
00:01:14.960 --> 00:01:18.330
see inside of your systems, and
maybe even outside of your systems,

25
00:01:18.330 --> 00:01:20.855
when it comes to what's most important.

26
00:01:20.855 --> 00:01:24.090
The data that you need to
make sure that you preserve.

27
00:01:24.090 --> 00:01:26.380
So, let's go ahead and
talk a little bit about that.

28
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:28.400
We've got a few different
types of storage.

29
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:33.500
One of the big ones that is very,
very common inside of systems today,

30
00:01:33.500 --> 00:01:35.550
is what's known as a hard disk drive.

31
00:01:35.550 --> 00:01:37.910
Now, hard disk drive,
what does that mean for us?

32
00:01:37.910 --> 00:01:42.060
Well, that is a place that
allows us to store our data and

33
00:01:42.060 --> 00:01:47.340
retain that data for use at a later time,
even if the computer has been powered off.

34
00:01:47.340 --> 00:01:49.550
And we have a few different
types that we wanna look at.

35
00:01:49.550 --> 00:01:51.790
But before we look at the different types,

36
00:01:51.790 --> 00:01:54.360
there is a commonality to
these different types.

37
00:01:54.360 --> 00:01:57.820
And that is the internal
nature of these drives.

38
00:01:57.820 --> 00:01:58.920
Let me show you what I mean here.

39
00:01:58.920 --> 00:02:03.970
If we look at what the drive consists of,
right.

40
00:02:03.970 --> 00:02:05.870
If we were to pop one of these open here,

41
00:02:05.870 --> 00:02:10.010
you could see that it contains
a series of platters right.

42
00:02:10.010 --> 00:02:12.900
You can see this arm, kind of like
the old record player needle, right.

43
00:02:12.900 --> 00:02:15.380
As you would play a record, right,

44
00:02:15.380 --> 00:02:18.690
that needle would go farther and
farther and farther across the record.

45
00:02:18.690 --> 00:02:23.220
While it's really not too much different
in concept when you look at the internal

46
00:02:23.220 --> 00:02:25.050
workings of a hard disk drive.

47
00:02:25.050 --> 00:02:29.620
Right, when I decide that inside of
the operating system I wanna click save.

48
00:02:29.620 --> 00:02:32.670
Well, depending on where I save it,
a lot of times,

49
00:02:32.670 --> 00:02:34.590
commonly it's gonna be
on one of these drives.

50
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:37.930
Now what happens when we need
to find that information?

51
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:42.040
Well this armature and these planners
is what helps us retrieve, and

52
00:02:42.040 --> 00:02:45.260
not only retrieve but store,
that information likewise too.

53
00:02:45.260 --> 00:02:48.670
And that actuator arm as it's called,
that little arm that looks like,

54
00:02:48.670 --> 00:02:51.630
kinda like,
again kinda like a record player needle.

55
00:02:51.630 --> 00:02:55.440
And you could see that it's very, very
close to the surface of those platters,

56
00:02:55.440 --> 00:02:57.810
and it uses magnets if you will.

57
00:02:57.810 --> 00:02:59.820
It's what's known as a magnetic media,

58
00:02:59.820 --> 00:03:04.210
it uses electromagnetic pulses to
store and retrieve the information.

59
00:03:04.210 --> 00:03:08.140
So that's one of the things you gotta keep
in mind with these hard drives is they

60
00:03:08.140 --> 00:03:11.440
are sensitive to magnetic shock,
if you will.

61
00:03:11.440 --> 00:03:13.370
You certainly don't wanna
be putting magnets over,

62
00:03:13.370 --> 00:03:17.200
in fact that's the way they erase a lot
of the storage data that's on them.

63
00:03:17.200 --> 00:03:21.932
So again, as the technology has
progressed, you can get more and

64
00:03:21.932 --> 00:03:23.147
more platters.

65
00:03:23.147 --> 00:03:27.610
What the traditional trend has been is
you start to see the fact that these

66
00:03:27.610 --> 00:03:29.820
capacities get larger and larger.

67
00:03:29.820 --> 00:03:32.760
What I mean by capacities is,
think of a basket, right.

68
00:03:32.760 --> 00:03:35.694
The bigger the basket, the more stuff
I can put in the basket, right.

69
00:03:35.694 --> 00:03:39.127
Well as the capacity grows
within these hard disk drives,

70
00:03:39.127 --> 00:03:41.800
I get the ability to
store more information.

71
00:03:41.800 --> 00:03:45.450
And we're gonna look, coming up, at some
of the different types of those drives.

72
00:03:45.450 --> 00:03:49.810
>> So Wes, let's talk about that
idea of capacity just for a moment.

73
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:54.600
So when somebody goes and picks up a hard
drive or they tell me that they have a 500

74
00:03:54.600 --> 00:04:00.110
gig hard drive, I really don't
know what that ends up meaning.

75
00:04:00.110 --> 00:04:02.640
So, what do we normally talk
about when we start talking about

76
00:04:02.640 --> 00:04:06.090
the term like gigabytes or
megabytes or anything like that.

77
00:04:06.090 --> 00:04:07.380
>> Sure, that's a measurement right.

78
00:04:07.380 --> 00:04:11.230
It's no different than if we
were to say inches, feet, miles,

79
00:04:11.230 --> 00:04:12.960
right, it's how we measure distance.

80
00:04:12.960 --> 00:04:16.590
Well, there's a way that we measure how
much we have in that basket, right.

81
00:04:16.590 --> 00:04:19.150
I need to know that something's
the size of an apple,

82
00:04:19.150 --> 00:04:23.460
how many apples can I get in there right,
versus I can get one watermelon, right?

83
00:04:23.460 --> 00:04:26.190
So there's different size
of what can be in there.

84
00:04:26.190 --> 00:04:30.210
So let's talk about those measurements
that we use inside of storage, right?

85
00:04:30.210 --> 00:04:33.730
One of the smaller ones, smallest ones
what we have are what is known as bytes,

86
00:04:33.730 --> 00:04:34.360
right?

87
00:04:34.360 --> 00:04:36.970
And when we look at a byte of data, right?

88
00:04:36.970 --> 00:04:40.640
That's broken up to even smaller
amounts of data called bits, right?

89
00:04:40.640 --> 00:04:44.017
Bit by bit, you might have heard that
term, if you haven't well now you have.

90
00:04:44.017 --> 00:04:48.230
And eight bits of data
become a byte right.

91
00:04:48.230 --> 00:04:52.408
Then we go up in to megabytes,
that's the next if you will,

92
00:04:52.408 --> 00:04:55.762
a thousand bits I believe it is,
is a megabyte.

93
00:04:55.762 --> 00:04:56.790
>> Kilobyte.

94
00:04:56.790 --> 00:04:59.430
>> Kilobyte, that's right,
I've completely forgot about kilobytes.

95
00:04:59.430 --> 00:05:02.211
A kilobyte, megabyte and
then gigabyte, and

96
00:05:02.211 --> 00:05:04.570
what you see is the amount of capacity.

97
00:05:04.570 --> 00:05:07.120
Once you get into gigabytes, right,

98
00:05:07.120 --> 00:05:12.320
now we're talking about 1
gigabyte is 1000 megabytes right?

99
00:05:12.320 --> 00:05:16.380
If we talk about 1000 kilobytes,
that's 1 megabyte.

100
00:05:16.380 --> 00:05:20.097
And it goes on and on and on up the scale
until you eventually you get in to what

101
00:05:20.097 --> 00:05:21.755
are known as terabytes, right?

102
00:05:21.755 --> 00:05:23.280
Well what's a terabyte?

103
00:05:23.280 --> 00:05:25.460
Well that is 1,000 gigabytes.

104
00:05:25.460 --> 00:05:27.900
So when you look at
the capacity of the drive,

105
00:05:27.900 --> 00:05:30.980
you have to make a choice if
you're gonna be supporting it,

106
