now we can use it as a storage device.

544
00:29:53.480 --> 00:29:57.670
>> This is, no doubt, the understanding
that data cannot go on a drive,

545
00:29:57.670 --> 00:30:01.590
regardless of whether its a solid
state drive or flash drive.

546
00:30:01.590 --> 00:30:04.410
Or mechanical drives without
either the partitioning or

547
00:30:04.410 --> 00:30:05.990
the actual formatting on there.

548
00:30:05.990 --> 00:30:10.120
Because if we do try to put data on to
a drive like that, there's no way for

549
00:30:10.120 --> 00:30:14.170
that system to be able to locate
data on that drive as well So

550
00:30:14.170 --> 00:30:15.630
we do need that understanding.

551
00:30:15.630 --> 00:30:17.710
Now, Wes we already talked
about hard drives and

552
00:30:17.710 --> 00:30:19.990
the core to formatting fairly well.

553
00:30:19.990 --> 00:30:24.100
What other types of drives do we need
to think about in terms of storage?

554
00:30:24.100 --> 00:30:28.260
>> One of the last things that I'd like to
tackle in this episode is optical drives.

555
00:30:28.260 --> 00:30:31.470
It's one of the things that we need to
know, it's another storage device that is

556
00:30:31.470 --> 00:30:34.960
out there and I know that we might
see it disappear eventually.

557
00:30:34.960 --> 00:30:36.440
But it's still very prevalent and

558
00:30:36.440 --> 00:30:38.210
it's gonna be something that
you're gonna encounter.

559
00:30:38.210 --> 00:30:40.660
So let's go ahead and dive right in.

560
00:30:40.660 --> 00:30:44.160
Optical drive,
we've got one here that you can see.

561
00:30:44.160 --> 00:30:48.630
Notice that we've got another mechanical,
magnetic based media unlike the one that

562
00:30:48.630 --> 00:30:52.390
Ronnie and I were talking about earlier,
like solid state's electrical, right?

563
00:30:52.390 --> 00:30:55.400
Your memory cards,
this is a mechanical drive.

564
00:30:55.400 --> 00:30:59.740
And we put these optical disks
inside the tray, we push our button,

565
00:30:59.740 --> 00:31:05.370
hopefully we push the button and it
inserts that disk into the optical drive.

566
00:31:05.370 --> 00:31:12.050
And it uses a laser in order to read and
write information on that disk.

567
00:31:12.050 --> 00:31:14.860
And essentially what it's doing
is it's burning the disk, really.

568
00:31:14.860 --> 00:31:19.000
It's either reading from it, right,
which isn't doing anything to the disk,

569
00:31:19.000 --> 00:31:22.160
other than the laser is interpreting
little raised areas and

570
00:31:22.160 --> 00:31:24.750
lowered areas on the disk surface.

571
00:31:24.750 --> 00:31:28.440
Or the laser is actually burning and
melting the plastic in the disk.

572
00:31:28.440 --> 00:31:32.000
And what that does is, that's essentially
writing the data to the disk.

573
00:31:32.000 --> 00:31:36.460
Now that being said, there are different
formats over the years and

574
00:31:36.460 --> 00:31:37.770
I kinda wanna just look at these.

575
00:31:37.770 --> 00:31:40.400
And you really can make these fairly easy.

576
00:31:40.400 --> 00:31:42.940
I know it looks like a slew
of letters up here, guys,

577
00:31:42.940 --> 00:31:45.530
we'll see if we can break it down,
make it a little bit easier.

578
00:31:46.680 --> 00:31:48.388
Three of the ones that we
really need to look at,

579
00:31:48.388 --> 00:31:49.897
that have become the industry standard.

580
00:31:49.897 --> 00:31:54.668
There's an older one, CDs,
DVDs and blue ray disk and

581
00:31:54.668 --> 00:31:57.800
look at the different variations.

582
00:31:57.800 --> 00:32:01.132
And man, like I said, this looks
like it could be very confusing.

583
00:32:01.132 --> 00:32:02.546
We got ROM, we got.

584
00:32:02.546 --> 00:32:06.282
R, we've got RW,
well what does that mean for us?

585
00:32:06.282 --> 00:32:10.159
Well let's take a look at what
that means for us, all right?

586
00:32:10.159 --> 00:32:14.901
When we look at ROM, all right,
I want you to notice something about ROM.

587
00:32:14.901 --> 00:32:18.501
ROM, and apparently I've got
a random text box there.

588
00:32:18.501 --> 00:32:25.590
[LAUGH] ROM is one in which you
can only read, you cannot write.

589
00:32:25.590 --> 00:32:28.430
All right, and
that is important to understand.

590
00:32:30.260 --> 00:32:33.250
So notice that I don't have
the ability to write to it.

591
00:32:33.250 --> 00:32:37.296
That means the manufacturer, whoever made
that disk, they put the data on it and

592
00:32:37.296 --> 00:32:40.643
they sealed it in a way that you
can't do anything else to the disk.

593
00:32:40.643 --> 00:32:45.448
Your, video games are like this,
your audio CDs are like this.

594
00:32:45.448 --> 00:32:49.280
I can't put additional
information onto there.

595
00:32:49.280 --> 00:32:51.820
The R is what's known as writable.

596
00:32:51.820 --> 00:32:56.440
Now, if we look at this one, R writable
means I can write to the disk one time,

597
00:32:57.440 --> 00:33:00.330
but then after that,
I don't have the ability to write again.

598
00:33:00.330 --> 00:33:02.380
Now, from them on out, it's read only.

599
00:33:03.420 --> 00:33:07.590
So write once, read multiple times.

600
00:33:08.650 --> 00:33:12.970
Now, the other ones here are,
they're unique in a way.

601
00:33:12.970 --> 00:33:16.050
Well, not this one, but
the RE definitely is.

602
00:33:16.050 --> 00:33:20.390
The reason I have them together is because
essentially even though the letters

603
00:33:20.390 --> 00:33:22.950
differ, and the format differs,
they're doing the same thing.

604
00:33:24.290 --> 00:33:27.540
RW, and
I don't care if these are CDs or DVDs.

605
00:33:27.540 --> 00:33:30.490
R, ROM, R, and RW mean the same thing.

606
00:33:31.590 --> 00:33:34.760
So RW basically means rewritable.

607
00:33:34.760 --> 00:33:36.290
Notice that I have multiple writes.

608
00:33:36.290 --> 00:33:40.340
Write many times, read as much as
you want, but write many times.

609
00:33:40.340 --> 00:33:43.550
RE is what they call in Blu-ray
essentially a writable disk,

610
00:33:43.550 --> 00:33:49.293
rewritable disk, it's called recordable or
erasable, that's specific to Blue-ray.

611
00:33:49.293 --> 00:33:54.510
Finally, lets, I put the carriage
right in front of the horse there,

612
00:33:54.510 --> 00:33:57.805
so we could take away all
of those crazy letterings.

613
00:33:57.805 --> 00:34:02.657
Cuz now we only have three different sets
of letters to worry about CD, DVD and

614
00:34:02.657 --> 00:34:03.420
Blu-ray.

615
00:34:03.420 --> 00:34:04.970
Well what does that mean for us?

616
00:34:04.970 --> 00:34:06.882
Well, lets take a look at that.

617
00:34:06.882 --> 00:34:13.766
When it comes to CDs and DVDs and Blu-ray.

618
00:34:13.766 --> 00:34:18.250
I really want you to think about
the capacity of information that can be

619
00:34:18.250 --> 00:34:19.165
stored on it.

620
00:34:19.165 --> 00:34:21.236
And also want you to
think about the speed.

621
00:34:21.236 --> 00:34:24.893
CDs around 700 megs, I know they vary,
I know there's variations on it,

622
00:34:24.893 --> 00:34:26.600
the most common one is 700 megs.

623
00:34:26.600 --> 00:34:27.520
So what is it good for?

624
00:34:28.700 --> 00:34:32.030
Well, what I didn't put up here is data,
it's good for data as well.

625
00:34:32.030 --> 00:34:34.930
But it's also common in things for
audio files, it's,

626
00:34:34.930 --> 00:34:39.120
I think about 80 minutes of audio
files that can be put in to it.

627
00:34:39.120 --> 00:34:41.700
It's not really too good for video.

628
00:34:41.700 --> 00:34:46.890
Although you will see older disk out there
that might still have some video want it.

629
00:34:46.890 --> 00:34:50.190
The common one that used video is DVD.

630
00:34:50.190 --> 00:34:52.720
Notice the difference here
between the CD and the DVD.

631
00:34:52.720 --> 00:34:55.120
The DVD gives me up to around 17 gigs,

632
00:34:55.120 --> 00:34:59.110
I'll tell you most commonly is
gonna be either 4.7 or 9.4 gigs.

633
00:34:59.110 --> 00:35:04.200
But, again it's about the compacity also
the quality of the playback if you will.

634
00:35:04.200 --> 00:35:10.738
So, it's very good for movies this is why
DVD was so common to find movies on it.

635
00:35:10.738 --> 00:35:14.353
Blu-ray on the other hand,
it's still movies and keep in mind,

636
00:35:14.353 --> 00:35:16.400
you could use these for data as well.

637
00:35:16.400 --> 00:35:20.090
It's still movies but
now it's the quality of that movie.

638
00:35:20.090 --> 00:35:23.630
High definition, remember we told you
that's a big watermelon of basket.

639
00:35:23.630 --> 00:35:28.375
That's a lot of capacity on that drive
well Blu-ray could scale up to about a 128

640
00:35:28.375 --> 00:35:31.010
gigs depending on what
kind of disc you have.

641
00:35:31.010 --> 00:35:35.530
Which makes them ideal for high definition
video and high definition playback.

642
00:35:35.530 --> 00:35:37.170
So you also see those commonly.

643
00:35:37.170 --> 00:35:38.540
So those are the three.

644
00:35:38.540 --> 00:35:42.310
And like I said, don't make all of those
jumbling of letters confuse you there.

645
00:35:42.310 --> 00:35:43.708
It doesn't have to be confusing.

646
00:35:43.708 --> 00:35:47.560
R, RW, and RE in this case.

647
00:35:47.560 --> 00:35:51.690
It depends on, do you want to write to it
and do you want to write multiple times?

648
00:35:51.690 --> 00:35:55.650
When it comes to CD, DVD and
Blu-ray it's about the capacity.

649
00:35:55.650 --> 00:35:57.420
Quality and the speed of the output.

650
00:35:57.420 --> 00:36:02.370
So, that is the other storage media
that we want you to take a look at.

651
00:36:02.370 --> 00:36:05.920
We definitely want you to know because
it is one that you're gonna come across

652
00:36:05.920 --> 00:36:08.440
when you decide that you're
gonna support computing.

653
00:36:09.470 --> 00:36:10.170
>> All right, Wes.

654
00:36:10.170 --> 00:36:13.120
Well, thank you for introducing us to
some of those different storage devices

655
00:36:13.120 --> 00:36:15.900
that we are gonna encounter
as users out there.

656
00:36:15.900 --> 00:36:17.400
Remember that a lot of these, of course,

657
00:36:17.400 --> 00:36:20.720
are based around that
idea of capacity as well.

658
00:36:20.720 --> 00:36:24.580
And you need to get the type of storage
for your computer that's gonna actually

659
00:36:24.580 --> 00:36:28.830
support how much stuff that you would need
to store on those types of drives as well.

660
00:36:28.830 --> 00:36:31.870
And then, from that point,
you just select the right type of media.

661
00:36:31.870 --> 00:36:35.480
Whether you're going for a solid state or
some type of flash drive or

662
00:36:35.480 --> 00:36:38.130
whether you're going for
mechanical or even optical.

663
00:36:38.130 --> 00:36:41.830
Those are some of the different
selections that you have ahead of you.

664
00:36:41.830 --> 00:36:43.780
>> Well, and that's a great place for
us to end this episode.

665
00:36:43.780 --> 00:36:47.960
Signing off for ITPro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

666
00:36:47.960 --> 00:36:48.980
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

667
00:36:48.980 --> 00:36:52.125
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

668
00:36:52.125 --> 00:37:01.920
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce operating systems architecture.  Here they show that there are several different operating systems that computer users will likely encounter.  They describe the major differences and also class them as desktop and/or server operating systems.  Lastly they describe some of the utilities and tools normally built into the operating system to keep the operating system maintained.
episodes.title: Computer Software Architecture
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.162 --> 00:00:15.280
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.280 --> 00:00:19.700
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and you're
watching the IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

4
00:00:19.700 --> 00:00:21.920
We are about to actually take a look into,

5
00:00:21.920 --> 00:00:26.360
well, the operating system side of
things and software side of things.

6
00:00:26.360 --> 00:00:30.950
And here to help us out to understand this
integration of ideas is Mr. Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:30.950 --> 00:00:32.160
Wes, welcome back to our show.

8
00:00:32.160 --> 00:00:33.048
>> Thanks for having me here.

9
00:00:33.048 --> 00:00:35.607
That's right,
it's great to be here with ITProTV crew.

10
00:00:35.607 --> 00:00:39.193
That's right, we're gonna be diving
into the operating system now and

11
00:00:39.193 --> 00:00:42.013
we've been talking so
far about a lot of hardware here but

12
00:00:42.013 --> 00:00:45.267
we haven't really touched base
on is what drives that hardware.

13
00:00:45.267 --> 00:00:49.426
And what is the basic interface
into the computing environment,

14
00:00:49.426 --> 00:00:51.850
into the computing system as a whole.

15
00:00:51.850 --> 00:00:55.830
So we definitely wanna start looking
at the operating system architecture.

16
00:00:55.830 --> 00:00:59.780
So what is an operating system and
why do we even need one?

17
00:00:59.780 --> 00:01:02.990
Well an operating system
essentially allows us to work

18
00:01:02.990 --> 00:01:04.650
with an information system.

19
00:01:04.650 --> 00:01:08.610
Without it, we wouldn't be able to
work with information systems at all.

20
00:01:08.610 --> 00:01:10.060
And even more basically than that,

21
00:01:10.060 --> 00:01:13.030
an operating system allows
us to control our hardware.

22
00:01:13.030 --> 00:01:15.050
So it is important, very important,

23
00:01:15.050 --> 00:01:19.630
that we have an operating system on our
machines so that we can use these systems.

24
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:23.725
Because keep in mind, it's the hardware
that needs to run, and it's the operating

25
00:01:23.725 --> 00:01:27.415
system that communicates to
that hardware to make it run.

26
00:01:27.415 --> 00:01:32.015
I've actually got a little diagram
here that just to bring up abstractly

27
00:01:32.015 --> 00:01:36.452
the different layers here that we have,
so if we could pull up the computer here.

28
00:01:36.452 --> 00:01:40.082
When we look at it, there's a few
different layers that we have, right.

29
00:01:40.082 --> 00:01:43.232
The user,
what does the user interact with?

30
00:01:43.232 --> 00:01:44.862
Remember, it all boils
down to the hardware and

31
00:01:44.862 --> 00:01:47.182
we're trying to get that
hardware to do what we want so

32
00:01:47.182 --> 00:01:49.222
that we can work with
an information system.

33
00:01:49.222 --> 00:01:51.832
Well, the primary interface

34
00:01:51.832 --> 00:01:54.762
into the machine is gonna
be a couple different ways.

35
00:01:54.762 --> 00:01:59.150
We have this term of what's known as
a GUI, that's a Graphical User Interface.

36
00:01:59.150 --> 00:02:03.900
And the graphical user interface is where
we can use like our mouse if you will.

37
00:02:03.900 --> 00:02:06.650
And we've got a cursor an arrow on

38
00:02:06.650 --> 00:02:10.400
the screen typically where we can do
something known as point and click.

39
00:02:10.400 --> 00:02:14.500
And it makes it fairly easy to work
with your operating system once you

40
00:02:14.500 --> 00:02:17.720
know some of the basics in
how to navigate through

41
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:20.430
the different locations inside
of the operating system.

42
00:02:20.430 --> 00:02:23.310
The other thing that we have is
what's known as a command line

43
00:02:23.310 --> 00:02:24.260
interpreter, right?

44
00:02:24.260 --> 00:02:27.510
And a command line interpreter is where
we can essentially take the mouse and

45
00:02:27.510 --> 00:02:28.230
throw it away.

46
00:02:28.230 --> 00:02:30.820
No, don't do that, don't throw
your mouse away, I was kidding.

47
00:02:30.820 --> 00:02:36.860
And we basically are going to type text
based information into a dialogue box and

48
00:02:36.860 --> 00:02:41.020
that is how we are going to interact
inside of the operating system.

49
00:02:41.020 --> 00:02:44.500
Now, the next thing that we have, the next
layer below that are the applications that

50
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:48.130
we use to get the output that we want,
right?

51
00:02:48.130 --> 00:02:51.320
We have all different types of
applications and software out there.

52
00:02:51.320 --> 00:02:55.110
And these actually run on top of
the operating system if you will.

53
00:02:55.110 --> 00:02:58.690
And we have things like our productivity
apps, we have utilities and

54
00:02:58.690 --> 00:03:03.360
different multi media applications where
we can do things like watching video.

55
00:03:03.360 --> 00:03:05.030
So what is the layer below that?

56
00:03:05.030 --> 00:03:08.630
Well here is where we start to get to
the actual operating system and the core

57
00:03:08.630 --> 00:03:13.680
functionality that's really helping us
communicate with our hardware, right?

58
00:03:13.680 --> 00:03:16.160
And there's all different
types that we have out there.

59
00:03:16.160 --> 00:03:20.910
And these are by far definitely
the most popular that we have in there.

60
00:03:20.910 --> 00:03:24.140
And we've got Windows and we'll talk a
little more about these operating systems.

61
00:03:24.140 --> 00:03:26.690
We have Unix that's been around for
a long time.

62
00:03:26.690 --> 00:03:30.870
Some of you might be familiar with Mac,
the OS X operating system is out there and

63
00:03:30.870 --> 00:03:31.880
then we have Linux.

64
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:36.110
And inside of that operating
system we have different

65
00:03:38.200 --> 00:03:41.830
components that help us to
interact with the hardware.

66
00:03:41.830 --> 00:03:44.540
We have things like background
processes that go on.

67
00:03:44.540 --> 00:03:46.170
Now, what is a background process?

68
00:03:46.170 --> 00:03:49.275
Notice that it's not in
the application section.

69
00:03:49.275 --> 00:03:50.805
Because a background process,

70
00:03:50.805 --> 00:03:54.815
unlike an application usually
isn't triggered by an end user.

71
00:03:54.815 --> 00:03:57.825
Meaning, quite literally, looking at
an icon and double clicking it and

72
00:03:57.825 --> 00:04:00.792
maybe a dialogue box comes up or
a notepad comes up.

73
00:04:00.792 --> 00:04:03.382
So your operating system
have these services and

74
00:04:03.382 --> 00:04:07.972
processes in the background that are
constantly running, that we probably, for

75
00:04:07.972 --> 00:04:09.982
the most part, don't even see.

76
00:04:09.982 --> 00:04:15.432
And you can probably put somewhere down
here a layer in between if you will.

77
00:04:15.432 --> 00:04:19.820
That's our drivers and that allows
us to interact with the hardware.

78
00:04:19.820 --> 00:04:24.150
So when we, and then finally at the bottom
we have the hardware as well too.

79
00:04:24.150 --> 00:04:28.910
We zoom back out here, I want you to
think of the user being at the top.

80
00:04:28.910 --> 00:04:36.560
The user is going to interact basically
with one of these two interfaces.

81
00:04:36.560 --> 00:04:43.380
And then what happens is the commands that
they send are based on the applications.

82
00:04:43.380 --> 00:04:46.350
The application talks to
the operating system and

83
00:04:46.350 --> 00:04:47.920
I know we can't see
that arrow right there.

84
00:04:47.920 --> 00:04:51.390
And then finally through the driver's and
the services that we have going on in

85
00:04:51.390 --> 00:04:55.400
the background, at the operating
system talks to the hardware.

86
00:04:55.400 --> 00:04:58.209
And then finally back through all
of that stack we get our output

87
00:04:58.209 --> 00:05:00.329
displayed on the monitor
whatever it might be.

88
00:05:00.329 --> 00:05:02.869
It might not be the fact that
you're trying to display anything,

89
00:05:02.869 --> 00:05:05.143
it could be the fact that you're
just trying to save data.

90
00:05:05.143 --> 00:05:09.730
So basically,
the interaction kind of works that way.

91
00:05:09.730 --> 00:05:12.340
All right, so an operating system in its

92
00:05:12.340 --> 00:05:16.530
very basic functionality allows
us to control the hardware.

93
00:05:16.530 --> 00:05:18.300
Without an operating system,

94
00:05:18.300 --> 00:05:23.560
unfortunately our hardware is just gonna
be sitting there doing absolutely nothing.

95
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:26.450
We're not gonna have an information system

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes help us to understand the basic Windows 7 user interface.  They show the different elements of the Windows 7 interface.  They describe and demonstrate how to work with the desktop, desktop icons, start menu and some of the customization elements.  They help the user to understand how it works to the advantage of the user.

Well, where did they go?

482
00:26:23.890 --> 00:26:25.120
Did it close them down?

483
00:26:25.120 --> 00:26:27.430
It did something known as minimize.

484
00:26:27.430 --> 00:26:29.830
All right, minimize in is
another option that you have.

485
00:26:29.830 --> 00:26:33.270
If you decide that you wanna
keep an application open, but

486
00:26:33.270 --> 00:26:38.800
you don't want to have it on your desktop,
you can choose the Show desktop icon and

487
00:26:38.800 --> 00:26:41.370
it minimizes all applications.

488
00:26:41.370 --> 00:26:44.630
Or we can come up here and
choose this underscore option and

489
00:26:44.630 --> 00:26:45.860
it does the same thing.

490
00:26:45.860 --> 00:26:52.280
So it's basically like saying, hey,
I wanna minimize all of your applications.

491
00:26:52.280 --> 00:26:54.160
One of the last things I
might show you here, and

492
00:26:54.160 --> 00:26:57.488
again, a little bit more advanced,
but just so you know where it is.

493
00:26:57.488 --> 00:27:01.780
If I right-click on the taskbar, I've got
a set of Properties that I can configure.

494
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:05.440
Now, it's gonna be a lot like the same
dialog box that you've seen before

495
00:27:05.440 --> 00:27:07.620
when we were on the Start menu.

496
00:27:07.620 --> 00:27:11.190
But the difference is the tabs,
okay, see these are tabs,

497
00:27:11.190 --> 00:27:13.540
I also take a second to
show you what these are.

498
00:27:13.540 --> 00:27:17.560
And you could switch between the different
tabs offering different options.

499
00:27:17.560 --> 00:27:19.370
The Taskbar here, keep in mind,

500
00:27:19.370 --> 00:27:24.270
in the Taskbar properties I do get the
option to modify the taskbar a little bit.

501
00:27:24.270 --> 00:27:28.320
Including things like Auto-hide which
would make the taskbar disappear.

502
00:27:28.320 --> 00:27:30.280
I don't personally like that setting, but

503
00:27:30.280 --> 00:27:34.510
you can also modify different aspects
of the taskbar if you want to.

504
00:27:34.510 --> 00:27:37.290
Now, that being said too,
maybe one of the true last

505
00:27:37.290 --> 00:27:40.008
things I will say about the taskbar,
notice how it says it's locked?

506
00:27:40.008 --> 00:27:42.890
Well, the taskbar is customizable as well.

507
00:27:42.890 --> 00:27:45.394
If I choose to choose that option,
basically,

508
00:27:45.394 --> 00:27:47.846
you'll see that the check
mark is gone there.

509
00:27:47.846 --> 00:27:51.351
And I do have the ability,
if I want now, I can,

510
00:27:51.351 --> 00:27:55.170
let's see if it'll let me do it,
there we go.

511
00:27:55.170 --> 00:27:59.170
I can move the taskbar to the different
sides of the desktop if I want.

512
00:27:59.170 --> 00:28:02.940
Personally, I just keep it right there,
and I do lock it.

513
00:28:04.930 --> 00:28:07.990
All right, Ronnie, so
that's a couple of things

514
00:28:07.990 --> 00:28:12.970
that we have as far as the basic
entrance into the interface.

515
00:28:12.970 --> 00:28:15.860
Keep in mind, hover,
right, hover over things.

516
00:28:15.860 --> 00:28:18.270
If you're not exactly sure what it does,
and

517
00:28:18.270 --> 00:28:21.610
there's an icon on your desktop,
hover over it, find out what it says.

518
00:28:21.610 --> 00:28:24.879
A lot of times you can get information
just by taking that cursor,

519
00:28:24.879 --> 00:28:26.551
and just hovering right over it.

520
00:28:26.551 --> 00:28:28.812
And it'll give you the chance to
see a little bit of information,

521
00:28:28.812 --> 00:28:30.800
even if you don't know what it does.

522
00:28:30.800 --> 00:28:34.130
>> Now, Wes, I know that we're a little
bit short on time but I think we have

523
00:28:34.130 --> 00:28:37.460
enough time to cover the idea of just
customization a little bit more.

524
00:28:37.460 --> 00:28:41.690
And that is, I know that people can change
it from that default background and

525
00:28:41.690 --> 00:28:44.350
actually make the style look
a little bit different.

526
00:28:44.350 --> 00:28:45.690
Wes, can you show us how to do that?

527
00:28:45.690 --> 00:28:47.360
>> Most definitely, great question here.

528
00:28:47.360 --> 00:28:51.210
Let's go back to our desktop and
this time remember that the right-click,

529
00:28:51.210 --> 00:28:54.360
the context,
the right-click on the desktop.

530
00:28:54.360 --> 00:28:58.020
And you gotta be careful with that too so
let me show you here on my desktop.

531
00:28:58.020 --> 00:29:01.270
Now here's what I wanna,
just real quick, I wanna show you here.

532
00:29:01.270 --> 00:29:05.230
Notice that when I right-click here,
notice there's a set of options.

533
00:29:05.230 --> 00:29:07.930
We'll get to those,
exactly what Ronnie was asking.

534
00:29:07.930 --> 00:29:10.240
But the moment I come down here,

535
00:29:10.240 --> 00:29:13.110
I get a completely different
set of right-click options.

536
00:29:13.110 --> 00:29:15.960
So what I'm gonna tell you now
is to do what Ronnie's saying.

537
00:29:15.960 --> 00:29:20.320
Make sure you're on the desktop, you
click the desktop when you right-click.

538
00:29:20.320 --> 00:29:24.940
And you're gonna notice something,
an option that says, Personalize, right?

539
00:29:24.940 --> 00:29:27.928
Well, we're gonna look in how
we can change that background.

540
00:29:27.928 --> 00:29:31.088
We'll select Personalize, all right.

541
00:29:31.088 --> 00:29:33.310
And then the option that we have here,
if we want,

542
00:29:33.310 --> 00:29:37.220
is to change what
background we might want.

543
00:29:37.220 --> 00:29:41.306
All right, and if I decide I can
change the desktop background.

544
00:29:41.306 --> 00:29:44.740
And looks like I'm getting out of
the area there where you can see that.

545
00:29:44.740 --> 00:29:46.390
Notice, it says Desktop Background?

546
00:29:46.390 --> 00:29:49.670
I've got the option,
I can click that, all right?

547
00:29:49.670 --> 00:29:54.575
And we'll scroll back out here and
I've got the chance that I can pick,

548
00:29:54.575 --> 00:29:58.045
in this case, I can select this
next picture that's in the list.

549
00:29:58.045 --> 00:30:01.655
You can download one of you want and
you can use your own pictures.

550
00:30:01.655 --> 00:30:03.785
If you like your favorite
comic book character,

551
00:30:03.785 --> 00:30:05.345
you put your comic book character there.

552
00:30:05.345 --> 00:30:07.825
In this case,
I'm just gonna use the defaults.

553
00:30:07.825 --> 00:30:11.355
And then we have the option to change
how the picture is positioned.

554
00:30:11.355 --> 00:30:14.325
If we wanna tile it, personally
that's a little distracting for me so

555
00:30:14.325 --> 00:30:17.140
I just let it fill
the whole entire screen.

556
00:30:17.140 --> 00:30:20.010
And notice that I can save the changes.

557
00:30:20.010 --> 00:30:24.940
And when I close this down, I now have
beautiful picture of a sunset or maybe

558
00:30:24.940 --> 00:30:28.880
a sunrise, and I don't know, some lavender
and a lake, makes me wanna go fishing.

559
00:30:28.880 --> 00:30:32.050
So you can [LAUGH] change
your background as well.

560
00:30:32.050 --> 00:30:34.300
Remember that you don't have to
stick with the defaults either.

561
00:30:34.300 --> 00:30:38.220
You can load up your own pictures and
load them into that area and

562
00:30:38.220 --> 00:30:39.850
you can customize it even more.

563
00:30:39.850 --> 00:30:43.780
>> Well, thank you, Wes, for showing
us at least some of those basics there.

564
00:30:43.780 --> 00:30:47.000
And a lot of times in a work environment,
in a corporate environment,

565
00:30:47.000 --> 00:30:49.128
as you go to work on
computers on a daily basis,

566
00:30:49.128 --> 00:30:51.764
it is possible that you can
change some of these options.

567
00:30:51.764 --> 00:30:56.465
Including the size of the mouse itself and
there's a few other things, but

568
00:30:56.465 --> 00:30:59.533
to customize it,
to make it fit what you need to.

569
00:30:59.533 --> 00:31:04.167
But you might also end up finding out
that you can't change any of it either

570
00:31:04.167 --> 00:31:06.960
because that environment may lock it down.

571
00:31:06.960 --> 00:31:10.730
Hopefully it won't be, but if that
environment locks it down to the point

572
00:31:10.730 --> 00:31:15.030
where when you right-click on something
and you don't have that option available,

573
00:31:15.030 --> 00:31:18.170
or the option looks like it's
grayed out and you can't select it.

574
00:31:18.170 --> 00:31:20.810
It could be that it is being
controlled somewhere else.

575
00:31:20.810 --> 00:31:23.066
So even though you might have it,
you may not as well.

576
00:31:23.066 --> 00:31:26.276
Just kinda realize that those are our
options that you'll be facing.

577
00:31:26.276 --> 00:31:29.942
Now, Wes has showed us a lot of great
things and helping us to at least get used

578
00:31:29.942 --> 00:31:33.420
to the interface that we'll be
seeing on day-to-day basis.

579
00:31:33.420 --> 00:31:36.930
But there's actually even more that
we're actually going to talk about.

580
00:31:36.930 --> 00:31:39.405
But we're gonna come back for
that in a part two.

581
00:31:39.405 --> 00:31:42.600
So that you get a full benefit of
understanding things like user

582
00:31:42.600 --> 00:31:45.550
accounts and a few other settings there

583
00:31:45.550 --> 00:31:48.381
that will really help you
as a computer user as well.

584
00:31:48.381 --> 00:31:51.540
Well, it's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

585
00:31:51.540 --> 00:31:55.047
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

586
00:31:55.047 --> 00:31:56.183
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

587
00:31:56.183 --> 00:32:00.808
>> Stay tuned for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

588
00:32:00.808 --> 00:32:09.250
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes continue to show some of the other configurations that a Windows 7 user will need to understand.  They describe the need of user accounts.  Also, they discuss the purpose of the user account control to help with computer safety and security.  They finish the episode with other user customizations that are possible.
episodes.title: Configurations and Preferences Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.032 --> 00:00:10.032
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.814 --> 00:00:15.470
Welcome back to another great
show right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.470 --> 00:00:19.850
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and you're
watching the IC3 Computing Fundamentals

4
00:00:19.850 --> 00:00:26.340
show where we are about to go into
the part two of configurations and

5
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:29.500
some of the different types of
preferences that we have available.

6
00:00:29.500 --> 00:00:31.230
We've already taken a look at
some of the customizations.

7
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:33.030
We're gonna take a look at
that a little bit more.

8
00:00:33.030 --> 00:00:36.310
But then there are some other features
that you need to know about as you

9
00:00:36.310 --> 00:00:37.340
use the computer.

10
00:00:37.340 --> 00:00:40.840
And who better to help us than, well, Mr.
Windows himself, Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:40.840 --> 00:00:41.990
Wes, welcome back to our show.

12
00:00:41.990 --> 00:00:43.020
>> Thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:43.020 --> 00:00:45.227
That's right.
I talked way too much on the first one, so

14
00:00:45.227 --> 00:00:46.808
we're coming back with a part two.

15
00:00:46.808 --> 00:00:47.359
That's right.

16
00:00:47.359 --> 00:00:51.697
There are a couple of things that we wanna
look at that we didn't touch base on in

17
00:00:51.697 --> 00:00:53.492
the first part of this episode.

18
00:00:53.492 --> 00:00:55.950
First part of the segment,
I guess I should say.

19
00:00:55.950 --> 00:00:57.660
And we looked at the desktop, right.

20
00:00:57.660 --> 00:01:00.590
We looked at the task bar,
some of the configurations but

21
00:01:00.590 --> 00:01:03.770
there are other configurations that
you might have to take into account

22
00:01:03.770 --> 00:01:07.720
when you are supporting a computer, or
maybe you're not supporting a computer,

23
00:01:07.720 --> 00:01:09.820
maybe you're just using the computer.

24
00:01:09.820 --> 00:01:12.340
You might want to understand
some of these next topics.

25
00:01:12.340 --> 00:01:15.900
And one of the first ones I want to
talk about are user accounts, and

26
00:01:15.900 --> 00:01:20.710
you might say well a user account, that's
just a person that logs into the machine.

27
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:25.400
And you would be right, that is true,
but the type of user account you

28
00:01:25.400 --> 00:01:29.950
have is going to drastically
change the computing experience,

29
00:01:29.950 --> 00:01:32.260
what you can and
cannot do within the machine.

30
00:01:32.260 --> 00:01:35.020
So one of the very first types
of user accounts that we

31
00:01:35.020 --> 00:01:38.440
wanna talk about is something
known as the administrator.

32
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:40.110
Or the administrative account.

33
00:01:40.110 --> 00:01:41.840
Now the administrator accounts.

34
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:44.950
These are the accounts that allow
you to pretty much have your

35
00:01:44.950 --> 00:01:47.180
run of the operating system.

36
00:01:47.180 --> 00:01:49.540
You can do things like
installing software.

37
00:01:49.540 --> 00:01:52.020
You can run most of your utilities.

38
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:54.970
In fact some of the utilities that you
have inside of Windows that keeps that

39
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:59.090
environment running to its tip-top shape,
requiring you to

40
00:01:59.090 --> 00:02:03.530
be this type of user before you can
even see or launch those utilities.

41
00:02:03.530 --> 00:02:06.830
So it is important to understand
that the administrator

42
00:02:06.830 --> 00:02:10.290
is not only a powerful account,
but it does present, potentially,

43
00:02:10.290 --> 00:02:13.910
security concerns, because of the fact,
and what I mean by security is

44
00:02:13.910 --> 00:02:17.620
don't think that I'm talking about the CIA
coming in a grabbing your computer.

45
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:19.400
I don't mean those kind
of security concerns.

46
00:02:19.400 --> 00:02:25.010
I mean the stability of the operating
system because you can make configuration

47
00:02:25.010 --> 00:02:29.400
changes that could change the core
functionality of the operating system or

48
00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:31.250
key system settings.

49
00:02:31.250 --> 00:02:35.315
You also have the potential to
misconfigure some settings and

50
00:02:35.315 --> 00:02:36.830
you could cause some problems too.

51
00:02:36.830 --> 00:02:41.610
So that's why if you're an administrator
you wanna protect that account, all right.

52
00:02:41.610 --> 00:02:45.460
Now if we are talking true security you
gonna wanna protect that account just

53
00:02:45.460 --> 00:02:48.408
because of the privileges that it has.

54
00:02:48.408 --> 00:02:52.510
It's what we'd call a privileged account
has more privileges then the other types

55
00:02:52.510 --> 00:02:57.440
of accounts that we're gonna talk about
which is what's known as a standard user.

56
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:02.120
Now the standard user, they can perform
most of their day to day tasks.

57
00:03:02.120 --> 00:03:08.070
They can launch most of the applications
that, line of business type applications,

58
00:03:08.070 --> 00:03:10.980
a lot of the software that's on
the machine, things like Notepad and

59
00:03:10.980 --> 00:03:14.280
Paint and Calculator that
we've already kinda looked at.

60
00:03:14.280 --> 00:03:17.330
So far they can launch those applications.

61
00:03:17.330 --> 00:03:18.100
However, but

62
00:03:18.100 --> 00:03:22.270
when they go to launch an application
that requires the other context.

63
00:03:22.270 --> 00:03:24.169
Right.
The administrator.

64
00:03:24.169 --> 00:03:26.470
Somethings going to change.

65
00:03:26.470 --> 00:03:27.140
All right?

66
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:29.210
Now, what does that change gonna be?

67
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:32.320
That's a little technology that's
been inside of the windows,

68
00:03:32.320 --> 00:03:37.080
a little dialogue box that pops up and
it could potentially blocks somebody

69
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:41.320
from launching certain applications,
certainly installing applications and

70
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:45.030
making key security settings
changes if you will.

71
00:03:45.030 --> 00:03:46.340
Let me show you what I mean here.

72
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:47.710
I got a little diagram here.

73
00:03:47.710 --> 00:03:49.440
When we talk about the user account,

74
00:03:49.440 --> 00:03:52.850
remember that I told you there
are two different types of users and

75
00:03:52.850 --> 00:03:56.600
again they have different things
that they can do on the computer.

76
00:03:56.600 --> 00:04:01.240
Now any time somebody logs in they get
what's known as this little electronic

77
00:04:01.240 --> 00:04:04.200
piece of information called a token.

78
00:04:04.200 --> 00:04:06.650
And just understand that
that tells the computer,

79
00:04:06.650 --> 00:04:09.360
the system,
the context of who you're logging into.

80
00:04:09.360 --> 00:04:12.090
What I mean is are you logging
in as a standard user?

81
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:14.400
Or are you logging in as an administrator?

82
00:04:14.400 --> 00:04:18.870
Now, if you are a standard user and
you log in, you get the standard users,

83
00:04:18.870 --> 00:04:21.270
let's just call it a standard user badge,
right?

84
00:04:21.270 --> 00:04:25.110
And it let's you know that you
have restricted privileges.

85
00:04:25.110 --> 00:04:29.920
When you decide that you are going to
launch an application, a utility, or

86
00:04:29.920 --> 00:04:34.280
a setting,
that requires that administrative badge.

87
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:38.320
Well, that's where the user
account control comes in to play.

88
00:04:38.320 --> 00:04:42.990
You might see these little user account
control icons, these little four colored,

89
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:46.560
almost looks like the UNO colors,
there, in a shield.

90
00:04:46.560 --> 00:04:49.670
That's letting you know,
any time you see that icon,

91
00:04:49.670 --> 00:04:53.730
that you have to be an administrator
to perform whatever functionality

92
00:04:53.730 --> 00:04:56.610
that it is that application performs.

93
00:04:56.610 --> 00:04:59.890
What it's doing here is it's
actually protecting your account.

94
00:04:59.890 --> 00:05:04.200
It's saying, I'm not gonna let you do
those things unless you can prove to me

95
00:05:04.200 --> 00:05:05.660
that you're an administrator.

96
00:05:05.660 --> 00:05:08.080
Now, what if you already
are an administrator?

97
00:05:08.080 --> 00:05:12.040
Well this is kind of interesting,
to protect the operating system,

98
00:05:12.040 --> 00:05:14.340
you're also running as a standard user.

99
00:05:14.340 --> 00:05:18.300
But the cool thing is, you have two badges
you don't just have one badge that says

100
00:05:18.300 --> 00:05:21.910
hey I'm a standard user or in this
case you're an administrator, you have

101
00:05:21.910 --> 00:05:26.700
a standard user badge and you also have
an administrator badge, all right?

102
00:05:26.700 --> 00:05:30.730
And this is kinda like showing your,
maybe you've got a security card,

103
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:33.625
the security clearance and
you say well here's what it says I am,

104
00:05:33.625 --> 00:05:38.050
I am West Bryan here but
my security card gets me through the door.

105
00:05:38.050 --> 00:05:42.260
Well, what happens is your operating
system looks at that administrator badge,

106
00:05:42.260 --> 00:05:43.190
in this case a token.

107
00:05:43.190 --> 00:05:46.330
And says okay, we could see
that you are the administrator.

108
00:05:46.330 --> 00:05:50.230
So what you have to do when this
little dialogue that's gonna pop up

109
00:05:50.230 --> 00:05:55.110
is you have to press, yes to continue
the operation or no to cancel it.

110
00:05:55.110 --> 00:05:57.900
All right, if you're a standard user,
and that's all you are, right,

111
00:05:57.900 --> 00:06:00.320
you're not wearing both badges,
like administrator.

112
00:06:00.320 --> 00:06:04.770
You're a standard user, you don't get
the yes to continue the operation,

113
00:06:04.770 --> 00:06:06.540
you still get the no for sure.

114
00:06:06.540 --> 00:06:11.940
But what you get is a username and
password dialog box, and what it's saying

115
00:06:11.940 --> 00:06:17.220
is, prove to me that you know

Maybe I don't like the fact that
Ronnie's made me a standard user and

343
00:18:02.300 --> 00:18:04.670
I want to be able to install what I want,
right?

344
00:18:04.670 --> 00:18:06.100
Well, let's see if we can change that.

345
00:18:06.100 --> 00:18:08.760
I'll go ahead and I'll click that,
and notice what we get,

346
00:18:08.760 --> 00:18:10.160
notice the option that we get.

347
00:18:11.160 --> 00:18:13.820
It's telling me,
type an administrator password.

348
00:18:13.820 --> 00:18:19.107
Remember the account that I was logged
in as was an administrative account.

349
00:18:19.107 --> 00:18:22.872
So what it's saying is, no,
you don't have these privileges but

350
00:18:22.872 --> 00:18:26.920
you need to type in a password of
a user that does have those privileges.

351
00:18:26.920 --> 00:18:28.940
So that's the User Account Control.

352
00:18:28.940 --> 00:18:31.970
And it is, just like Ronnie's saying,
it's protecting your computer from

353
00:18:31.970 --> 00:18:36.670
running things you otherwise wouldn't
even know are on your computer.

354
00:18:36.670 --> 00:18:39.260
So let me go ahead,
I'll do a switch user this time,

355
00:18:39.260 --> 00:18:42.990
make it a little bit faster, and
I'll log back in as our Administrator.

356
00:18:42.990 --> 00:18:46.470
And we'll see if there's a difference
in the user experience that

357
00:18:46.470 --> 00:18:50.680
an administrator has versus the standard
user when they got locked out there

358
00:18:50.680 --> 00:18:52.350
by that User Account Control.

359
00:18:52.350 --> 00:18:57.050
We're going to the same place again guys,
no different, Start > Control Panel.

360
00:18:57.050 --> 00:19:00.490
Once Control Panel launches,
upper right hand corner,

361
00:19:00.490 --> 00:19:04.512
we're going to User Accounts and
Family Safety > User Accounts.

362
00:19:04.512 --> 00:19:08.533
And then we're gonna change
User Account Control settings.

363
00:19:08.533 --> 00:19:11.320
Now, as an administrator,
when I decide that hey,

364
00:19:11.320 --> 00:19:15.490
I wanna change these settings,
I get the User Account dialog box, right?

365
00:19:15.490 --> 00:19:19.390
Notice that it didn't warn me,
right, didn't do anything.

366
00:19:19.390 --> 00:19:23.080
Now I will tell you that if you
install software as an administrator,

367
00:19:23.080 --> 00:19:26.170
you will trigger the User Account Control.

368
00:19:26.170 --> 00:19:30.810
But you notice that how we did that before
as a standard user it gave the yes and no?

369
00:19:30.810 --> 00:19:34.274
The difference would be is that
the password dialog box is not there.

370
00:19:34.274 --> 00:19:37.130
It isn't there and
we could just click Yes.

371
00:19:37.130 --> 00:19:38.980
All right, so we've got a couple of,

372
00:19:38.980 --> 00:19:41.440
that's the difference
between the user accounts.

373
00:19:41.440 --> 00:19:45.290
Couple other things that you might
have to set up occasionally,

374
00:19:45.290 --> 00:19:47.910
you might have to adjust the date and
time.

375
00:19:47.910 --> 00:19:51.050
Now I know my head's kinda
covering up this over here but

376
00:19:51.050 --> 00:19:54.740
we kinda showed you that task link
earlier but we really didn't click on it.

377
00:19:54.740 --> 00:19:59.510
If I want to I can click this right there,
just click right on the date and

378
00:19:59.510 --> 00:20:04.058
time there and I can choose change
date and time setting hyperlink.

379
00:20:04.058 --> 00:20:07.556
And if we come up here towards the top,
we could see that we have the ability,

380
00:20:07.556 --> 00:20:10.550
if we want,
now notice something that's interesting.

381
00:20:10.550 --> 00:20:12.970
Standard users can't do this,
so keep that in mind.

382
00:20:12.970 --> 00:20:15.420
I could change the time
zone if I wanted to.

383
00:20:15.420 --> 00:20:18.780
I could change the date and time as well.

384
00:20:18.780 --> 00:20:20.910
Now we also have the ability,
if we need to,

385
00:20:20.910 --> 00:20:22.880
to change things like the keyboard layout.

386
00:20:22.880 --> 00:20:28.000
And the keyboard layout for me is the US,
if you will, keyboard layout.

387
00:20:28.000 --> 00:20:31.700
But if I go back to the Start menu and
I go to Control Panel,

388
00:20:31.700 --> 00:20:35.870
there's a lot of things that
you can do in Control Panel.

389
00:20:35.870 --> 00:20:38.420
We're gonna go to Clock,
Language, and Region.

390
00:20:40.460 --> 00:20:43.042
All right, and notice Date and
Time settings I can do here.

391
00:20:43.042 --> 00:20:45.190
So there's a lot of different
places that you can do those.

392
00:20:45.190 --> 00:20:49.520
Region and Language,
I have the ability to set Formats,

393
00:20:49.520 --> 00:20:52.850
Location, I could set the keyboard
arrangement if I want.

394
00:20:52.850 --> 00:20:55.610
So it is another good way to customize it.

395
00:20:55.610 --> 00:20:58.220
I would say, Ronnie,
the final thing I'll show you is how

396
00:20:58.220 --> 00:21:01.775
to do a little bit of personalization of
the theme that you have in Windows 7.

397
00:21:01.775 --> 00:21:04.670
It's a collection of visual settings here.

398
00:21:04.670 --> 00:21:07.770
Nice way to change this is just
to right-click on the desktop,

399
00:21:07.770 --> 00:21:09.130
choose Personalize.

400
00:21:10.630 --> 00:21:14.790
And you'll see that you the ability,
if you want, to change the themes.

401
00:21:14.790 --> 00:21:20.620
If I change the theme it's gonna
change a lot of the banners,

402
00:21:20.620 --> 00:21:23.560
if you will, around the different
interfaces if we want.

403
00:21:23.560 --> 00:21:28.210
We can also change the desktop icons and I
can also change the mouse pointer as well.

404
00:21:28.210 --> 00:21:32.020
You notice I just got this basic mouse,
or cursor here.

405
00:21:32.020 --> 00:21:36.440
If I decided to, we could change
the cursor, we can change the button.

406
00:21:36.440 --> 00:21:39.250
So a little bit more
customization that you can do,

407
00:21:39.250 --> 00:21:43.100
some of the pointer options if you want to
increase the speed or slow the speed down.

408
00:21:43.100 --> 00:21:47.300
So you do have the ability to fully
customize the user experience,

409
00:21:47.300 --> 00:21:48.801
the user environment.

410
00:21:48.801 --> 00:21:53.264
And also pay attention to the types
of user accounts that you might be

411
00:21:53.264 --> 00:21:54.292
logging into.

412
00:21:54.292 --> 00:21:58.612
Cuz it could restrict your ability
to do certain functions inside of

413
00:21:58.612 --> 00:22:00.136
the operating system.

414
00:22:00.136 --> 00:22:03.478
>> There's no doubt that the majority
of the features that we've seen here

415
00:22:03.478 --> 00:22:04.847
are really gonna be helpful,

416
00:22:04.847 --> 00:22:08.170
especially if you're working
inside of a business setting.

417
00:22:08.170 --> 00:22:12.020
There are some personalized home settings
that are also available out there

418
00:22:12.020 --> 00:22:12.650
for us too.

419
00:22:12.650 --> 00:22:16.320
What they call the parental
safety types of settings as well,

420
00:22:16.320 --> 00:22:19.120
that allow you to control other
accounts that you create.

421
00:22:19.120 --> 00:22:21.980
And you can limit them by
several different things.

422
00:22:21.980 --> 00:22:23.680
One, of course, is a time limit.

423
00:22:23.680 --> 00:22:26.850
You have a child on your machine,
you can also say look,

424
00:22:26.850 --> 00:22:28.870
I don't want them spending all day.

425
00:22:28.870 --> 00:22:32.040
You can limit the amount of time that
they can gain access through that

426
00:22:32.040 --> 00:22:32.888
Windows 7 machine.

427
00:22:32.888 --> 00:22:35.720
If they are playing video games,

428
00:22:35.720 --> 00:22:39.900
you also have the ability through
a voluntarily rating system to say,

429
00:22:39.900 --> 00:22:44.200
I don't want these ratings or
above to be allowed there as well.

430
00:22:44.200 --> 00:22:48.493
And then of course, they actually
do have a little bit more filtering

431
00:22:48.493 --> 00:22:52.946
that you can do by content that is
also available to you right there too.

432
00:22:52.946 --> 00:22:56.726
And all that is just to help you
out in the home setting as well.

433
00:22:56.726 --> 00:23:00.030
So we wanna mention those but
a lot of times those configurations don't

434
00:23:00.030 --> 00:23:02.080
necessarily need to go
through all of them.

435
00:23:02.080 --> 00:23:06.240
Because, well, those are there for
you to try to explore and take a look at.

436
00:23:06.240 --> 00:23:10.020
But just realize that they are there for
you, no need to buy a third party set,

437
00:23:10.020 --> 00:23:13.740
at least that's what Microsoft would say,
unless you really want to.

438
00:23:13.740 --> 00:23:17.310
But just kinda realize that there's a lot
of customization, a lot of configuration

439
00:23:17.310 --> 00:23:23.190
for an end user who is just getting used
to working with the computer to deal with.

440
00:23:23.190 --> 00:23:26.430
But probably by far the most challenging
one, if you start off, right,

441
00:23:26.430 --> 00:23:30.270
is understanding that you need to make
sure you have your own user account, okay?

442
00:23:30.270 --> 00:23:33.850
And you need to understand why you're not
gonna be able to launch certain programs,

443
00:23:33.850 --> 00:23:37.650
and that might be because you are a
standard user versus the administrative

444
00:23:37.650 --> 00:23:38.820
user as well.

445
00:23:38.820 --> 00:23:40.780
But keeping those things separated out,

446
00:23:40.780 --> 00:23:44.200
especially in the work environment,
is gonna be very helpful for you.

447
00:23:44.200 --> 00:23:46.760
And hopefully will also help protect you,
as well.

448
00:23:46.760 --> 00:23:49.910
So that actually is a lot of information,
Wes,

449
00:23:49.910 --> 00:23:53.800
that we have available right there for
the user to actually deal with.

450
00:23:53.800 --> 00:23:58.936
>> That's right, when it comes down to it,
password protect your operating systems.

451
00:23:58.936 --> 00:24:03.600
Remember that it is PC, it is a personal
computer, personal computing experience,

452
00:24:03.600 --> 00:24:06.475
make sure you configure it
according to your needs.

453
00:24:06.475 --> 00:24:08.905
And then also, if you happen
gonna be supporting an end user,

454
00:24:08.905 --> 00:24:10.185
listen to their needs, right.

455
00:24:10.185 --> 00:24:12.952
If you configure your
computer at a certain way,

456
00:24:12.952 --> 00:24:15.726
that might not be the way
somebody else wants it.

457
00:24:15.726 --> 00:24:19.312
There's no right way or wrong way,
customize it, get in there,

458
00:24:19.312 --> 00:24:23.767
work with the settings and make sure that
you have the best experience possible.

459
00:24:23.767 --> 00:24:25.377
And then if you're supporting somebody,

460
00:24:25.377 --> 00:24:28.620
that you help to make their experience
the best it can be as well.

461
00:24:28.620 --> 00:24:29.290
>> All right, Wes.

462
00:24:29.290 --> 00:24:32.890
Well, thank you again for helping us to
understand at least the basics in terms of

463
00:24:32.890 --> 00:24:37.110
the Windows 7 interface that we're gonna
be encountering on a day-to-day basis.

464
00:24:37.110 --> 00:24:39.070
And also thank you for watching.

465
00:24:39.070 --> 00:24:40.900
Great place for us to sign off.

466
00:24:40.900 --> 00:24:43.580
So for ITProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

467
00:24:43.580 --> 00:24:44.710
>> And I'm West Bryan.

468
00:24:44.710 --> 00:24:48.012
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

469
00:24:48.012 --> 00:24:55.471
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wed take a look at file management.  The smallest amount of data that users store is called a file, regardless of the size or type of data, they tell us.  With this as a basic understanding, the user must understand that to work with files, we must understand the path (location of the data) on a hard drive and the idea of moving, copying and storing and creating files, they discuss.  They also point out the concept of using storage devices to house data files, must begin with file systems and even additional attributes that can configured on files.
episodes.title: File Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:11.983 --> 00:00:15.230
Welcome to the another great
episode right here in ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.230 --> 00:00:16.790
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:16.790 --> 00:00:19.310
you're watching
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals show.

5
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:23.580
Where we're about to take look in
to the realm of file management.

6
00:00:23.580 --> 00:00:26.710
Now, when it comes down to the idea
of using data onto your computer,

7
00:00:26.710 --> 00:00:30.270
you're going to realize that they do
have to be managed at some point.

8
00:00:30.270 --> 00:00:32.650
And we need to actually
understand the basics of that.

9
00:00:32.650 --> 00:00:35.930
And who better to help us to
do that than Mister Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:35.930 --> 00:00:37.250
Wes, welcome back to our studios.

11
00:00:37.250 --> 00:00:38.420
>> Thanks, Ronnie for having me here.

12
00:00:38.420 --> 00:00:39.750
That's right.
It's great to be with

13
00:00:39.750 --> 00:00:41.340
here with the ITProTV crew.

14
00:00:41.340 --> 00:00:44.260
We're going to dive right in here and,
just like Ronnie said,

15
00:00:44.260 --> 00:00:46.850
we are gonna be looking
at file management.

16
00:00:46.850 --> 00:00:49.551
The first thing that I wanna do is,
I wanna talk a little bit about

17
00:00:49.551 --> 00:00:52.570
the interface that you're gonna use
to manage your folders and files.

18
00:00:52.570 --> 00:00:55.109
We're gonna kinda group
both of these together,

19
00:00:55.109 --> 00:00:56.990
even though we say file management.

20
00:00:56.990 --> 00:00:59.552
Again, we're also gonna talk
a little bit about folders or

21
00:00:59.552 --> 00:01:02.176
maybe some of you have heard
the term directories out there.

22
00:01:02.176 --> 00:01:03.260
So we need to look at that.

23
00:01:03.260 --> 00:01:07.676
But we also need to talk about what is the
interface that's gonna be used to view and

24
00:01:07.676 --> 00:01:09.470
manage these files and folders.

25
00:01:09.470 --> 00:01:12.746
So that as we go through this
demonstration describing what a file and

26
00:01:12.746 --> 00:01:15.350
folder is,
you'll know that interface pretty well.

27
00:01:15.350 --> 00:01:16.951
And what interface are we talking about?

28
00:01:16.951 --> 00:01:19.800
Well, we're talking about one that's
been around for a little while now.

29
00:01:19.800 --> 00:01:21.340
And it's called Windows Explorer.

30
00:01:21.340 --> 00:01:24.130
Maybe some of you guys have a newer
operating system, like Windows 7.

31
00:01:24.130 --> 00:01:26.060
You might know it as File Explorer.

32
00:01:26.060 --> 00:01:27.593
Understand guys, it's just a name change.

33
00:01:27.593 --> 00:01:31.996
What we're talking about is the primary
graphical user interface that allows you

34
00:01:31.996 --> 00:01:33.920
to manage those files and folders.

35
00:01:33.920 --> 00:01:35.250
Let's go ahead and dive right in here.

36
00:01:35.250 --> 00:01:38.725
I've got a Windows 7 machine here up
on our screen there, Mister Ronnie.

37
00:01:38.725 --> 00:01:41.769
And we're gonna launch
this little folder icon,

38
00:01:41.769 --> 00:01:45.547
down there at the bottom of our,
we talked about our task bar.

39
00:01:45.547 --> 00:01:49.370
And one of the default icons
is your Windows Explorer.

40
00:01:49.370 --> 00:01:52.718
Now when we look at Windows Explorer,
you'll see that there's all these

41
00:01:52.718 --> 00:01:54.938
different boxes here,
on the left-hand side.

42
00:01:54.938 --> 00:01:58.490
You have what's known as
the tree hierarchy, if you will.

43
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:02.600
The context pane is on
the right-hand side.

44
00:02:02.600 --> 00:02:04.640
Excuse me a minute,
make sure I get that right.

45
00:02:04.640 --> 00:02:07.050
And notice that we have all
these different locations.

46
00:02:07.050 --> 00:02:08.160
Kinda zoom in here.

47
00:02:08.160 --> 00:02:12.460
Well, this is what's known as a file
hierarchy or a directory hierarchy.

48
00:02:12.460 --> 00:02:17.040
And if I happen to open one
of these locations up, well,

49
00:02:17.040 --> 00:02:21.090
you're gonna see that there
are a series of folders here.

50
00:02:21.090 --> 00:02:24.079
If I happen to, let's say,
maybe get to the desktop.

51
00:02:26.410 --> 00:02:31.033
Well, I can create this little,
we'll just call it an icon for now,

52
00:02:31.033 --> 00:02:33.121
I can create this little icon.

53
00:02:33.121 --> 00:02:35.410
We'll call it Test.doc, if you will.

54
00:02:35.410 --> 00:02:37.879
So notice, oop, or I'll say dco.

55
00:02:37.879 --> 00:02:39.905
If you can help me out there
with my spelling on doc,

56
00:02:39.905 --> 00:02:41.381
that would be great there, Ronnie.

57
00:02:41.381 --> 00:02:44.575
[LAUGH] I'll go ahead and
rename that to what it's supposed to be.

58
00:02:44.575 --> 00:02:48.707
So you can see that even though,
when we talk about managing files and

59
00:02:48.707 --> 00:02:52.781
folders we talk about it being
the Windows Explorer that we do this.

60
00:02:52.781 --> 00:02:56.170
Understand that you can also
do this to the desktop.

61
00:02:56.170 --> 00:02:59.550
Now, that being said, we'll look
a little bit more into Windows Explorer,

62
00:02:59.550 --> 00:03:00.990
coming up, as we work through this.

63
00:03:00.990 --> 00:03:04.379
Because we wanna talk about,
basically, what is a file?

64
00:03:04.379 --> 00:03:06.310
Why do we even need a file?

65
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:09.560
Well, a file is really nothing more
than an object within your computer that

66
00:03:09.560 --> 00:03:10.700
stores data.

67
00:03:10.700 --> 00:03:13.490
Now when we say storing data,
it can store different types of data.

68
00:03:13.490 --> 00:03:17.690
It doesn't necessarily have to be
a file that just contains textual

69
00:03:17.690 --> 00:03:19.540
information that we're gonna read.

70
00:03:19.540 --> 00:03:24.000
It could contain textual information that
the operating system needs to read as

71
00:03:24.000 --> 00:03:25.530
part of it's functionality.

72
00:03:25.530 --> 00:03:30.240
It could be a video file, if you will,
that contains some kind of graphical data.

73
00:03:30.240 --> 00:03:34.630
But one of the things that we wanna make
sure is that we really do understand

74
00:03:34.630 --> 00:03:38.160
the file itself and
how we apply it to our storage.

75
00:03:38.160 --> 00:03:39.920
If you remember,
we were talking about our storage.

76
00:03:39.920 --> 00:03:42.871
And one of the things that we had
mentioned in our storage episode

77
00:03:42.871 --> 00:03:46.761
was a little bit about partitioning and
formatting with file systems, if you will.

78
00:03:46.761 --> 00:03:48.025
And then, finally,

79
00:03:48.025 --> 00:03:52.247
using that storage once we had everything
set up the way we wanted to go.

80
00:03:52.247 --> 00:03:55.820
We'll talk a little briefly here
about what a folder is, as well.

81
00:03:55.820 --> 00:03:59.720
If a file contains an object that
contains data, what is a folder?

82
00:03:59.720 --> 00:04:01.738
Well, a folder can contain data, as well.

83
00:04:01.738 --> 00:04:06.399
But typically what it does is it's used to
group your data together based on however

84
00:04:06.399 --> 00:04:08.010
it is that you wanna find it.

85
00:04:08.010 --> 00:04:10.890
Makes it easier to find your data
when you can group it together in

86
00:04:10.890 --> 00:04:12.150
a single location.

87
00:04:12.150 --> 00:04:13.590
And that's essentially what a folder is.

88
00:04:13.590 --> 00:04:17.160
A folder is really an object
that stores multiple files,

89
00:04:17.160 --> 00:04:19.830
and even other folders, too.

90
00:04:19.830 --> 00:04:23.980
Now let me show you this real quick here
in our interface, as we continue through.

91
00:04:23.980 --> 00:04:26.806
I can also make a folder on the desktop,
as well.

92
00:04:26.806 --> 00:04:30.549
And we'll just call this, again, Test,
because I'm very creative here for

93
00:04:30.549 --> 00:04:31.790
sure today.

94
00:04:31.790 --> 00:04:34.550
Notice that I have this icon,
this pretty little icon.

95
