And that's what I also got to figure.

543
00:27:56.690 --> 00:28:01.175
Notice that it says I'm gonna uncheck that
Hide protected operating system files.

544
00:28:01.175 --> 00:28:04.504
And notice this Show hidden files,
folders, and drives.

545
00:28:04.504 --> 00:28:08.443
I'm gonna go ahead and uncheck that,
change the radio button, I should say.

546
00:28:08.443 --> 00:28:10.570
We'll apply that, we'll say OK.

547
00:28:10.570 --> 00:28:15.380
And now I want you to notice that there
are more files on my desktop than what

548
00:28:15.380 --> 00:28:17.600
has been shown by default.

549
00:28:17.600 --> 00:28:20.830
We have some configuration files,
remember I told you system files?

550
00:28:20.830 --> 00:28:22.870
Well, here's an INI file, all right?

551
00:28:22.870 --> 00:28:25.110
Here's one of those INI files
that we were talking about.

552
00:28:25.110 --> 00:28:27.170
And Windows says,
let's keep this out of view here,

553
00:28:27.170 --> 00:28:28.700
because you don't need
to mess with this file.

554
00:28:28.700 --> 00:28:29.690
What does it contain?

555
00:28:29.690 --> 00:28:32.030
I'm not even gonna open it,
but just trust me on this one.

556
00:28:32.030 --> 00:28:35.950
It contains the current settings,
my background settings, my theme settings,

557
00:28:35.950 --> 00:28:39.610
what icons I have on my desktop,
how I have the taskbar arranged.

558
00:28:39.610 --> 00:28:41.110
And it saves that for me so

559
00:28:41.110 --> 00:28:45.180
that the next time I log into
the computer, that whole environment is

560
00:28:45.180 --> 00:28:49.370
configured the way I configured it
prior to logging out of the machine.

561
00:28:49.370 --> 00:28:53.910
So that's a couple things there, Ronnie,
I think the last thing I do wanna mention,

562
00:28:53.910 --> 00:28:56.730
I know we're running on time,
is file sharing.

563
00:28:56.730 --> 00:29:01.550
When it comes to file sharing, keep in
mind that file sharing is a way that if

564
00:29:01.550 --> 00:29:06.630
somebody is on another computer,
they can connect over a network connection

565
00:29:06.630 --> 00:29:11.880
back into your computer, and
they can look at those files.

566
00:29:11.880 --> 00:29:14.600
Typically, we do this by
creating a shared folder.

567
00:29:14.600 --> 00:29:18.470
And inside of that folder, remember we're
grouping those file objects together.

568
00:29:18.470 --> 00:29:21.430
When I share that folder out,
it now becomes available to

569
00:29:21.430 --> 00:29:24.240
other people on the network so
that they can connect to it.

570
00:29:24.240 --> 00:29:26.710
And they can share that resource as well.

571
00:29:26.710 --> 00:29:27.405
>> A lot of times,

572
00:29:27.405 --> 00:29:30.435
the idea of the file system is not
limited to just hard drives then.

573
00:29:30.435 --> 00:29:32.800
What we also have to
realize in today's world,

574
00:29:32.800 --> 00:29:37.313
especially when we are working in a
computer network at a business somewhere.

575
00:29:37.313 --> 00:29:41.995
Even though we might be able to transfer
files using things like the flash drive as

576
00:29:41.995 --> 00:29:45.825
well, and
even larger external types of drives.

577
00:29:45.825 --> 00:29:48.595
The overall nature though,
inside a business system,

578
00:29:48.595 --> 00:29:52.555
is probably going to be that type of file
sharing that Wes was just mentioning.

579
00:29:52.555 --> 00:29:56.018
The idea here is fairly simple, is that
it will be all stored in a location.

580
00:29:56.018 --> 00:30:00.349
And then everybody can gain access to it
without us having to actually pass around

581
00:30:00.349 --> 00:30:01.870
media at some point.

582
00:30:01.870 --> 00:30:06.450
And that way we can control a single,
centralized storage share instead, and

583
00:30:06.450 --> 00:30:08.460
actually have all those
features available.

584
00:30:08.460 --> 00:30:11.900
Well, that's a great place for
us to also end this episode then.

585
00:30:11.900 --> 00:30:15.460
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

586
00:30:15.460 --> 00:30:16.480
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

587
00:30:16.480 --> 00:30:19.520
>> Stay tuned right here for
more IC3 Computing Fundamentals.

588
00:30:19.520 --> 00:30:29.310
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes introduce the basic networking concepts.  They classify networks by geography, types and access technologies.  They uses the terminology that users are likely to encounter when talking about the most generic network geography:  LAN, WAN and PAN.  Briefly they describe how devices must be uniquely identified if they are to communicate on a network.  Lastly, they describe some of the access methods that are used such as Wireless and wired as well as how to access the internet.  They also talk about the use of terms like SLAs too.
episodes.title: Networking
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.208 --> 00:00:15.630
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.630 --> 00:00:17.210
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

4
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:20.620
you're watching
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals show.

5
00:00:20.620 --> 00:00:24.420
Where we are about to jump into
the world of networking and

6
00:00:24.420 --> 00:00:25.880
the introduction to that.

7
00:00:25.880 --> 00:00:29.110
Just enough to get us comfortable in
understanding the environment that

8
00:00:29.110 --> 00:00:31.650
we'll generally be working
in with computing.

9
00:00:31.650 --> 00:00:33.580
And who better to help us than Mr.
Wes Bryan?

10
00:00:33.580 --> 00:00:34.730
Wes, welcome back to our show.

11
00:00:34.730 --> 00:00:36.320
>> Thanks for having me here, Ronnie.

12
00:00:36.320 --> 00:00:38.400
It's great to be with the ITProTV crew.

13
00:00:38.400 --> 00:00:40.560
That's right,
we're diving into the world of networking.

14
00:00:40.560 --> 00:00:42.910
And one of the reasons really,

15
00:00:42.910 --> 00:00:45.850
we're in a computing environment
in general anymore today.

16
00:00:45.850 --> 00:00:48.363
Maybe in the earlier days,
you would've been connected to a network.

17
00:00:48.363 --> 00:00:53.344
But it's almost unrealistic to think
that your computers today at some point,

18
00:00:53.344 --> 00:00:56.110
aren't going to be connected to a network.

19
00:00:56.110 --> 00:00:59.391
So that's why it's important to understand
even some of the basics when it comes

20
00:00:59.391 --> 00:00:59.979
to networks.

21
00:00:59.979 --> 00:01:02.340
And so, let's go ahead and
start right there.

22
00:01:02.340 --> 00:01:05.890
Why is it that we would even
wanna have a network at all?

23
00:01:05.890 --> 00:01:07.450
Well, I want you to think of it as base.

24
00:01:07.450 --> 00:01:10.899
On a very basic level it's
about sharing resources.

25
00:01:10.899 --> 00:01:12.960
So I'm not sharing anything with anybody.

26
00:01:12.960 --> 00:01:14.130
I don't believe in file sharing.

27
00:01:14.130 --> 00:01:16.280
Well, that's not really
what we're talking about.

28
00:01:16.280 --> 00:01:20.130
When you make a connection out
there to the good old Internet and

29
00:01:20.130 --> 00:01:23.550
you, maybe view, maybe Facebook or
something like that.

30
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:25.300
Maybe you check your emails.

31
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:27.120
That's all information and guess what?

32
00:01:27.120 --> 00:01:30.270
You're connecting to somebody else's
network in order to get access to that

33
00:01:30.270 --> 00:01:31.220
information.

34
00:01:31.220 --> 00:01:34.993
And even let's just take the Internet and
just leave it alone for now.

35
00:01:34.993 --> 00:01:38.847
Let's just talk about inside
of our home networks, right.

36
00:01:38.847 --> 00:01:40.310
We've got a little diagram here.

37
00:01:40.310 --> 00:01:43.030
We're going to explain what
this means at the top.

38
00:01:43.030 --> 00:01:46.220
This local area network
that I'm talking about.

39
00:01:46.220 --> 00:01:48.660
All right, let's just take
an average home network, right.

40
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:50.800
You guys, maybe you've seen this,
maybe you haven't.

41
00:01:50.800 --> 00:01:53.741
But a lot of times in just
a home network right,

42
00:01:53.741 --> 00:01:56.120
you're gonna have maybe a desktop, laptop.

43
00:01:56.120 --> 00:01:57.860
We're gonna have our mobile phone, right.

44
00:01:57.860 --> 00:02:02.650
We might have some gaming consoles there
and today we've got the smart TVs right.

45
00:02:02.650 --> 00:02:06.082
Well, all of those things
are communicating together and

46
00:02:06.082 --> 00:02:09.032
if we don't see it on the surface,
that's okay.

47
00:02:09.032 --> 00:02:12.620
But understand under the hood, we open
up that hood and look at the engine.

48
00:02:12.620 --> 00:02:15.720
They are all communicating
either if not with one another,

49
00:02:15.720 --> 00:02:19.998
they're at least communicating with a
single device that allows them to do that,

50
00:02:19.998 --> 00:02:21.860
so it's important to understand.

51
00:02:21.860 --> 00:02:25.690
That's one of the main reasons
when it comes down to it,

52
00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:27.760
that we wanna know about
networking in general,

53
00:02:27.760 --> 00:02:32.100
is just that sharing resources and
the communication between devices.

54
00:02:32.100 --> 00:02:35.040
>> There's no doubt that networking is
one of these concepts that you have to

55
00:02:35.040 --> 00:02:36.540
at least understand.

56
00:02:36.540 --> 00:02:38.610
And even though in a work environment,

57
00:02:38.610 --> 00:02:43.790
you may not see all of the details
behind networking, more than likely,

58
00:02:43.790 --> 00:02:47.690
you are going to be part of a network
when you're sitting down at a computer.

59
00:02:47.690 --> 00:02:49.370
And even though you might
be thinking right now,

60
00:02:49.370 --> 00:02:52.120
this is your first forray
into working with computers.

61
00:02:52.120 --> 00:02:54.170
Why do I really need this?

62
00:02:54.170 --> 00:02:58.634
It is about getting access to resources
that are beyond what your computer

63
00:02:58.634 --> 00:03:02.964
can have access to at any one point
in time, if you're isolated alone.

64
00:03:02.964 --> 00:03:05.610
And so we need to understand
at least the fundamentals.

65
00:03:05.610 --> 00:03:08.950
So when we start talking about this
idea of the fundamentals then,

66
00:03:08.950 --> 00:03:12.950
let's go ahead and break it down
a little bit farther for us, Wes.

67
00:03:12.950 --> 00:03:15.900
>> What is really the difference then,
between my home

68
00:03:15.900 --> 00:03:19.525
network that you were just showing and
let's say a working business network then?

69
00:03:19.525 --> 00:03:20.495
>> That's a great question.

70
00:03:20.495 --> 00:03:23.055
Absolutely, so
if we look at a home network,

71
00:03:23.055 --> 00:03:26.035
a home network is typically
a very small network.

72
00:03:26.035 --> 00:03:29.195
Now, if you're one of these people
that live in the life of luxury.

73
00:03:29.195 --> 00:03:33.787
Maybe you do happen to have a huge
home network but for the most part,

74
00:03:33.787 --> 00:03:38.862
it is a self contained environment,
if you will, that is, a lot of times,

75
00:03:38.862 --> 00:03:43.070
most often, it's restricted
to a single location, right.

76
00:03:43.070 --> 00:03:46.600
And when we talk about that
single location, a lot of times,

77
00:03:46.600 --> 00:03:49.360
what we have is that you
are in control of it.

78
00:03:49.360 --> 00:03:51.210
You have just a handful of devices and

79
00:03:51.210 --> 00:03:53.890
those devices communicate
amongst each other.

80
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:57.910
Versus something like a corporate,
network, which could be a series of

81
00:03:57.910 --> 00:04:02.450
networks alttogether,
communicating together with these.

82
00:04:02.450 --> 00:04:06.300
We've talked about servers in the past,
providing resources and

83
00:04:06.300 --> 00:04:07.580
we've got these big computers.

84
00:04:07.580 --> 00:04:11.450
Again, I call them servers but just
understand, they're just big computers and

85
00:04:11.450 --> 00:04:12.690
they're providing resources.

86
00:04:12.690 --> 00:04:16.430
Well, that communication leads
to things like productivity,

87
00:04:16.430 --> 00:04:21.320
leads to things like us having
the ability to get our job done.

88
00:04:21.320 --> 00:04:25.270
But one of the big differences when it
comes to a home network versus a corporate

89
00:04:25.270 --> 00:04:27.860
network is,
what we call scalability, right.

90
00:04:27.860 --> 00:04:29.770
In a home network,
they're relatively small.

91
00:04:29.770 --> 00:04:32.540
Like I said,
even if you have a 15-room mansion,

92
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:35.420
you're talking about
a relatively small network.

93
00:04:35.420 --> 00:04:36.920
When you look at a work environment,

94
00:04:36.920 --> 00:04:39.910
a corporate environment,
these networks can scale up.

95
00:04:39.910 --> 00:04:44.010
And when I say scale up, I'm not just
talking about ten computers, right, Max.

96
00:04:44.010 --> 00:04:48.440
I'm talking about beyond that,
maybe even up to the thousands, right and

97
00:04:48.440 --> 00:04:52.910
they usually cost a pretty penny,
if you will.

98
00:04:52.910 --> 00:04:55.060
Pardon the pun here,
if you're not in the States,

99
00:04:55.060 --> 00:04:57.470
but they cost a lot of money to maintain.

100
00:04:57.470 --> 00:05:01.560
And you typically have dedicated
teams that manage these networks,

101
00:05:01.560 --> 00:05:03.590
versus your home network.

102
00:05:03.590 --> 00:05:07.110
Unless you're paying somebody else to
do it, like a technician to come in and

103
00:05:07.110 --> 00:05:10.590
help you, for the most part,
you're in control of your network.

104
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:12.210
You're the one that's
going to be servicing it.

105
00:05:12.210 --> 00:05:15.360
You're gonna be the one that has to
pay for things to get fixed, and

106
00:05:15.360 --> 00:05:19.830
again, it's just one of the things is
about scale more than anything else.

107
00:05:19.830 --> 00:05:22.360
Now that being said,
I do wanna talk about,

108
00:05:22.360 --> 00:05:25.850
I mentioned just briefly
the geographical regions, right.

109
00:05:25.850 --> 00:05:29.450
And I mentioned something known,
as if we go back to the slide here,

110
00:05:29.450 --> 00:05:32.010
I talked about a local area network.

111
00:05:32.010 --> 00:05:33.820
Maybe you've never heard this term before.

112
00:05:33.820 --> 00:05:35.250
Let's call it LAN right?

113
00:05:35.250 --> 00:05:39.050
A local area network is one
that is self-contained and

114
00:05:39.050 --> 00:05:40.910
it's a private network right?

115
00:05:40.910 --> 00:05:44.120
And it's just a single
geographical location.

116
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:47.800
When I say that it could a home network,
it could be a building right?

117
00:05:47.800 --> 00:05:49.160
Even corporate networks right?

118
00:05:49.160 --> 00:05:52.890
So this doesn't lend itself to just
corporate networks or just home networks.

119
00:05:52.890 --> 00:05:56.420
Understand that it's an isolated
network that's self-contained and

120
00:05:56.420 --> 00:05:58.340
it's in a single location.

121
00:05:58.340 --> 00:06:00.460
Now, the location in this
case could be a building.

122
00:06:00.460 --> 00:06:01.550
You could have a couple of floors.

123
00:06:01.550 --> 00:06:03.470
It could be the whole
building the company owns.

124
00:06:03.470 --> 00:06:05.100
It could be a house if you will.

125
00:06:05.100 --> 00:06:06.930
That's what's known as
a local area network.

126
00:06:06.930 --> 00:06:09.814
However, when you start taking
some of these networks here,

127
00:06:09.814 --> 00:06:12.208
let me get out here and
find out what I did with that.

128
00:06:12.208 --> 00:06:16.570
There we go, there's one, and
you start taking multitudes.

129
00:06:16.570 --> 00:06:22.030
Let's say that these houses here,
are each their own individual network.

130
00:06:22.030 --> 00:06:26.180
And their different Internet service
providers, that's what an ISP is.

131
00:06:26.180 --> 00:06:29.067
An Internet service provider's what
provides you your Internet connection,

132
00:06:29.067 --> 00:06:30.584
we'll come back to that in a second here.

133
00:06:30.584 --> 00:06:34.770
But notice, that we have all of these
little networks scattered all over.

134
00:06:34.770 --> 00:06:36.665
Let's say,
they can be all over United States.

135
00:06:36.665 --> 00:06:38.840
They could be across the world, right.

136
00:06:38.840 --> 00:06:43.834
Well, they're essentially a bunch of local
area networks inter-networked together

137
00:06:43.834 --> 00:06:47.216
that make a larger network that
we call a wide area network.

138
00:06:47.216 --> 00:06:51.257
And a wide area network by definition,
in opposite to a LAN,

139
00:06:51.257 --> 00:06:56.930
is one that is basically a group of LANs
that span multiple geographical locations.

140
00:06:56.930 --> 00:07:00.680
And when we think about geographical, it
doesn't have to be necessarily worldwide,

141
00:07:00.680 --> 00:07:02.890
so it doesn't have to be
that large of a scale.

142
00:07:02.890 --> 00:07:07.160
It could be the fact that maybe we've
got a network here in Gainesville.

143
00:07:07.160 --> 00:07:09.910
Maybe we've got a network
that's over in Atlanta.

144
00:07:09.910 --> 00:07:11.580
Maybe there's one out on California.

145
00:07:11.580 --> 00:07:14.505
Maybe somewhere in Los Angeles,
if you will, San Francisco.

146
00:07:14.505 --> 00:07:20.117
Well the collection of those two,
that larger perspective if you will,

147
00:07:20.117 --> 00:07:23.100
is what makes a wide area network.

148
00:07:23.100 --> 00:07:26.410
For the average home user and
somebody just getting into computers,

149
00:07:26.410 --> 00:07:30.366
you probably will never see one of these
unless you go onto more advanced studies.

150
00:07:30.366 --> 00:07:34.064
But for the most part, that's what
your ISP is allowing you to do,

151
00:07:34.064 --> 00:07:36.060
communicate with other networks.

152
00:07:36.060 --> 00:07:39.790
That if you back up and you look into
them like we're doing right here,

153
00:07:39.790 --> 00:07:43.910
you can see it's a larger network
spanning multiple geographical location.

154
00:07:43.910 --> 00:07:48.044
So that is a couple of the terms
that you might wanna be aware of,

155
00:07:48.044 --> 00:07:53.521
just in basic networking is, the local
area network versus the wide area network.

156
00:07:53.521 --> 00:07:57.229
>> Another one of these terms is what
we call personal area network as well.

157
00:07:57.229 --> 00:08:01.436
And usually, this is just a small realm of
devices that you're probably in control

158
00:08:01.436 --> 00:08:05.181
of and a lot of times even though you and
I don't think about it very often.

159
00:08:05.181 --> 00:08:09.103
But if you have a smartphone on you,
if you have a laptop on you,

160
00:08:09.103 --> 00:08:13.469
if you're working at home and
you really only have just a few devices,

161
00:08:13.469 --> 00:08:17.761
that is your personal local area
network that normally fits inside of

162
00:08:17.761 --> 00:08:21.120
the context of that local
area network as well.

163
00:08:21.120 --> 00:08:25.030
So those terms that we're really
talking about are all about the idea of

164
00:08:25.030 --> 00:08:29.290
geographical location with
those devices to one another.

165
00:08:29.290 --> 00:08:33.038
The smallest of course then would be
the personal area network verses the local

166
00:08:33.038 --> 00:08:36.953
area network, which is all in one location
but probably in the span of a building or

167
00:08:36.953 --> 00:08:40.444
a single location that in which all
of the wires are directly connected.

168
00:08:40.444 --> 00:08:44.785
And then WAN's of course might be your
connection from the main office that you

169
00:08:44.785 --> 00:08:48.732
might be working with to branch offices
that your company also has maybe

170
00:08:48.732 --> 00:08:52.910
throughout the city or
maybe even throughout the country as well.

171
00:08:52.910 --> 00:08:57.180
These particular types of
classifications are not so

172
00:08:57.180 --> 00:08:59.980
important that we have to
understand every detail about them.

173
00:08:59.980 --> 00:09:02.660
But we do need to understand them if we're
gonna be working those companies and

174
00:09:02.660 --> 00:09:06.220
they talk about sending you out to
a branch office to work from there.

175
00:09:06.220 --> 00:09:08.460
And you're wondering well,
how am I gonna get my files?

176
00:09:08.460 --> 00:09:12.060

00:35:15.537 --> 00:35:16.752
In that way, we have use of that.

621
00:35:16.752 --> 00:35:20.427
So all of these involved those
service level type of agreement, and

622
00:35:20.427 --> 00:35:24.633
the same thing between you an your ISP,
will also have the same thing as well.

623
00:35:24.633 --> 00:35:28.007
So here in this episode, what we took
a look at in basic networking, right?

624
00:35:28.007 --> 00:35:32.514
Is kind of the over all categorization
here between the geographically

625
00:35:32.514 --> 00:35:34.326
located types of networks.

626
00:35:34.326 --> 00:35:38.552
In which we'll generally talk about in
business demarcation a lot of times.

627
00:35:38.552 --> 00:35:39.182
But then,

628
00:35:39.182 --> 00:35:43.889
we also talked about some of the different
types of networks in terms of access.

629
00:35:43.889 --> 00:35:47.867
Wireless networks, the idea of LANs and
what we generally see there, and

630
00:35:47.867 --> 00:35:51.733
also of course, the idea here of
connecting out to the internet, too.

631
00:35:51.733 --> 00:35:53.433
And just remember that you will see that.

632
00:35:53.433 --> 00:35:57.696
That the idea of all these things do kind
of merge together, but at the same time,

633
00:35:57.696 --> 00:36:00.344
they do have concepts that
we have to understand.

634
00:36:00.344 --> 00:36:04.160
Well, that's a great place for
us to sign off for this episode then.

635
00:36:04.160 --> 00:36:07.260
For ITProTV,
I've been your hose Ronnie Wong.

636
00:36:07.260 --> 00:36:08.280
>> And I'm West Bryan.

637
00:36:08.280 --> 00:36:12.878
>> Stay tuned right here, for
more IC3 computing fundamentals.

638
00:36:12.878 --> 00:36:21.240
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes show us some of the different data and system protection tools available to the user.  They discuss the use of system restore and data backups  They also show how to create restore points and use restore points.  They also show using the Windows 7 backup to backup and restore as well.  They remind us that to protect data we must consider backups as part of that strategy.
episodes.title: Backup and Restore
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.151 --> 00:00:10.151
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.160 --> 00:00:14.750
Welcome to another great
episode right here on ITProTv.

3
00:00:14.750 --> 00:00:16.770
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:16.770 --> 00:00:19.950
you're watching the IC3
computing fundamental show.

5
00:00:19.950 --> 00:00:24.400
And where we're about to take a look into
the realm of back ups and restoration.

6
00:00:24.400 --> 00:00:28.030
Now, it's one of the most important things
that we can actually do to help us prevent

7
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:31.230
data loss, so it's something we
definitely need to at least touch on and

8
00:00:31.230 --> 00:00:32.920
get a basic understanding of.

9
00:00:32.920 --> 00:00:36.400
And here to help us to actually
understand those details, Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:36.400 --> 00:00:37.590
Wes, welcome back to our studios.

11
00:00:37.590 --> 00:00:39.880
>> Thanks for having me Ronnie,
as always, great to be here.

12
00:00:39.880 --> 00:00:42.960
That's right,
we're gonna be looking at what should be

13
00:00:42.960 --> 00:00:46.100
part of normal system maintenance now.

14
00:00:46.100 --> 00:00:47.950
You heard Ronnie say
preventive maintenance,

15
00:00:47.950 --> 00:00:49.550
what is it that we're trying to prevent?

16
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:53.970
Well, data loss, you have important, we're
talking about information system right.

17
00:00:53.970 --> 00:00:57.760
And the information that is on those
system is just crucial to us and

18
00:00:57.760 --> 00:00:58.680
important to us.

19
00:00:58.680 --> 00:01:01.750
So one of the things we wanna make
sure that we can do is that we can

20
00:01:01.750 --> 00:01:06.400
protect our system for
what might be an inevitable failure.

21
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:09.760
Devices fail all the time, and it's
not a matter of if they're gonna fail,

22
00:01:09.760 --> 00:01:11.280
it's just a matter of
when they're gonna fail.

23
00:01:11.280 --> 00:01:15.490
Sometimes we're lucky enough, right, that
we don't have any problems with a machine.

24
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:19.370
I know I've got a little Compaq that I've
had jeez, I admit, seems like now it

25
00:01:19.370 --> 00:01:22.880
must be ten years, almost, that it's
going on since I first bought it.

26
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:25.160
So, have I had any problems with it?

27
00:01:25.160 --> 00:01:28.760
Well, not as far as the data's
concerned but I'm lucky.

28
00:01:28.760 --> 00:01:31.260
And one of the things that
you don't want to do is play

29
00:01:31.260 --> 00:01:34.730
a gamble with what's
important in your systems.

30
00:01:34.730 --> 00:01:36.460
Now, what is important to you?

31
00:01:36.460 --> 00:01:38.810
That's going to differ from
the next person, right?

32
00:01:38.810 --> 00:01:43.420
So for instance in a home environment,
maybe some of your documents

33
00:01:43.420 --> 00:01:46.010
that you have on your computer maybe,
maybe they are important,

34
00:01:46.010 --> 00:01:50.680
maybe they're not important, but maybe you
have things like a family pictures, right?

35
00:01:50.680 --> 00:01:54.710
As far as I'm concerned, there isn't
really a piece of software that I cannot

36
00:01:54.710 --> 00:01:58.610
afford to lose, and just completely, don't
worry about the drive fail, just throw

37
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:01.910
the drive out and get a new one and
reinstall the software and that's fine.

38
00:02:01.910 --> 00:02:05.790
However, you know for me I can't get
those pictures of my family back,

39
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:08.380
they're just you can't replace them.

40
00:02:08.380 --> 00:02:10.480
So that's what we're gonna
be talking about here is,

41
00:02:10.480 --> 00:02:15.760
how we can ensure that not only the system
can be restored if necessary but

42
00:02:15.760 --> 00:02:18.090
also the data itself can be too.

43
00:02:18.090 --> 00:02:19.220
All right so

44
00:02:19.220 --> 00:02:22.600
the first thing that we're gonna look at
we're gonna look at the system itself.

45
00:02:22.600 --> 00:02:26.470
And this is a technology that is inside
of Windows, it's been inside Windows for

46
00:02:26.470 --> 00:02:28.960
a while now it's called System Restore.

47
00:02:28.960 --> 00:02:32.430
Now one of the things that we're gonna
keep in mind here is that what system

48
00:02:32.430 --> 00:02:35.070
restore doesn't do all right.

49
00:02:35.070 --> 00:02:38.030
Cuz remember we're looking
at system restoration here,

50
00:02:38.030 --> 00:02:40.660
what this doesn't do is
restore the user data.

51
00:02:40.660 --> 00:02:43.410
So we're gonna kind of combine
two different things here.

52
00:02:43.410 --> 00:02:46.390
We'll talk about the data
restoration here coming up but

53
00:02:46.390 --> 00:02:48.960
we're gonna start here
with our system itself.

54
00:02:48.960 --> 00:02:52.570
Now, there are a couple of happenings or
going ons, if your will,

55
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:56.370
in your computing experience that might
cause problems that would need you to use

56
00:02:56.370 --> 00:02:58.490
this software known as System Restore.

57
00:02:58.490 --> 00:03:02.760
And some of the common things,
first of all it could be malware.

58
00:03:02.760 --> 00:03:04.970
We always talk about malware
could infect a system.

59
00:03:04.970 --> 00:03:08.210
And it might require you to rebuild
things like system files, right.

60
00:03:08.210 --> 00:03:12.920
The other thing too, that might happen is
installing drivers that maybe the driver

61
00:03:12.920 --> 00:03:15.700
is corrupt, this could cause
problems with your system.

62
00:03:15.700 --> 00:03:20.130
Maybe for whatever reason it locks
you out of your machine, well,

63
00:03:20.130 --> 00:03:21.630
that's another thing that could happen.

64
00:03:21.630 --> 00:03:25.580
You can install an application, an
application could cause problems as well.

65
00:03:25.580 --> 00:03:29.470
Or how about this,
you might even delete an application and

66
00:03:29.470 --> 00:03:31.810
sometimes you can bring that
back with system restore too.

67
00:03:31.810 --> 00:03:36.250
But the main thing we want to know about
system restore is it's a way that you can

68
00:03:36.250 --> 00:03:40.560
return your configuration on your
machine to an earlier point in time,

69
00:03:40.560 --> 00:03:44.530
should today be the day that things
go wrong with that computer.

70
00:03:44.530 --> 00:03:47.120
>> Now Wes before we go on any further and

71
00:03:47.120 --> 00:03:50.350
you show us exactly what's going on here,
let's talk about the need for

72
00:03:50.350 --> 00:03:55.150
system restore just a little bit more on
a basic side for some of our users, right?

73
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:58.950
The very fact is, your computer operating
system is really just software.

74
00:03:58.950 --> 00:04:01.150
The more often you use it,
you're gonna find out something and

75
00:04:01.150 --> 00:04:03.760
we're gonna talk about this in
probably a little bit of time as well.

76
00:04:03.760 --> 00:04:08.520
It's gonna start to change and
it's gonna start to add files in,

77
00:04:08.520 --> 00:04:10.630
sometimes what can end up happening,
right?

78
00:04:10.630 --> 00:04:15.590
Is that you download something and
you add it into your computer system, and

79
00:04:15.590 --> 00:04:20.685
now all the sudden, the computer doesn't
respond the way that you think it should.

80
00:04:20.685 --> 00:04:23.235
And so now, you might have gone two or

81
00:04:23.235 --> 00:04:27.105
three days just thinking well, I'll fix
it at some point, and you just don't.

82
00:04:27.105 --> 00:04:30.695
And after a while you start realizing
it's getting worse and worse, and

83
00:04:30.695 --> 00:04:34.715
now you're actually in trouble because
you're wondering I don't know what I did.

84
00:04:34.715 --> 00:04:36.835
I thought I actually had removed it but

85
00:04:36.835 --> 00:04:40.250
I didn't really remove it,
I still see some things happening.

86
00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:41.200
Well what can you do?

87
00:04:41.200 --> 00:04:46.460
Well that's where System Restore helps us
out, is in those situations in which when

88
00:04:46.460 --> 00:04:50.810
somebody says look, it was working fine
two days ago and now it's not working.

89
00:04:50.810 --> 00:04:56.270
This is something you may want to try
that will help us to recover at least

90
00:04:56.270 --> 00:05:01.870
the files as they were during that day
before you actually had some changes.

91
00:05:01.870 --> 00:05:04.770
So in the background what's going on
there in the System Restore, right.

92
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:10.420
It is actually going to say, look, Ronnie
you decided to install some software.

93
00:05:10.420 --> 00:05:13.300
But before you do that which looks
like it's gonna make a major change in

94
00:05:13.300 --> 00:05:15.520
the operating system,
let me go ahead and do this.

95
00:05:15.520 --> 00:05:19.250
Let me take a picture of the operating
system files, as they are right now.

96
00:05:19.250 --> 00:05:23.215
And in that way, when Ronnie you
install that and it changes something,

97
00:05:23.215 --> 00:05:25.043
you'll be very happy that I did.

98
00:05:25.043 --> 00:05:28.479
And the reason why is because
we can always go back to that

99
00:05:28.479 --> 00:05:31.187
time right before I
installed something and

100
00:05:31.187 --> 00:05:35.301
that will make all those files appear
as it were a snapshot in time.

101
00:05:35.301 --> 00:05:40.198
So hopefully rolling back those
changes the day before I actually made

102
00:05:40.198 --> 00:05:45.267
that change, and then, maybe getting
rid of the problem that I caused.

103
00:05:45.267 --> 00:05:47.930
Now Wes,
have you ever had to use System Restore?

104
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:51.180
>> Absolutely, on many occasions I've had
to use it and it's usually because of

105
00:05:51.180 --> 00:05:55.320
the errors that I have made not
the errors that others have made.

106
00:05:55.320 --> 00:05:57.170
So one of the things that we'll do.

107
00:05:57.170 --> 00:06:00.100
System restore, we're gonna check
first of all to see if it's enabled.

108
00:06:00.100 --> 00:06:04.070
One of the things that you need to pay
attention to is wherever it is that you're

109
00:06:04.070 --> 00:06:09.270
trying to bring these configurations
to that earlier point in time.

110
00:06:09.270 --> 00:06:12.200
You have to make sure that the drive
that associated with those files

111
00:06:12.200 --> 00:06:14.350
that it does have system
restore turned on.

112
00:06:14.350 --> 00:06:17.890
And that's the basic right there is
making sure that this is enabled.

113
00:06:17.890 --> 00:06:20.620
Let me show what I mean here,
we got a Windows 7 machine and

114
00:06:20.620 --> 00:06:21.950
we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna dive right in.

115
00:06:21.950 --> 00:06:26.580
Get into the Start Menu, and
on this one here, the interesting thing

116
00:06:26.580 --> 00:06:30.020
is we're gonna right click on our
computer icon on the Start Menu.

117
00:06:30.020 --> 00:06:32.800
We're gonna drop down to
what is known as Properties.

118
00:06:32.800 --> 00:06:34.330
Let me go ahead and
zoom in there right there, and

119
00:06:34.330 --> 00:06:37.020
you can see that we're
going to Properties.

120
00:06:37.020 --> 00:06:40.900
Now when we go to Properties this is
what's known as the System Control Panel

121
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:41.690
all right?

122
00:06:41.690 --> 00:06:45.550
And the System Control Panel is gonna
be where we can look at System Restore.

123
00:06:45.550 --> 00:06:49.770
And on the left-hand side here you'll
see that there is this System protection

124
00:06:49.770 --> 00:06:53.540
option, we're going to go ahead and
we gonna launch that.

125
00:06:53.540 --> 00:06:57.490
Now, this launches us from the System
Control Panel into what's known as

126
00:06:57.490 --> 00:06:58.920
the System Properties.

127
00:06:58.920 --> 00:07:01.570
And from the System Properties you can see

128
00:07:01.570 --> 00:07:04.310
we have what's known as
System Protection here.

129
00:07:04.310 --> 00:07:07.560
Now, with the System Protection,
notice that it says, what it tells us.

130
00:07:07.560 --> 00:07:10.430
Use the system protection to
undo unwanted system changes and

131
00:07:10.430 --> 00:07:13.020
restore previous versions of files.

132
00:07:13.020 --> 00:07:17.000
Now, the focus that we're
going to be looking at is

133
00:07:17.000 --> 00:07:21.000
restoring those unwanted system
changes that you've made, and

134
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:23.900
now you want to go back to that earlier
point, that's what we're going to do.

135
00:07:23.900 --> 00:07:26.500
Let's find out if
System Restore is turned on.

136
00:07:26.500 --> 00:07:28.968
Now with my Local Disk (C:), right?

137
00:07:28.968 --> 00:07:35.060
Local Disk (C:) being where all your
operating system files are on by default.

138
00:07:35.060 --> 00:07:37.270
Notice that it does say
that it is turned on.

139
00:07:37.270 --> 00:07:40.770
So that's good,
we know that System Restore is already on,

140
00:07:40.770 --> 00:07:45.110
our primary hardware, our primary storage
container that we need to focus on.

141
00:07:46.380 --> 00:07:51.380
Now, the next thing that we
have to do is we have to create

142
00:07:51.380 --> 00:07:55.230
something that Ronnie was kind
of alluding to here earlier.

143
00:07:55.230 --> 00:07:57.440
And that's something
known as a restore point.

144
00:07:57.440 --> 00:07:58.567
Now, that's the first thing.

145
00:07:58.567 --> 00:08:01.793
Now there are a couple of things
that trigger restore points, but

146
00:08:01.793 --> 00:08:05.148
let's talk about what the restore
point is before the triggering.

147
00:08:05.148 --> 00:08:09.497
The restore point is a point in time
snapshot of the configuration of your

148
00:08:09.497 --> 00:08:15.050
computer as it was the moment, well,
you create that checkpoint, if you will.

149
00:08:15.050 --> 00:08:19.400
Now, what happens is as you go and make
changes, if you make an unwanted change,

150
00:08:19.400 --> 00:08:23.480
if you get a virus on your computer that
makes changes to your operating system or

151
00:08:23.480 --> 00:08:25.940
maybe even install a driver
that causes a problem.

152
00:08:25.940 --> 00:08:28.690
And you decide that you're
going to go back to this

153
00:08:28.690 --> 00:08:33.250
point in time configuration
snapshot called the restore point.

154
00:08:33.250 --> 00:08:36.140
What it supposed to do
is undo those changes.

155
00:08:36.140 --> 00:08:37.680
Now, I talked about triggering,

156
00:08:37.680 --> 00:08:40.570
there are a couple of things in here
that trigger these restore points.

157
00:08:40.570 --> 00:08:42.650
In fact, let's see here,

158
00:08:42.650 --> 00:08:46.410
there's a way that you can see if
you've already got restore points made.

159
00:08:46.410 --> 00:08:49.020
This is something that
I like to make sure.

160
00:08:49.020 --> 00:08:52.380
Don't wait til you need a restore point to
figure out if the restore points are being

161
00:08:52.380 --> 00:08:53.000
created.

162
00:08:53.000 --> 00:08:55.940
Otherwise, this software really
isn't doing you any good.

163
00:08:55.940 --> 00:08:59.590
So if I decide that I'm gonna
do a system restore, right?

164
00:08:59.590 --> 00:09:02.310
I can do the System Restore and
we're not actually doing the restore,

165
00:09:02.310 --> 00:09:06.080
I'm using this to find out if I
already have those restore points.

166
00:09:06.080 --> 00:09:09.610
So notice that it says Restore
system files and settings.

167
00:09:09.610 --> 00:09:12.010
I'm gonna choose Next in this wizard.

168
00:09:12.010 --> 00:09:16.320
And here we go,
we can see that we do have some

169
00:09:16.320 --> 00:09:20.020
automatically created
point in time snapshots.

170
00:09:20.020 --> 00:09:24.440
All right, now like I was saying earlier,
one of the things that triggers this,

171
00:09:24.440 --> 00:09:27.880
application installations,
driver installations, right?

172
00:09:27.880 --> 00:09:30.450
Windows Update,
it applies updates to a machine,

173
00:09:30.450 --> 00:09:34.110
right before that happens
it creates a checkpoint.

174
00:09:34.110 --> 00:09:36.990
So that let's say if
Windows Update is downloaded, and

175
00:09:36.990 --> 00:09:40.540
maybe there's some kinda communication
breakdown and it corrupts the file and

176
00:09:40.540 --> 00:09:42.500
it causes problems in your computer.

177
00:09:42.500 --> 00:09:46.530
You can always roll back, restore
back to that earlier point in time.

178
00:09:46.530 --> 00:09:49.150
Same thing goes with applications,
when it comes to applications,

179
00:09:49.150 --> 00:09:53.120
if you install an application, it becomes
problematic, you need to get rid of it.

180
00:09:53.120 --> 00:09:55.470
Well, you can come in here and
you can use your restore point and

181
00:09:55.470 --> 00:09:57.730
you can restore to that
earlier point in time.

182
00:09:57.730 --> 00:10:00.320
Now I'm gonna go ahead and
cancel out of this wizard.

183
00:10:00.320 --> 00:10:03.500
One of the things I wanted to do is just
see if I had any restore points available

184
00:10:03.500 --> 00:10:05.330
before we do the next one.

185
00:10:05.330 --> 00:10:08.990
Okay, so if I was to install
let's say an application,

186
00:10:08.990 --> 00:10:11.340
it would trigger one automatically.

187
00:10:11.340 --> 00:10:14.610
But I wanna show you how to
create one manually as well.

188
00:10:14.610 --> 00:10:17.360
All right,
notice we have this Create button here.

189
00:10:17.360 --> 00:10:21.430
The Create button allows me to
manually define a restore point.

190
00:10:21.430 --> 00:10:25.476
All right and
what we're gonna do we call this Demo.

191
00:10:25.476 --> 00:10:26.600
You can name it what you want,

192
00:10:26.600 --> 00:10:30.700
name it as far you're naming can mention
make sure that it's easily identifiable.

193
00:10:30.700 --> 00:10:34.090
Maybe, you're installing like a graphics
card, drivers something you might call it

194
00:10:34.090 --> 00:10:38.640
graphics card driver install or
driver install and that's up to you.

195
00:10:38.640 --> 00:10:41.510
Just make sure that it's
easily recognizable so

196
00:10:41.510 --> 00:10:43.940
that you know where to restore back to.

197
00:10:43.940 --> 00:10:48.400
And we're gonna go ahead and
we'll choose Create.

198
00:10:48.400 --> 00:10:50.505
Now in manually creating
that restore point,

199
00:10:50.505 --> 00:10:56.265
Is doing the same identical thing that
the automatic restore point was doing.

200
00:10:56.265 --> 00:10:59.145
Notice it says the restore
point was created successfully.

But the major difference between
the full backup and this differential,

426
00:23:04.970 --> 00:23:08.910
you'll notice that the backups
are starting to slowly increase in size.

427
00:23:08.910 --> 00:23:10.140
Well why is that?

428
00:23:10.140 --> 00:23:12.866
That's because on Monday,
if I make changes to documents, right,

429
00:23:12.866 --> 00:23:14.890
they're gonna have those
archived bits present.

430
00:23:14.890 --> 00:23:18.550
That means the backup subsystem
goes all of these files?

431
00:23:18.550 --> 00:23:19.820
I need to back up.

432
00:23:19.820 --> 00:23:22.710
I'm just backing up the changes, though.

433
00:23:22.710 --> 00:23:23.765
And it's a little bit different.

434
00:23:23.765 --> 00:23:25.060
We're not backing up everything.

435
00:23:25.060 --> 00:23:29.120
It says well I have got a full backup so
let me look on Monday and

436
00:23:29.120 --> 00:23:31.060
just see what's changed.

437
00:23:31.060 --> 00:23:36.300
Then when Tuesday comes in we're
gonna make some changes as well.

438
00:23:36.300 --> 00:23:39.850
But then when we run the backup system
it's also gonna see those changes that

439
00:23:39.850 --> 00:23:42.050
happened back on Monday as well.

440
00:23:42.050 --> 00:23:45.060
So that it is gonna
back up those likewise.

441
00:23:45.060 --> 00:23:47.230
And then so on and so forth.

442
00:23:47.230 --> 00:23:50.640
On Wednesday we're gonna make our new,
unique changes that

443
00:23:50.640 --> 00:23:55.220
weren't there on Tuesday and weren't
there on Monday, the red disk here.

444
00:23:55.220 --> 00:23:59.523
But then it sees all of the changes
that have been made for

445
00:23:59.523 --> 00:24:02.557
the past two days and it includes that.

446
00:24:02.557 --> 00:24:07.703
And then it does it for Thursday, and by
Friday, we've got a pretty large backup.

447
00:24:07.703 --> 00:24:10.707
Now what is the benefit and
drawbacks to this one?

448
00:24:10.707 --> 00:24:14.089
Well, let's talk about the drawback first.

449
00:24:14.089 --> 00:24:16.950
The drawback is that the backup set.

450
00:24:16.950 --> 00:24:18.920
And again I'm gonna tell you
what the backup set means.

451
00:24:18.920 --> 00:24:21.700
The data that you need to restore
gets larger and larger and

452
00:24:21.700 --> 00:24:23.730
larger as you go through the week.

453
00:24:23.730 --> 00:24:28.060
The benefit to that over
the full backup is that it's not

454
00:24:28.060 --> 00:24:32.010
quite as full as a full backup,
so it doesn't take quite as long.

455
00:24:32.010 --> 00:24:36.940
Now, one of the great, one of the other
drawbacks I would say to that is the fact

456
00:24:36.940 --> 00:24:40.970
that when you restore, all right,
when you do your restoration.

457
00:24:40.970 --> 00:24:43.720
You need this full backup
because that contains all

458
00:24:43.720 --> 00:24:46.220
of the data that you had the prior week.

459
00:24:46.220 --> 00:24:50.030
And then let's say if
it fails on Thursday,

460
00:24:50.030 --> 00:24:55.230
I need that full backup, and I also
need the backup set for the prior day.

461
00:24:55.230 --> 00:25:00.640
And then when I do my
restoration those two components

462
00:25:00.640 --> 00:25:06.670
the two different amounts of information
make up a total restoration.

463
00:25:06.670 --> 00:25:11.170
But again this backup doesn't take quite
as long as the full backup to do, but

464
00:25:11.170 --> 00:25:13.589
it does start to progressively get larger.

465
00:25:14.850 --> 00:25:18.211
The last one we'll talk about is
called the incremental back-up, and

466
00:25:18.211 --> 00:25:21.440
the incremental back-up,
if I could say that right,

467
00:25:21.440 --> 00:25:25.030
does something a little bit
different than the differential.

468
00:25:25.030 --> 00:25:29.910
It says I only care about
what has changed today, and

469
00:25:29.910 --> 00:25:31.430
that's all I am going to back up.

470
00:25:31.430 --> 00:25:33.840
I am gonna look at the full backup, right?

471
00:25:33.840 --> 00:25:37.510
I am gonna see, well on Monday we're
making some unique files, unique changes,

472
00:25:37.510 --> 00:25:39.020
I'll back that up.

473
00:25:39.020 --> 00:25:42.280
But then on Tuesday, I don't care
about what happened on Monday,

474
00:25:42.280 --> 00:25:46.540
I just wanna know what happened on Tuesday
and I'm gonna back that data up, and

475
00:25:46.540 --> 00:25:50.120
then likewise Wednesday,
Thursday and Friday.

476
00:25:50.120 --> 00:25:53.780
Notice it doesn't care about the prior
days and the backups stays small,

477
00:25:53.780 --> 00:25:54.700
that's the benefit to it.

478
00:25:54.700 --> 00:25:57.210
It doesn't take too long
to backup your data.

479
00:25:57.210 --> 00:26:01.010
The drawback is let's say that
same analogy that on Thursday,

480
00:26:01.010 --> 00:26:02.720
I lose my machine.

481
00:26:02.720 --> 00:26:05.000
I come in on Thursday and
everything's gone.

482
00:26:05.000 --> 00:26:08.980
Right, with a full backup I just need the
tape from Wednesday I just need the backup

483
00:26:08.980 --> 00:26:10.730
set from Wednesday and I'm good.

484
00:26:10.730 --> 00:26:15.360
If its differential I need the full
backup and Wednesday, unfortunately

485
00:26:15.360 --> 00:26:18.940
on the incremental backup because they
are incremental I need Wednesday,

486
00:26:18.940 --> 00:26:23.580
I need Tuesday, I need Monday and
I need that full backup.

487
00:26:23.580 --> 00:26:27.160
And you can see by putting
all of those together,

488
00:26:27.160 --> 00:26:30.460
that ends up being the full
restoration that's needed.

489
00:26:30.460 --> 00:26:33.980
So the backup process
takes a little bit longer.

490
00:26:33.980 --> 00:26:36.330
Now that being said I've
talked about a backup set low.

491
00:26:36.330 --> 00:26:38.540
What do you say Ronnie we
actually see this in action,

492
00:26:38.540 --> 00:26:41.900
no more theory let's jump in and
show you what we're talking about.

493
00:26:41.900 --> 00:26:45.530
I'm gonna drop back down to control panel,
remember that's through the start menu.

494
00:26:46.910 --> 00:26:49.160
We'll bring up the control panel.

495
00:26:49.160 --> 00:26:51.990
We're gonna go to system and security,

496
00:26:51.990 --> 00:26:55.980
and right down here is back up and
restore right.

497
00:26:55.980 --> 00:26:57.625
We're going to use that utility.

498
00:26:57.625 --> 00:27:01.245
Now the first thing you You have to do
is what's known as backup scheduling.

499
00:27:01.245 --> 00:27:05.685
I can't do a backup if I don't
first turn the software on and

500
00:27:05.685 --> 00:27:10.765
say at this date at this time,
I'm gonna perform a backup.

501
00:27:10.765 --> 00:27:12.230
So let's go ahead and do that.

502
00:27:12.230 --> 00:27:15.780
We're gonna set our backup and
it's gonna start the Windows backup,

503
00:27:15.780 --> 00:27:18.260
but it's not actually running
the backup process yet.

504
00:27:18.260 --> 00:27:23.390
It's saying okay, well,
what do you want to back up, all right?

505
00:27:23.390 --> 00:27:26.450
Now what we have to do

506
00:27:26.450 --> 00:27:31.080
is we have to ensure that the disk
that we have has enough space on it.

507
00:27:31.080 --> 00:27:36.070
And I can tell you that if I
try to back up on this drive,

508
00:27:36.070 --> 00:27:39.980
well guess what it's not gonna allow
me to do that, it says only four Gigs.

509
00:27:39.980 --> 00:27:44.670
So let's go ahead and real quick,
let me change that and

510
00:27:44.670 --> 00:27:47.630
make it big enough as that I can use that.

511
00:27:47.630 --> 00:27:51.600
So should have hand that,
should have thought about that before, but

512
00:27:51.600 --> 00:27:54.080
we can go ahead and
we can change that real quick.

513
00:27:54.080 --> 00:27:58.270
So let me make that volume
capable to be backed up to

514
00:27:59.600 --> 00:28:04.680
and we will,
let's start that process one more time,

515
00:28:04.680 --> 00:28:07.120
and we should see that
we have enough space.

516
00:28:07.120 --> 00:28:08.530
Notice that it says recommended.

517
00:28:08.530 --> 00:28:12.800
Why did it change from not allowing me to,
to recommended?

518
00:28:12.800 --> 00:28:16.340
Wherever you back up to you have to have
enough space to fit the information in

519
00:28:16.340 --> 00:28:17.800
there, so we'll go ahead and do that.

520
00:28:17.800 --> 00:28:18.642
We'll choose next.

521
00:28:18.642 --> 00:28:25.330
And again, you can let Windows
choose what it needs to back up, and

522
00:28:25.330 --> 00:28:28.900
it'll know what it needs to do, but we're
gonna go ahead and say just let me choose.

523
00:28:29.960 --> 00:28:34.680
We'll choose next, and here are all the
different locations that you can back up.

524
00:28:34.680 --> 00:28:36.840
You can also include
a complete system image,

525
00:28:36.840 --> 00:28:41.540
which is just a full snapshot of your hard
drive right now, we're not gonna do that.

526
00:28:41.540 --> 00:28:43.150
We're gonna go ahead and uncheck this.

527
00:28:43.150 --> 00:28:43.900
We'll go ahead and

528
00:28:43.900 --> 00:28:48.330
uncheck all these other files just to
make it a little bit faster here for us.

529
00:28:48.330 --> 00:28:53.405
And what I'm gonna do is, I'm gonna
make sure that it backs up my documents.

530
00:28:53.405 --> 00:28:56.780
Now that being said what
documents do I have to backup?

531
00:28:56.780 --> 00:29:00.990
Let's go ahead and create a document
really quick, and we'll call this test.

532
00:29:00.990 --> 00:29:06.500
And we are gonna go ahead and we are gonna
put another test file really quick

533
00:29:06.500 --> 00:29:12.640
inside of our Documents location, and
we'll call this test2, and let's go ahead.

534
00:29:12.640 --> 00:29:14.160
Now that we set the schedule.

535
00:29:14.160 --> 00:29:16.580
Notice that it tells me,
what is backed up?

536
00:29:16.580 --> 00:29:19.210
And if I needed to change the schedule,
I could.

537
00:29:19.210 --> 00:29:21.550
Notice that by default,
this is what we have.

538
00:29:21.550 --> 00:29:24.200
All right, I'm not gonna change it,
but it is part of,

539
00:29:24.200 --> 00:29:28.260
if you are gonna head do the scheduling.

540
00:29:28.260 --> 00:29:31.580
You should know how to modify the schedule
if the default doesn't work for you.

541
00:29:31.580 --> 00:29:34.380
Now you can see that the backup
is in process right here.

542
00:29:36.340 --> 00:29:40.330
And we will go ahead, notice we
could view the details if we want,

543
00:29:40.330 --> 00:29:43.630
it says creating a shadow copy and
that really didn't take too long.

544
00:29:43.630 --> 00:29:48.330
So it looks like the backup has
Happened like we want it to.

545
00:29:48.330 --> 00:29:51.010
So Ronnie what do you say
we simulate an error here?

546
00:29:51.010 --> 00:29:56.980
We'll go ahead, we'll delete this file,
and I'll delete it from the,

547
00:29:56.980 --> 00:30:01.970
let me select the right thing here so
I get the appropriate right-click options.

548
00:30:01.970 --> 00:30:06.839
We'll go into our folder here,
Documents folder that we just used.

549
00:30:08.540 --> 00:30:12.680
There's our test file, and
we're gonna go ahead and delete this, and

550
00:30:12.680 --> 00:30:16.660
we'll make sure that it isn't any smoke
and mirrors here, you know there's nothing

551
00:30:16.660 --> 00:30:19.870
up my sleeves like you can probably
see that, because it's short sleeves.

552
00:30:19.870 --> 00:30:22.030
All right, now we've got a failure.

553
00:30:22.030 --> 00:30:24.330
I need to get this data
back how do I do it.

554
00:30:24.330 --> 00:30:29.440
Well here's how we perform the restoration
let's go ahead and show you guys that.

555
00:30:29.440 --> 00:30:32.790
All right, so we're gonna go back
to Control Panel > System and

556
00:30:32.790 --> 00:30:36.150
Security, back to Backup and Restore,

557
00:30:36.150 --> 00:30:40.750
I know that's a little redundant there,
and notice this Restore My Files.

558
00:30:40.750 --> 00:30:43.450
All right, so
we're gonna say Restore My Files and

559
00:30:43.450 --> 00:30:45.980
it gives me the option to search for
individual files.

560
00:30:45.980 --> 00:30:50.530
If you happen to know what the file is
it's in what's known as the backup set.

561
00:30:50.530 --> 00:30:53.900
Now, I mentioned a backup set earlier but
I would take a second here real quick and

562
00:30:53.900 --> 00:30:55.270
show you what I mean.

563
00:30:55.270 --> 00:31:00.900
If I dropdown the Windows Explorer and
I go to the location, in which I stored

564
00:31:00.900 --> 00:31:05.520
that backup information, notice I have
a file here, that's what a backup set is.

565
00:31:05.520 --> 00:31:10.940
A backup set is the data that you are
keeping on hand in case of a failure so

566
00:31:10.940 --> 00:31:12.270
that you can restore.

567
00:31:12.270 --> 00:31:15.030
So, let's go ahead, and
let's let this Wizard.

568
00:31:15.030 --> 00:31:18.670
We'll browse for folders, make sure
that I said, I said, browse for files.

569
00:31:18.670 --> 00:31:20.590
How about we browse for folders.

570
00:31:20.590 --> 00:31:25.290
I'll select the backup of the C drive
that we just created, I'll choose,

571
00:31:25.290 --> 00:31:30.370
add the folder, as you can see here, we'll
choose, next, and it asks me if I wanna

572
00:31:30.370 --> 00:31:33.400
back it up to a different location,
or to the original location?

573
00:31:33.400 --> 00:31:36.330
We'll go ahead and keep the original
location, and we're gonna perform

574
00:31:36.330 --> 00:31:40.760
the restore, and it's telling me,
do you wanna copy and replace these files?

575
00:31:40.760 --> 00:31:44.600
I'm just gonna go ahead and say,
I want to copy and replace.

576
00:31:44.600 --> 00:31:48.548
There is one file that it can't do, and
I'll tell you what this error is about.

577
00:31:48.548 --> 00:31:52.120
That's the desktop.ini file,
cuz it's also backing up that, and

578
00:31:52.120 --> 00:31:55.720
that's a configuration file, and
it's saying hey there's a conflict there.

579
00:31:55.720 --> 00:31:59.652
I'm not worried about that file cuz I
already have one on the desktop, and

580
00:31:59.652 --> 00:32:00.930
we'll choose Finish.

581
00:32:03.142 --> 00:32:10.140
And I'm gonna go to my Documents folder
and sure enough there is my test document.

582
00:32:10.140 --> 00:32:14.420
Now, one of the reasons I
left out the desktop is,

583
00:32:14.420 --> 00:32:18.640
to show you the fact that you have to
choose the right locations, right?

584
00:32:18.640 --> 00:32:21.940
All I chose, in the backup, was documents.

585
00:32:21.940 --> 00:32:23.060
I didn't choose the desktop.

586
00:32:23.060 --> 00:32:27.030
So, you notice what isn't on my desktop,
my file.

587
00:32:27.030 --> 00:32:30.780
So, that's just an example of making sure,
that, when you do the restoration,

588
00:32:30.780 --> 00:32:36.540
that you've selected the right locations
in your backup scheduling to begin with.

589
00:32:36.540 --> 00:32:39.350
Because you don't wanna wait until you
need a backup to make sure that you've got

590
00:32:39.350 --> 00:32:41.150
these configurations right.

591
00:32:41.150 --> 00:32:41.800
Why?

592
00:32:41.800 --> 00:32:43.670
Because exactly what happened there.

593
00:32:43.670 --> 00:32:49.230
Notice I do have what I included,
test two is there, but what I don't have

594
00:32:49.230 --> 00:32:53.240
is a misconfiguration of the settings,
and that's the one on the Desktop.

595
00:32:53.240 --> 00:32:57.170
Backup and restoration, not too hard
as long as you know what to do,

596
00:32:57.170 --> 00:33:00.450
just make sure that you perform
backups and you test them.

597
00:33:00.450 --> 00:33:04.080
Don't wait till you need them in order
to figure out if they worked or not.

598
00:33:05.170 --> 00:33:09.250
>> When you're a regular computer
user on a daily basis at a business,

599
00:33:09.250 --> 00:33:11.110
you might not be asked to backup at all.

600
00:33:11.110 --> 00:33:15.200
So don't assume that you have to do any
of this that we've just showed you.

601
00:33:15.200 --> 00:33:16.980
But in a home environment,

602
00:33:16.980 --> 00:33:20.840
especially if you do have data that you
want to ensure that's going to be kept,

603
00:33:20.840 --> 00:33:24.720
you need to make sure you have
a plan to backup your system.

604
00:33:24.720 --> 00:33:28.160
And even though we showed you the way
that's included inside of Windows 7

605
00:33:28.160 --> 00:33:31.930
itself, there are utilities out there
that will do the same thing for

606
00:33:31.930 --> 00:33:33.450
you that Wes has shown you.

607
00:33:33.450 --> 00:33:38.540
For example the other day I ended up
with a nice little USB hard drive,

608
00:33:38.540 --> 00:33:42.540
and when I plugged it directly into my
computer it asked me if I wanted to

609
00:33:42.540 --> 00:33:47.280
go ahead and make a backup of
the entire computing system right then.

610
00:33:47.280 --> 00:33:49.780
And all I had to do was
follow the menu system along.

611
00:33:49.780 --> 00:33:53.670
Well that's another example of a backup
that you can have, that allows for

612
00:33:53.670 --> 00:33:57.410
if something were to happen on
the following day after I backed it up,

613
00:33:57.410 --> 00:34:01.200
I should be able to just plug that device
in there, and rerun that software,

614
00:34:01.200 --> 00:34:03.660
and follow the instructions for
the restoration.

615
00:34:03.660 --> 00:34:07.210
Wes showed us the manual process for
being able to inside of Windows, so

616
00:34:07.210 --> 00:34:10.680
just kind of understand that
there are those things available

617
00:34:10.680 --> 00:34:13.380
to help ensure we won't lose the data.

618
00:34:13.380 --> 00:34:17.230
Also when we take a look at the idea of
system restore, well not both of these,

619
00:34:17.230 --> 00:34:21.160
might not be something that you'll ever do
inside of that workplace environment, but

620
00:34:21.160 --> 00:34:23.010
it could be that they
asked you to do that,

621
00:34:23.010 --> 00:34:27.500
so you need at least know where some
of this is gonna be located as well.

622
00:34:27.500 --> 00:34:31.010
Well that's a great place for
us to also end this episode as well.

623
00:34:31.010 --> 00:34:34.310
Signing off for ITProTV,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong.

624
00:34:34.310 --> 00:34:35.230
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

625
00:34:35.230 --> 00:34:38.715
>> Stay tuned here for
more IC3 computing fundamentals.

626
00:34:38.715 --> 00:34:48.290
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Wes describe the concept of cloud computing and how it effects the user.  They describe the different types of cloud computing services that are available.  Also they talk about some of the different services available for most end users.  They also talk about it’s importance to the computing world today and that most people use cloud services regardless of whether they know it or not.
episodes.title: Cloud Computing
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.223 --> 00:00:15.645
Welcome back to another great
episode right here on ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.645 --> 00:00:17.282
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong, and

00:00:17.282 --> 00:00:20.062
you're watching
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals show.

5
00:00:20.062 --> 00:00:24.274
Where we are about to take a look at
what the realm of cloud computing.

6

Now we've really been sticking to
the desktop environment talking about

00:00:29.147 --> 00:00:33.800
the PC itself, the system unit and
really a microcosm of itself.

8
00:00:33.800 --> 00:00:38.210
But now when we start getting into the

00:00:38.210 --> 00:00:41.390
And we are now going to float into

Wes, welcome back to our show.

00:00:42.860 --> 00:00:46.330
>> Thanks man, I mean who better to have

12
00:00:46.330 --> 00:00:47.051
>> That's right.

13
00:00:47.051 --> 00:00:49.325
>> Everybody knows my
head is in the clouds.

14
00:00:49.325 --> 00:00:50.498
[LAUGH] That's right.

15
00:00:50.498 --> 00:00:54.020
So we're gonna look at some of the
concepts here that we need to understand.

16
00:00:54.020 --> 00:00:57.440
Again, keep in mind there are many
different cloud technologies there, and

17
00:00:57.440 --> 00:00:59.170
they can go many different ways.

00:25:03.853 --> 00:25:10.660
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Wes introduce the basic computing security concepts.  They emphasize the importance of security implementations being goal oriented: Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.  The discuss some of the different way to implement credentials: passwords, SSO and password managers.  Also they discuss connecting securely through your browser and how to see it or implement it.  Wes also mentions the purpose of the firewall for the computer user and demonstrate some of the settings within the Windows Firewall.
episodes.title: Security

Data integrity prevents

So if I take something finally like this,

The concept here is to understand by

As you add additional characters you're

When you formulate your password,

If I love guitars, I love music, well,

So I wanna make something that's unique to

make it something that maybe somebody

based on my traits

178
00:10:03.420 --> 00:10:08.901
Now, that being said, there are a couple

that we wanna kinda take care of here,

You do run the risk, Ronnie was telling

gauge ourselves with as to make sure that

Confidentiality, he mention data

Well, here is the problem I can make this

So now we've done the first two that

00:10:38.880 --> 00:10:39.850
nobody can get into my computer.

186
00:10:41.160 --> 00:10:45.400
Integrity, since no one can get into
the computer they can’t modify the data.

187
00:10:45.400 --> 00:10:46.820
So we met the first two.

188
00:10:46.820 --> 00:10:49.140
The problem is now that

the availability is completely hindered.

So what will I do?

As you start to make this

00:11:02.000 --> 00:11:02.980
Well, now here's the problem.

You've got it in a written format that if

00:11:07.680 --> 00:11:09.240
they can get into your computer and

now it doesn't matter that

80 character password because now somebody

00:11:19.110 --> 00:11:20.220
How about this?

The other thing that is

00:11:27.889 --> 00:11:29.350

00:11:29.350 --> 00:11:31.010
And there are applications or

implementations inside of
a corporate network where maybe they

00:11:38.240 --> 00:11:42.320
Sharing passwords is something

Now, reusing passwords is

207
00:11:45.948 --> 00:11:50.468
And there's a couple of different ways or
reasons that we might reuse a password or

208
00:11:50.468 --> 00:11:52.379

209
00:11:54.450 --> 00:11:58.660
First and foremost we're gonna say if

They will also implement something

And this is an implementation,

We call it policies, but think of it as
a rule that says, okay, once you've used,

217
00:12:26.370 --> 00:12:28.790
in fact, we can go back to my screen here.

218
00:12:28.790 --> 00:12:33.620
Once you've used this password,
right here.

219
00:12:33.620 --> 00:12:36.010
I don't want you to reuse this password.

220
00:12:36.010 --> 00:12:39.640
I'm gonna require you to

221
00:12:39.640 --> 00:12:42.130
So we'll use some of

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes demonstrate and explain some of the commonly used PC troubleshooting tools and methods in IT. Here they show you how to use built-in features found in the Windows operating system like UAC settings, Compatibility Mode, and Backup and Restore. They also explore potential causes/cures for the dreaded Blue Screen Of Death(BSOD) as well as tools like msconfig, Reliability Monitor, and Event Viewer.

00:25:51.090 --> 00:25:55.780
Also keep in mind that you do not

00:25:55.780 --> 00:25:57.470
This does not back up user data.

00:25:57.470 --> 00:25:59.610
That's what backup and restore is for.

00:25:59.610 --> 00:26:04.900
This just creates these point-in-time

472
00:26:04.900 --> 00:26:07.970
So for instance, I install a driver.

00:26:07.970 --> 00:26:09.560

00:26:18.560 --> 00:26:25.570
Well, If I grab one of these restore

00:26:25.570 --> 00:26:30.130

479
00:26:30.130 --> 00:26:33.700
However, Dan and

480
00:26:33.700 --> 00:26:38.580
It's not gonna restore data that might
be lost as far as the user data.

481
00:26:38.580 --> 00:26:41.780
That's why you don't rely
on system restore for that.

482
00:26:41.780 --> 00:26:44.660
You rely on the back up and
restore process.

All right, so that takes us

00:27:10.140 --> 00:27:14.499
software's written and how drivers
interact with the operating system.

490
00:27:14.499 --> 00:27:21.260
But being said I blue screen probably
every Windows edition since XP to now.

491
00:27:21.260 --> 00:27:24.989
This is sometimes on a monthly basis
just doing different tests and

492
00:27:24.989 --> 00:27:27.940
configurations so
never say never on this one.

493
00:27:27.940 --> 00:27:30.949
So what are some of the things
the potential causes that can happen with

494
00:27:30.949 --> 00:27:32.072
the blue screen of death?

495
00:27:32.072 --> 00:27:37.503
Well we have things like bad memory,
bad CPU, hard drive issues, bad driver,

496
00:27:37.503 --> 00:27:43.530
commonly too especially in things like
your laptop environments overheating.

497
00:27:43.530 --> 00:27:46.120
All right so what are some of the
utilities that you are gonna use in order

498
00:27:46.120 --> 00:27:48.570
to troubleshoot things like
blue screens of death.

499
00:27:48.570 --> 00:27:49.130
All right.

500
00:27:49.130 --> 00:27:51.990
And again this is where
we're kinda get in to the,

501
00:27:51.990 --> 00:27:53.730
let's go back to the computer here.

502
00:27:53.730 --> 00:27:56.170
And remember I told you Windows Explorer,
right?

503
00:27:56.170 --> 00:27:59.690
Well you probably didn't think
of Windows Explorer as the being

504
00:27:59.690 --> 00:28:02.900
some kinda utility that you can use in
order to troubleshoot a blue screen.

505
00:28:02.900 --> 00:28:07.000
Now if it's a repetitive blue screen you
might have to go to more advance methods.

506
00:28:07.000 --> 00:28:11.801
But if I open up Windows Explorer.

507
00:28:11.801 --> 00:28:16.490
And I right-click,
all right, on local disk C.

508
00:28:18.120 --> 00:28:20.090
Notice that I can choose Properties.

509
00:28:21.220 --> 00:28:23.790
And I've got a couple of options, right?

510
00:28:23.790 --> 00:28:27.660
If I think that it's a hard-drive issue,
I can go to Tools right here.

511
00:28:28.690 --> 00:28:31.010
And from Tools I've got
a couple of options.

512
00:28:31.010 --> 00:28:35.320
If I think it's a hard drive issue, look,
I can use what is known as Check Disk.

513
00:28:35.320 --> 00:28:38.550
Now, Check Disk this is
the graphical user interface.

514
00:28:38.550 --> 00:28:41.150
I've tried to stay away from
the command line on this one.

515
00:28:41.150 --> 00:28:43.130
But understand inside the command line,

516
00:28:43.130 --> 00:28:48.380
you can run CHKDSK with
a couple of options behind it.

517
00:28:48.380 --> 00:28:50.000
And what does it do?

518
00:28:50.000 --> 00:28:53.410
Well, it does the same thing as
choosing this check now option.

519
00:28:53.410 --> 00:28:56.440
Keep in mind that we cannot
check the disk for errors,

520
00:28:56.440 --> 00:29:00.210
as the operating system is currently using
it, so this happens, it schedules it,

521
00:29:00.210 --> 00:29:02.550
if you will, and
it happens on the next reboot.

522
00:29:02.550 --> 00:29:06.790
We could either automatically fix the file
system errors, and we can also scan for

523
00:29:06.790 --> 00:29:10.330
and attempt the recovery of data that's
maybe in sectors on the hard drive that

524
00:29:10.330 --> 00:29:11.490
are starting to fail.

525
00:29:11.490 --> 00:29:15.780
So you can start to see that blending
of hardware and software here.

526
00:29:15.780 --> 00:29:20.570
The other thing that I could run is things
like, for instance, Disk Defragmenter.

527
00:29:20.570 --> 00:29:21.780
And that's right here.

528
00:29:21.780 --> 00:29:27.290
And as well disk cleanup
to get rid of different

529
00:29:27.290 --> 00:29:32.050
potentially If you have fragmented files,
if you have a lot of log files behind

530
00:29:32.050 --> 00:29:34.910
these unnecessary files,
that can also cause problems.

531
00:29:34.910 --> 00:29:39.460
Not so much though with, however,
with the blue screen of death.

532
00:29:39.460 --> 00:29:41.105
Now when it comes to
the blue screen of death,

533
00:29:41.105 --> 00:29:45.955
there's one other one that I want to talk
about, well actually a couple more here.

534
00:29:45.955 --> 00:29:50.165
And that is bad memory and a bad driver.

535
00:29:50.165 --> 00:29:53.045
So, first things first where
we'll talk about bad memory.

536
00:29:53.045 --> 00:29:56.540
We're gonna go to the Start button,
all right?

537
00:29:56.540 --> 00:29:59.560
We're going to grow to Control Panel
> System and Security, and

538
00:29:59.560 --> 00:30:02.060
we're gonna drop down to
Administrative Tools.

539
00:30:02.060 --> 00:30:03.140
And I want you to know that

540
00:30:03.140 --> 00:30:06.440
inside of here there's something called
the Windows Memory Diagnostic, all right?

541
00:30:06.440 --> 00:30:09.180
If you think you have bad memory in
the machine and it's causing problems,

542
00:30:09.180 --> 00:30:11.250
you can run this and
it checks your memory for errors.

543
00:30:11.250 --> 00:30:14.440
If it finds the errors it's gonna give
you an output on the reboot screen

544
00:30:14.440 --> 00:30:17.420
that lets you know hey we've
detected problems with your memory.

545
00:30:17.420 --> 00:30:20.560
And in this case you know that it's time
to service the memory in the machine and

546
00:30:20.560 --> 00:30:23.390
it could be causing the blue screen.

547
00:30:23.390 --> 00:30:27.890
Last one here is,
as I know we are coming up on time here.

548
00:30:27.890 --> 00:30:33.740
Got more to go, but I do want to get this
one in here because it relates to BSOD and

549
00:30:33.740 --> 00:30:39.625
that is also gonna be inside
of the administrative tools.

550
00:30:39.625 --> 00:30:42.850
A couple different ways, in fact,
let's do a completely different way,

551
00:30:42.850 --> 00:30:44.530
let me show you computer management.

552
00:30:44.530 --> 00:30:48.950
Start, you right click the computer and
you choose Manage and

553
00:30:48.950 --> 00:30:51.170
inside of here, you have Device Manager.

554
00:30:51.170 --> 00:30:55.030
And as you've seen in other episodes,
if you're not familiar with what this is,

555
00:30:55.030 --> 00:30:57.870
go back and
watch our episodes on PC configuration.

556
00:30:57.870 --> 00:31:02.050
Keep in mind, this is the place that, if
I think I have bad drivers, I can go in.

557
00:31:02.050 --> 00:31:05.819
I can view by right clicking on
the component, choosing Properties.

558
00:31:06.880 --> 00:31:12.420
And I can see driver details as well
as potentially updating the driver or

559
00:31:12.420 --> 00:31:15.400
rolling it back should
it blue screen on you.

560
00:31:15.400 --> 00:31:20.310
All right, so that is one thing that
you can do and I know I keep saying

561
00:31:20.310 --> 00:31:23.690
that's enough for this one I do have
one more on the blue screen of death.

562
00:31:23.690 --> 00:31:26.900
And that is something known as msconfig.

563
00:31:26.900 --> 00:31:31.880
Msconfig is going to be something that
allows us if we end up blue screening.

564
00:31:33.240 --> 00:31:37.420
All right what we can do is we can enter
a Diagnostic startup mode if we want or

565
00:31:37.420 --> 00:31:43.630
we could change the boot to Safe boot
with minimalistic boot which it says,

566
00:31:43.630 --> 00:31:46.920
don't load any of those third-party
drivers that might be causing the problem.

567
00:31:46.920 --> 00:31:50.860
Just load what the operating
system needs to get functional so

568
00:31:50.860 --> 00:31:53.960
that you can get in there and
potentially roll back those drivers

569
00:31:53.960 --> 00:31:57.140
through Device Manager and
then maybe update the driver and

570
00:31:57.140 --> 00:32:00.010
install the appropriate driver should
it start to give you problems.

571
00:32:00.010 --> 00:32:04.860
So, Dan that's the blue BSOD but I better
turn this back to Dan because he's looking

572
00:32:04.860 --> 00:32:07.370
at me and I think we're turning and
burning on that clock right now.

573
00:32:07.370 --> 00:32:08.800
>> That clock has burned,

574
00:32:08.800 --> 00:32:12.405
it's done it's a smoldering wick sitting
on a stool in front of us right now.

575
00:32:12.405 --> 00:32:14.510
[LAUGH] But Wes, some great stuff though.

576
00:32:14.510 --> 00:32:16.560
Obviously these are common
trouble shooting things,

577
00:32:16.560 --> 00:32:20.360
they are common issues that we have
that we need to be able to overcome

578
00:32:20.360 --> 00:32:23.980
without having to pick up a phone and
dial up a help desk.

579
00:32:23.980 --> 00:32:25.230
What do we like to say?

580
00:32:25.230 --> 00:32:27.630
You give a man a fish,
you feed him for a day.

581
00:32:27.630 --> 00:32:31.870
You teach a man to fish, and you, or
a woman, it can be anybody, right?

582
00:32:31.870 --> 00:32:34.500
Any person out there that would
like to eat on a regular basis,

583
00:32:34.500 --> 00:32:35.778
we're gonna teach you how to fish.

584
00:32:35.778 --> 00:32:39.420
And do troubleshooting techniques so
that you don't have to rely on anybody but

585
00:32:39.420 --> 00:32:42.770
yourself to figure out what's going on
get your computer back up and running.

586
00:32:42.770 --> 00:32:45.400
Wes, are we looking down
the barrel of a part two on this?

587
00:32:45.400 --> 00:32:47.320
>> We are.
>> Alright looks like we've got

588
00:32:47.320 --> 00:32:48.720
another one coming up for you.

589
00:32:48.720 --> 00:32:51.440
Part two on this so
hopefully we'll see you in that episode.

590
00:32:51.440 --> 00:32:54.480
As for this one though, thanks for
stopping by Wes We'll see you there.

591
00:32:54.480 --> 00:32:56.060
We'll hopefully see you there as well.

592
00:32:56.060 --> 00:32:58.080
We're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this episode.

593
00:32:58.080 --> 00:33:00.830
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

594
00:33:00.830 --> 00:33:01.710
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

595
00:33:01.710 --> 00:33:03.594
>> See you next time.

596
