episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue to demonstrate and explain some of the commonly used PC troubleshooting tools and methods in IT. They pick back up by showing you how to diagnose and repair slow application response and unresponsive apps using tools like the Performance Monitor, Task Manager, and Resource Monitor.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Software Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:10.008
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.159 --> 00:00:15.715
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.715 --> 00:00:18.600
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and today's episode,

4
00:00:18.600 --> 00:00:22.760
well, we're back for more of
the IC3 Computing Fundamentals series.

5
00:00:22.760 --> 00:00:25.770
Joining us back in the studios again for
part two, a little bit more to go on

6
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:29.030
troubleshooting software,
is our good friend Mister Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:29.870
Welcome back.

8
00:00:29.870 --> 00:00:30.668
Glad to have you.

9
00:00:30.668 --> 00:00:31.360
Fire away.

10
00:00:31.360 --> 00:00:33.290
>> [LAUGH] I appreciate it.

11
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:35.255
I talked way too much in the first one.

12
00:00:35.255 --> 00:00:37.645
Now, all kidding aside,
all joking aside, guys,

13
00:00:37.645 --> 00:00:42.995
we did have a couple more that I wanted
to show, but time was not on our side.

14
00:00:42.995 --> 00:00:45.975
It certainly wasn't a friend
of ours in that last episode.

15
00:00:45.975 --> 00:00:48.467
And we certainly don't want
to rush you through it.

16
00:00:48.467 --> 00:00:50.797
We just got a couple more
that we're gonna add here.

17
00:00:50.797 --> 00:00:56.667
And it is probably something that at least
at one point you will probably face.

18
00:00:56.667 --> 00:00:59.467
So it does lend itself to these last two.

19
00:00:59.467 --> 00:01:00.688
Let's show you what we mean.

20
00:01:00.688 --> 00:01:01.228
We'll go ahead.

21
00:01:01.228 --> 00:01:07.558
We'll talk about slow application response
times and an unresponsive application.

22
00:01:07.558 --> 00:01:11.384
Now one of the biggest things I can tell
you is when you have slow application

23
00:01:11.384 --> 00:01:15.456
response time is to make sure first of
all you're running an antivirus software

24
00:01:15.456 --> 00:01:18.457
because we can blame some of
these conditions on viruses.

25
00:01:18.457 --> 00:01:21.134
I didn't mention that in part one,
a blue screen of death,

26
00:01:21.134 --> 00:01:24.508
it could really be a virus, could be
a piece of malware that's got onto your

27
00:01:24.508 --> 00:01:27.690
system or a rootkit or something
like that that's causing problems.

28
00:01:27.690 --> 00:01:30.390
So even with the blue screen of
death make sure that you've got,

29
00:01:30.390 --> 00:01:33.345
you should always have antivirus
running in real-time protection.

30
00:01:33.345 --> 00:01:37.560
But if you do start to see these
problematic happenings and nothing's

31
00:01:37.560 --> 00:01:42.633
changed on your machine, you haven't
dealt with drivers, you haven't installed

32
00:01:42.633 --> 00:01:48.550
applications, that might be time to run an
antivirus scan and a full scan, at that.

33
00:01:48.550 --> 00:01:53.980
Now, what are some things that can
cause slow application response times?

34
00:01:53.980 --> 00:01:55.430
Could be a full hard drive, right?

35
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:58.680
Remember, we need to store information and
when applications create additional

36
00:01:58.680 --> 00:02:02.540
information they also, in turn,
need to be able to store that, right?

37
00:02:02.540 --> 00:02:03.780
These are information systems.

38
00:02:03.780 --> 00:02:05.060
That's what it's about.

39
00:02:05.060 --> 00:02:07.870
And when the storage
location starts to get full,

40
00:02:07.870 --> 00:02:11.480
you can start to see things
like slow response times.

41
00:02:11.480 --> 00:02:14.900
An application takes a little bit
longer to launch up because, remember,

42
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:18.600
the operating system is busy talking to
the drive controller saying hey, get me

43
00:02:18.600 --> 00:02:22.700
the pieces of the file and I know it's in
here somewhere, I'll find it eventually.

44
00:02:22.700 --> 00:02:25.930
And certainly can take a while for
the application to launch.

45
00:02:27.480 --> 00:02:30.010
The other thing that
could be is low memory.

46
00:02:30.010 --> 00:02:34.420
With 64-bit systems being so prevalent
today, this is potentially less and

47
00:02:34.420 --> 00:02:35.200
less of a problem.

48
00:02:35.200 --> 00:02:36.320
But we can't really say that,

49
00:02:36.320 --> 00:02:40.950
because there are still certain
implementations out there that are 32-bit.

50
00:02:40.950 --> 00:02:43.590
And even if you're talking about
things like tablets and stuff,

51
00:02:43.590 --> 00:02:46.400
you might be limited to the memory
constraints that you have.

52
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:48.369
So what can we do if you have low memory?

53
00:02:49.550 --> 00:02:50.970
Well, you could upgrade your memory.

54
00:02:50.970 --> 00:02:53.980
[LAUGH] And if you can't upgrade or
put in additional memory,

55
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:56.890
then chances are you're gonna
have to move to another system.

56
00:02:56.890 --> 00:02:59.980
However, I will tell you, there is one
thing that you can do and let me show you.

57
00:02:59.980 --> 00:03:02.272
If you do have a limited amount of memory,

58
00:03:02.272 --> 00:03:04.904
you can optimize what is
known as a paging file.

59
00:03:04.904 --> 00:03:07.256
And a paging file, guys, very basically,

60
00:03:07.256 --> 00:03:11.515
it means that I can use a portion of the
hard drive as though it were physical RAM,

61
00:03:11.515 --> 00:03:14.520
like we were talking about
on our hardware components.

62
00:03:14.520 --> 00:03:19.392
And this has the potential to help
you when you do have the low memory

63
00:03:19.392 --> 00:03:23.660
issues here that might be
restricting the applications.

64
00:03:23.660 --> 00:03:25.040
So, let me show you how
you we would do this.

65
00:03:25.040 --> 00:03:27.140
We're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna drop down to our start menu,

66
00:03:27.140 --> 00:03:32.730
we're gonna right-click on computer and
then, we are going to choose properties.

67
00:03:32.730 --> 00:03:37.670
And when our properties control panel
comes up, we do have some hyper or

68
00:03:37.670 --> 00:03:39.750
task links, as as they call them.

69
00:03:39.750 --> 00:03:43.280
We're gonna go ahead and
jump into Advanced system settings.

70
00:03:43.280 --> 00:03:46.850
All right, because we're looking
at performance issues, right?

71
00:03:46.850 --> 00:03:47.680
Well, look at here,

72
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:52.460
we got a category right on the advanced
tab here that does say Performance.

73
00:03:52.460 --> 00:03:54.049
Well, what is this about?

74
00:03:54.049 --> 00:03:58.306
I want you to notice that we can, let me
kinda move that out of the way there,

75
00:03:58.306 --> 00:04:02.177
out above my head, notice we have
what's known as virtual memory.

76
00:04:02.177 --> 00:04:05.750
That's what the paging file
essentially consists of.

77
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:11.010
It's not actual physical RAM modules,
right, that we can see on the motherboard.

78
00:04:11.010 --> 00:04:12.980
It's software-based memory.

79
00:04:12.980 --> 00:04:15.120
And more appropriately, again,

80
00:04:15.120 --> 00:04:18.550
software-based virtualized memory
is what's on that hard drive.

81
00:04:18.550 --> 00:04:22.860
And if we want, we could choose
the settings here, all right.

82
00:04:22.860 --> 00:04:27.110
And notice that we have visual effects
here, too, and I wanna kinda mention

83
00:04:27.110 --> 00:04:30.580
that as well as being something
that you could modify here.

84
00:04:30.580 --> 00:04:36.100
Do I wanna adjust for best appearance or
do I wanna adjust for better performance?

85
00:04:36.100 --> 00:04:39.800
And again, if you do have a specific
application that's causing problems and

86
00:04:39.800 --> 00:04:43.580
you do have limited memory resources,
or even computing resources,

87
00:04:43.580 --> 00:04:46.080
maybe the CPU's a couple years behind,

88
00:04:46.080 --> 00:04:48.805
then what you can do is you can
adjust this for better performance.

89
00:04:48.805 --> 00:04:53.270
And Windows goes through and it knows how
to scale some of this resource utilization

90
00:04:53.270 --> 00:04:55.560
down so maybe you'll get
a better computing experience.

91
00:04:55.560 --> 00:04:59.710
But when it comes to virtual memory,
we wanna go to the Advanced tab and

92
00:04:59.710 --> 00:05:04.680
looking at the Advanced tab, here is
where we can modify that paging file.

93
00:05:04.680 --> 00:05:05.760
Notice what it says here, guys.

94
00:05:05.760 --> 00:05:06.520
By definition,

95
00:05:06.520 --> 00:05:12.080
a paging file is an area on the hard disk
that Windows uses as if it were RAM.

96
00:05:12.080 --> 00:05:13.280
All right, so what's going on here?

97
00:05:13.280 --> 00:05:16.910
In other operating systems, I believe, and
Dan might correct me if I'm wrong on this,

98
00:05:16.910 --> 00:05:19.100
you might even hear this
called the swap file, right?

99
00:05:19.100 --> 00:05:20.240
Cause what are we doing?

100
00:05:20.240 --> 00:05:22.970
We're taking memory or
data that's in memory and

101
00:05:22.970 --> 00:05:24.530
we're putting into the hard drive.

102
00:05:24.530 --> 00:05:27.590
And we're taking that information
that an application's looking for

103
00:05:27.590 --> 00:05:30.810
off of the hard drive and we're
swapping it back into physical memory.

104
00:05:30.810 --> 00:05:33.610
All right,
Windows typically manages this for us.

105
00:05:33.610 --> 00:05:35.620
Let me show you here
that you can change it.

106
00:05:35.620 --> 00:05:39.200
And I will give you the recommended
specifications by Microsoft

107
00:05:39.200 --> 00:05:41.070
if you are gonna manage this.

108
00:05:41.070 --> 00:05:43.910
Do I manage these settings at all?

109
00:05:43.910 --> 00:05:45.070
Not at all.

110
00:05:45.070 --> 00:05:46.310
I don't usually change these.

111
00:05:46.310 --> 00:05:51.060
With the commonality of 64 bit operating
systems typically having plenty of RAM,

112
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:53.760
Windows can manage this all it wants.

113
00:05:53.760 --> 00:05:57.010
There are situations where I try to
enhance performance on this because

114
00:05:57.010 --> 00:06:02.000
of the fact that I do not wanna give
the paging file 16 gigabytes on my hard

115
00:06:02.000 --> 00:06:05.330
